Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Dominion Voting Systems employee Eric Coomer told an Antifa meeting he “made sure” Donald Trump wouldn’t win.
Justification: Eric Coomer is a former Dominion Voting Systems employee who made anti-Trump comments on his Facebook page in 2016. Colorado conservative activist and podcaster Joe Oltmann claims he heard Coomer speaking on an "antifa conference call" before the 2020 election telling participants he "made sure" former President Donald Trump wouldn’t win the election. Oltmann has provided no evidence of the 2020 allegation, and Coomer is suing Oltmann for defamation.
Sources: Email interview with Dominion spokesperson Stephanie Walstrom

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Kamala Harris has a “drinking problem.”
Justification: This video was altered to slow Vice President Kamala Harris’ speech. Original footage from her address at an Oct. 27 Philadelphia rally shows she spoke with a typical cadence.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "The cocaine found in the White House was Kamala’s.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded. The U.S. Secret Service closed its investigation without a suspect citing a lack of evidence.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “ICE officials have been ordered NOT to wear their uniforms or badges when they vote today" so as not to intimidate noncitizens.
Justification: Federal law prohibits Immigration enforcement activity at polling places. A U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement official said employees were reminded not to wear uniforms and insignia to avoid confusing voters. Noncitizens are already prohibited from voting in federal elections.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “It’s now been confirmed by Dominion that their voting machines have a programming issue that will affect vote counts.”
Justification: Michigan voters using Dominion Voting Systems’ voter assist terminals, which are designed to help voters with disabilities, could receive an error message if they choose "straight-ticket" voting, and then decide to vote across party lines. Dominion and Michigan election officials said a programming issue is causing this. Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson initially said during an Oct. 28 press briefing that the programming issue was "nationwide." Her office and Dominion later clarified that the problem is Michigan-specific. Michigan election officials said this problem is fixable and won’t prevent voters from casting ballots with their chosen candidates. Dominion did not say this problem will affect vote counts.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A “ballot mule” was caught on camera Nov. 2 in Lincoln, Nebraska.
Justification: Todd Wiltgen, the election commissioner of Lancaster County, where the video was taken, told PolitiFact he reviewed surveillance footage of the drop box and found the video shows an 18-year-old first-time voter dropping off his ballot, not a "ballot mule." The Nebraska Voter Accuracy Project, a group that has spread false claims about the 2020 and 2022 election being "stolen," sent Nebraska officials an email taking credit for the video.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows former President Donald Trump voting in the 2024 election in New York.
Justification: This image is from 2016, when former President Donald Trump and his wife Melania Trump cast ballots on Election Day in New York City.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Voting machines in Shelby County, Tennessee, are swapping votes from Kamala Harris to Donald Trump.
Justification: Some early voters in Shelby County, Tennessee, told Democratic state legislators that voting machine touchscreens were registering candidates they didn’t select. Election officials said there were no machine malfunctions. Voters using their fingers to  click a small box inside a larger box on the ballots might have inadvertently selected the candidate listed above. Officials urged voters to click the candidates’ names in the center of the box or use a provided stylus to mark the ballots.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris paid The Shade Room to interview her “for perceived support amongst black voters.”
Justification: The Shade Room’s founder, Angie Nwandu, told PolitiFact that Harris’ campaign did not pay for the interview. We searched Google and the Nexis news database for reports on a leak revealing that Harris paid to be on The Shade Room but found no credible results.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos show federal authorities arrested and charged a clone instead of the real Sean “Diddy” Combs.
Justification: The images are AI-generated deepfakes that spread online in March 2024. The real Sean "Diddy" Combs remains in federal custody awaiting trial.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Text message shows Turnout the Vote offering “$200 to vote for Kamala Harris.”
Justification: Turnout the Vote, a progressive voting advocacy group, said it does not compensate people for registering to vote or voting. The group pays voting ambassadors — people they hire to help organize support for a particular campaign ahead of the election — up to $200 as part of its get-out-the-vote efforts. Federal law prohibits offering to pay or making a payment to someone for voting, withholding a vote or voting for or against a particular candidate.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump wore “Proud Boy gang colors” Oct. 27, 2024, at Madison Square Garden.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump wore a blue suit and red tie Oct. 27 at his Madison Square Garden rally. He wore a black suit and golden-yellow tie at an Oct. 25 rally in Traverse City, Michigan.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris "proclaimed she would not accept the outcome of the election and has a team of lawyers ready to overturn them"
Justification: We reviewed the transcript of the NBC News interview and found that Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t say she wouldn’t accept the 2024 election results. In the interview, she criticized former President Donald Trump for trying to overturn the 2020 election results. Harris said her campaign had a team ready in case Trump declared victory on election night while votes are still being counted. But that’s not evidence of a plot to overturn the election result.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala campaign photoshops her with a McDonald’s uniform!”
Justification: There’s no evidence that Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign edited a photo to show her wearing a McDonald’s uniform. An X user took credit for the image and said it was fake.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video of Vice President Kamala Harris talking to a voter on the phone is fake because the camera app was on while she was on the call.
Justification: iPhones can run other apps during a call, according to iPhoneuser guidesfor operating systems 12 to 18. In the rest of the full video, Harris talks to other voters on speaker phone, other people’s voices can be heard while the phone app is open. We tried it ourselves on an iPhone and found that we could make a call with the camera app open.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Vice President Kamala Harris’ mother “worked the MK Ultra program” and was “involved in secret mind-control experiments.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris’ mother, Shyamala Gopalan, worked as a breast cancer researcher. The mind control experiments called MK-Ultra, part of a clandestine CIA program, were conducted at McGill University’s Allan Memorial Institute in Montreal; they began and ended several years before Gopalan moved from Berkeley, California, to Canada for work.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Beyonce got paid $10 MILLION for her speech” at a Kamala Harris rally.
Justification: PolitiFact searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports that the Harris-Walz campaign paid Beyoncé to endorse Vice President Kamala Harris or give remarks at a Houston rally on Oct. 25. Neither the Harris campaign nor Beyoncé’s representatives responded to a request for comment.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris imprisoned a woman for three years for praying.
Justification: Bevelyn Beatty Williams was sentenced to 41 months in prison for violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act, or the FACE Act, for physically obstructing access to a Manhattan Planned Parenthood and threatening patients and workers in June 2020. Williams was convicted in February after a unanimous jury found her guilty; Manhattan Judge Jennifer L. Rochon sentenced her. Vice President Kamala Harris was not involved in the case or the decision.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Vice Presidential nominee Tim Walz “says that if Democrats win they’ll make (U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez) speaker of the house.”
Justification: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, did not say Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y, would be the next House speaker if Democrats win back the House in November. Walz said Democrats will win the election and told Ocasio-Cortez they would "put a gavel in your hand in the House." In the House, the head of every committee or subcommittee controls the gavel in their hearings; there are 20 standing House committees and 104 subcommittees.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows 2024 ballots cast for Republicans in North Carolina that a postal worker said he was going to make “disappear.”
Justification: This is a photo from 2020 that shows blank absentee ballots in Wallingford, Connecticut.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “illegal ‘voters’ cutting the line” to vote in Pennsylvania.
Justification: Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, election officials said in a statement that a viral video captured a brief conversation between a group of voters, their translators and a local election official at a polling location. The voters in the video were there to apply for mail-in ballots. The older and disabled voters were allowed to sit, rather than stand in line, as their applications were processed, which is standard procedure, the county said. Only U.S. citizens who are registered to vote in Pennsylvania would have been able to apply for a mail-in ballot, the county said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris wants people to stop saying “Merry Christmas.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris did say, "How dare we speak Merry Christmas?" when she was a U.S. senator from California in 2017, but the video was taken out of context. The Instagram post omits the key detail that Harris was saying this under the context that Americans shouldn’t say "Merry Christmas" until Congress passed the DREAM Act, or Development, Relief and Education for Alien Minors. The DREAM Act would have provided a pathway to citizenship to children who came to the United States illegally.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: At Vice President Kamala Harris’ Houston campaign rally, when an attendee had a medical emergency, none of the “abortion doctors” onstage helped.
Justification: At Vice President Kamala Harris’ Oct. 25 Houston rally, a few minutes into Dr. Todd Ivey’s speech about the importance of abortion access, people from the crowd called out. Initially, the words were inaudible and interspersed with people booing the abortion access limitations Ivey described. Once it was clear someone had summoned a medic, Ivey amplified the call for help and gestured to where help was needed. He kept gesturing until it was confirmed aid was provided.
Sources: Emailed statement from Houston Fire Department

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "The Pentagon reportedly failed to send absentee ballots to active military service members before the election.”
Justification: The Defense Department doesn’t send absentee ballots to active overseas service members. Service members and their families must register with their home states, which are responsible for sending out absentee ballots. The Pentagon oversees the Federal Voting Assistance Program to help service members vote. If state ballots don’t arrive in time, service members can print out the Federal Write-In Absentee Ballot from the voting assistance program’s website.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a ‘Democratic operative’ making credible allegations of fraud during the 2020 presidential election in Georgia.
Justification: Secretly recorded video showed a man identified as Joel Caldwell making unspecific, unsubstantiated allegations of election malfeasance and reviving long-debunked claims about Georgia’s 2020 presidential election. The 2020 presidential election ballots in Georgia were counted three times and Joe Biden won each time. Republican state officials deny allegations of widespread fraud. We found no news reports or other information supporting social media posts’ assertions that Caldwell was involved with Georgia’s Democratic Party, and a party spokesperson said no one named Joel Caldwell was on the party’s payroll during the 2020 election cycle.
Sources: The Georgia Coalition for the People’s Agenda

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The FBI seized a video of former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton killing a child at a Sean “Diddy” Combs party.
Justification: The posts repeat false claims from a website known for publishing fabricated news stories. Federal authorities did seize videos from Sean "Diddy" Combs’ "freak off" parties, but court documents and reports by credible news outlets about these videos mention neither Clinton nor the killing of a child. There is no credible evidence former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton attended any of Combs’ parties.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “GA election official Gabriel Sterling says audits will take place after election day because it’s ‘nerve-racking’ to count ballots in front of poll watchers.”
Justification: The person in the video describing Georgia’s risk-limiting audits is not Gabriel Sterling, chief operating officer for the Georgia secretary of state. He is identified in both the Instagram clip and the transcript of the video as Joseph Kirk, an elections supervisor in Bartow County, Georgia. Counting votes is separate from a risk-limiting audit. Votes are counted to determine election outcomes; risk-limiting audits check a sample of ballots after an election to verify that the results have been correctly certified. Risk-limiting audits have been conducted after election results were certified in every election since 2020, a Georgia secretary of state spokesperson said.
Sources: The National Conference of State Legislators

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Fox News reported Donald Trump donated $1,300 for hurricane relief.
Justification: The image was not part of a Fox News report. It was not on Fox News’ website and a network spokesperson told PolitiFact in an email, "I can confirm this was not reported on FOX News." The image was shared as parody and has telltale signs of being artificially generated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Hurricane Nadine” was on a path to hit Florida on Oct. 10.
Justification: As of Oct. 12, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Hurricane Center had not reported that a storm called Nadine was developing near the U.S. Nadine is the next name on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s 2024 list of Atlantic tropical cyclone names.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “geoengineering happening” as Hurricane Milton approaches Florida.
Justification: The video does not show Hurricane Milton approaching Florida. It was uploaded in 2021. Experts told PolitiFact geoengineering cannot form hurricanes. Experts identified these clouds as asperitas, and said they’re associated with thunderstorms but don’t produce storms themselves.
Sources: The Harvard Solar Geoengineering Research Program
World Meteorological Organization International Cloud Atlas

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a missile strike on Israel.
Justification: The Instagram video does not show Israel on Oct. 1. We found the video posted on Facebook Jan. 4, 2023, showing footage from the Dubai Marina in the United Arab Emirates. Dubai’s government media office said December 2022 that mysterious lights in Dubai’s skies were caused by skydivers with pyrotechnics setting a Guinness World Record for highest-altitude skydiving firework display.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala Harris staged hurricane relief photo op with C-17, no supplies sent to victims.”
Justification: This claim is false. A mechanical issue was discovered on the plane after Vice President Kamala Harris was photographed near the aircraft, and the hurricane relief supplies were moved to another plane.
Sources: Statement from the North Carolina National Guard

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: North Carolina removed 747,000 voters from the voter rolls to try to “steal the election.”
Justification: The North Carolina State Board of Elections said  the state had removed about 747,000 voters from its voter rolls since January 2023. A board spokesperson and multiple election experts said the removals reflect routine voter list maintenance, as prescribed by state and federal law. It was not a one-time purge of voters, experts said.
Sources: North Carolina State Board of Elections
North Carolina State Board of Elections on YouTube
Phone interview with Hilary Harris Klein

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Sean “Diddy” Combs wrote the book “The Adrenochrome Witch.”
Justification: This book isn’t real.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “FBI finds human remains at a McDonald’s meat supplier.”
Justification: The video in the post shows a 2013 news report about a police investigation at International Biological Inc., a Detroit business. International Biological’s owner, Arthur Rathburn, was sentenced in 2018 to nine years in prison for selling diseased body parts for use in medical and dental training. Neither investigators nor prosecutors made any connection between International Biological and McDonald’s. The fast-food company was not mentioned in court documents about the case.
Sources: U.S. Attorney’s Office Eastern District of Michigan

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Hurricane Nadine was a catastrophic Category 5 hurricane that struck Central America and the Bahamas in October 2024.”
Justification: Hurricane Nadine didn’t exist as of Oct. 10, though the next storm could have that name. Text describing a Hurricane Nadine in the past tense came from a website on which users write fictional articles about hurricanes.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING: Diddy hospitalized after being jumped in prison.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.
Sources: Statement from the Federal Bureau of Prisons

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Missouri registered 78,421 in just one week of February of this year. Out of that number, 23,253 were dead people!"
Justification: The Social Security Administration’s Help America Vote Verification database doesn’t show the number of people who have registered to vote in the United States. The database shows the overall number of times a state has requested the verification of a potential voter’s Social Security number. Requests can be made multiple times for a single person, adding to the overall numbers featured in the database.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social, “I hope that America obliterates Israel.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump didn’t post that he hopes the United States obliterates Israel. He said he hopes that it obliterates Iran if the country’s "terrorist proxies" assassinate him.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Oregon secretary of state “removed” former President Donald Trump and U.S. Sen. JD Vance from “the official state website.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump and U.S. Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, don’t appear in Oregon’s voters’ guide because the Republican presidential and vice presidential nominees didn’t submit a statement for inclusion, according to the Oregon secretary of state’s office. They weren’t removed from the website.
Sources: Oregon Secretary of State candidate filing search

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Vice President Kamala Harris' comments in Augusta, Georgia, show the Biden administration is offering Hurricane Helene victims only $750 in relief.
Justification: This clip omits other parts of Vice President Kamala Harris’ remarks, in which she says the Federal Emergency Management Agency is providing "tens of thousands more dollars" to help people with home repair and temporary housing. FEMA said the "Serious Needs Assistance" amounting to $750 covers essential items such as "food, water, baby formula, breastfeeding supplies, medication and other emergency supplies."
Sources: Email exchange with The White House

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Oct. 6, 2024, fires in Beirut caused by Israeli airstrikes.
Justification: This footage was first shared Sept. 30 in a TikTok video that included an artificial intelligence-generated label. The user who first posted the video has a TikTok bio that says "AI artist" and the person told PolitiFact this and all of the videos on the account are generated with AI.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Liberal woman films herself eating dog food” because she said, “I’m eating dog food until Kamala is president.”
Justification: This video was altered. The original shows a Polish TikTok creator who pretends to be a dog. She doesn’t vow to eat dog food until Vice President Kamala Harris is elected president.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: If an election worker writes anything on your ballot before you put it in the voting machine, “your ballot could be disqualified.”
Justification: Election administrators from multiple states confirmed that election workers can’t invalidate your ballot by writing on it. In some states such as North Carolina and Texas, election workers are required by law to mark ballots in order to ensure election security.
Sources: North Carolina State Board of Elections

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: FEMA “blocked a runway” at a South Carolina airport and “halted” hurricane relief flights.
Justification: Organizers of the Runway Relief Project, staged at South Carolina’s Greenville Downtown Airport, collected donated supplies and arranged flights to distribute the donations to North Carolina’s Hurricane Helene victims. The group halted delivery flights Oct. 4 and stopped accepting donations Oct. 6 because it had received more than needed for now, organizers said. FEMA had nothing to do with that decision, organizers said in a video on Facebook. A little-used secondary airport runway was closed for three days to accommodate a FEMA-contracted medical group, but that didn’t affect flights in or out, an airport spokesperson said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Out of the 28 North Carolina counties destroyed by Hurricane Helene, 26 of them supported President Trump in the 2020 election … If you’re wondering why the government hasn’t helped these people, now you know why.”
Justification: North Carolina’s Democratic governor, Roy Cooper, requested a federal major disaster declaration Sept. 27 and President Joe Biden approved it the next day. Twenty-five counties were covered in the declaration, regardless of how they voted in the 2020 presidential election. As of Oct. 5, the Federal Emergency Management Agency provided at least $26 million to 25,000 North Carolina households. Biden also increased federal funding for emergency work in North Carolina on Oct. 2.
Sources: North Carolina Office of the Governor
North Carolina State Board of Elections
Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief And Emergency Assistance Act

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Hurricane Milton is part of Tampa’s plan to become a “15-minute city.”
Justification: A National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration official told PolitiFact that human weather modification did not cause Hurricane Milton. The "15-minute city" is an urban planning concept for designing cities to let residents meet basic needs with a short walk or bike ride from their homes. It has been the target of conspiracy theories about other disasters, including the 2023 Hawaii wildfires. Tampa officials are working to address the city’s transportation problems, including reducing commute times, but this is unconnected to the hurricane.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: As part of his “charitable donations,” in 1990 Donald Trump “chartered a private plane to get Nelson Mandela to America when the U.S. government wouldn't help."
Justification: In June 1990, Nelson Mandela, an anti-apartheid activist who spent 27 years in prison, toured eight U.S. cities as part of a larger world tour. While in the U.S., Mandela traveled in one of Donald Trump’s planes. Mandela paid Trump $130,000 to rent the plane; it wasn’t part of Trump’s "charitable donations," as some social media users claimed. The U.S. government paid for Mandela’s security and used a military plane to transport a bulletproof limousine across states during his eight-city tour. ​
Sources: New York City Department of Records and Information Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Univision accidentally shows that Kamala Harris is reading from a teleprompter live on air.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris spoke Oct. 10 at a town hall on Univision in Las Vegas. A teleprompter with words on it was seen in a short video clip shared online, but the Univision moderator and news president said the words were in Spanish and meant for the moderator, not Harris. After the words disappeared from the teleprompter, Harris continued her answer without pause for another three minutes.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Jussie Smollett is Kamala Harris’ nephew.
Justification: Jussie Smollett’s parents are not Kamala Harris’ siblings. They are also not the siblings of Kamala Harris’ husband nor her sister’s husband. Smollett’s mother and Harris share the same maiden name. This is not proof that they are sisters. "Harris" is the 25th most popular surname in the U.S., according to 2010 Census data. Harris’ parents are Indian and Jamaican; Smollett’s ancestry is African American, Russian and Polish.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows footage of Hurricane Milton in Florida.
Justification: The clips do not show footage of Hurricane Milton. Reverse-image searches revealed most of the video clips were taken from April 2022 to September 2024, before Milton made landfall Oct. 9. They show natural disasters in Iowa, Kansas, Brazil and Vietnam. One clip shows flooding caused by Hurricane Helene in September.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Vice President Kamala Harris commented on President Joe Biden’s “mental fitness,” saying, “he’s not stable” and “we should all be concerned.”
Justification: This video has been deceptively edited to give the appearance that Vice President Kamala Harris called President Joe Biden "unstable" during an Oct. 16 Fox News interview. Harris used that word to describe former President Donald Trump.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Hurricane Milton article is evidence they "control and plan these storms."
Justification: An article describing Hurricane Milton’s path and effects in past tense originated on a "Hypothetical Hurricanes" wiki page that lets weather enthusiasts create articles and graphics for fictional storm seasons. The wiki page about the fictional Milton was deleted because of misinformation concerns, the site’s administrator said. The name "Milton" had been planned by the World Meteorological Organization as one of 2024’s named storms. It replaced Michael, a storm that hit Florida in 2018, on the rotating list of storm names in 2019.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Tim Walz “falsely claims that being gay in Nebraska is ‘illegal’"
Justification: A viral clip from Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz’s speech at a pro-LGBTQ+ event shows him saying, "When I was a kid growing up in Nebraska, being gay was illegal, still technically illegal." Social media posts omitted that in his next sentence, he made clear he was referring to the laws of the past: "Look how much has changed since this organization was founded 40 years ago," Walz said. Laws criminalizing homosexuality were repealed in Nebraska in 1977, when Walz was about 13.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump admitted during the Sept. 10 presidential debate that he “blew up the Nord Stream pipeline.”
Justification: During the Sept. 10 presidential debate, when former President Donald Trump said, "I ended the Nord Stream 2 pipeline," he referred to sanctions he signed while in office that affected the project’s completion, not a 2022 attack that damaged the pipeline. A Trump campaign spokesperson called the claim "absolutely false and insane." Germany continues its investigation into the attack and in June issued an arrest warrant for a Ukrainian man suspected of being involved.  ​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows footage of Hurricane Helene
Justification: All the clips included in the viral video were shared online before Sept. 26, when Hurricane Helene made landfall on the western Florida coast as a Category 4 storm.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Hurricane Helene was the product of intentional weather modification.
Justification: There are no projects that can modify or create hurricanes. ​The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration conducted Project Stormfury in the 1960s to experiment with seeding existing hurricanes, but it ended in 1983 and no weather modification projects have been done since. ​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Tim Walz said "we can't afford four more years" of Kamala Harris.
Justification: In a Sept. 21 Pennsylvania speech, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz criticized Republicans for inaction after school shootings and said the country "can’t afford four more years of this." Walz, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, was not criticizing Vice President Kamala Harris. The clip was edited to remove his preceding comments and his subsequent remarks, which refer to the Trump-Vance campaign, not to Harris.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California S.B. 1174 eliminates the requirement for voter ID at polling places.
Justification: Already, California law says that the majority of voters are not required to provide ID when voting in person. S.B. 1174 prohibits local governments from requiring voter ID at polling places. It was drafted in response to a Huntington Beach, California, law that conflicted with state law and would require voters to show ID at polling places in 2026. All people must provide proof of identity when they register to vote in California. Falsifying voter registration information is a felony punishable by up to three years in prison.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A Haitian woman was arrested in Springfield, Ohio, for eating a cat.
Justification: Alexis Ferrell of Canton, Ohio, was arrested Aug. 26 on animal cruelty and disorderly conduct charges after Canton police said she tortured, killed and ate a cat in front of people in Canton. Ferrell is not a Haitian immigrant. She was born in Ohio and graduated from an Ohio high school in 2015, The Associated Press reported. Canton is about 175 miles northeast of Springfield, Ohio. Springfield city spokesperson Karen Graves told PolitiFact city authorities have received "no credible reports of pets being harmed, injured or abused by individuals within the immigrant community."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The government is arming “illegal immigrants.”
Justification: Migrants in the U.S. illegally are not allowed to possess guns or ammunition, according to federal law 18 U.S.C. 922. Michelle Mittelstadt, a spokesperson for the Migration Policy Institute, a nonpartisan think tank, told PolitiFact that the U.S. government is not providing migrants living in the country unlawfully with weapons or money to buy weapons. We searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports of the U.S. government supplying immigrants in the country illegally with weapons.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows helicopter “dropping millions” of mosquitoes in Massachusetts towns hit by eastern equine encephalitis virus.
Justification: Massachusetts on Aug. 16 announced its first human case of eastern equine encephalitis, a deadly mosquito-borne virus. About 10 communities are on high alert and some have issued voluntary curfews or closed public parks at dusk to control the virus’ spread. A video seen in a social media post doesn’t show mosquitoes being released from a helicopter there. It’s from Miami in 2023. Massachusetts has no such program.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Ku Klux Klan member at a rally for former President Donald Trump.
Justification: This video shows a self-described "troll" wearing a Ku Klux Klan costume to antagonize supporters of former President Donald Trump. The man, Michael Picard, told a reporter that he’s not a racist.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Haitians are responsible for the disappearance of 16 cats in Bangor, Maine.
Justification: This claim is unfounded. A spokesperson for the local police department said: "We have no reason to believe any specific ethnic group that numbers approximately a dozen people in the greater Bangor area are responsible for the disappearance of the missing cats."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Immigrants get $2,000 each time they cross the border illegally.
Justification: The federal government does not pay immigrants $2,000 each time they cross the border unlawfully. People who cross the border unlawfully the first time can be fined and imprisoned for up to six months. Repeat offenses could lead to more fines and up to two years of imprisonment. Refugees, who enter the country legally, qualify for cash assistance to cover food and housing in the first year of their arrival. Some Haitian and Cuban immigrants without refugee status are also eligible for the same benefits.
Sources: The Administration for Children and Families

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala Harris said she will shut down X if elected.”
Justification: In a 2019 interview, Vice President Kamala Harris discussed banning former President Donald Trump from Twitter. The full video of the interview shows she did not say she would shut down X, formerly Twitter, if she became president.
Sources: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. X post

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Four government agencies donated nearly $900,000 of taxpayer money to Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign.
Justification: Government agencies did not donate taxpayer money to Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign. The contributions the video cites are personal donations from people employed by or affiliated with government agencies. Open Secrets, a nonprofit organization that tracks money in politics, groups political campaigns’ top contributors by employer or affiliation to show where candidates are getting their support.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Walz dancing to Beyoncé in a cowboy hat and crop top.
Justification: This video was altered. The original video was posted in February and shows performer Matthew Krumpe dancing to "Texas Hold ‘Em."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Image claims Tiger Woods said “Kamala's fake black accent is embarrassing and extremely offensive.”
Justification: The originating X post containing this claim was made by a self-described satire and parody account. Tiger Woods has not recently made any public comments about Vice President Kamala Harris, according to a review of news stories and social media accounts.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Kamala involved in P-Diddy’s rapes and assaults.”
Justification: The Instagram post and the article it refers to does not present any evidence that Vice President Kamala Harris was involved in the crimes Sean "Diddy" Combs’ is accused of committing. We searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports of Harris being involved in Combs’ alleged crimes. Combs’ indictment does not mention Harris.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video shows a body that Israel embedded with a bomb exploding during a Palestinian funeral procession.
Justification: The video was taken during a funeral procession near Damascus, Syria in 2012, NBC reported. Activists told CNN in 2012 that the explosion was caused by a Syrian government-organized car bombing.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Karine Jean-Pierre, President Joe Biden’s press secretary, ended a press conference when a reporter asked about Donald Trump’s assassination attempt.
Justification: The clip is altered. In the full video, White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre answers the reporter’s question.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Debate moderators made the false claim to Donald Trump that there is nowhere in the United States where abortion is legal up until birth."
Justification: ABC News debate moderator Linsey Davis fact-checked a false claim by former President Donald Trump, who said Democrats support aborting babies after birth. Davis correctly pointed out that killing a baby after it is born is illegal in all 50 states.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: NFL’s Philadelphia Eagles endorsed Kamala Harris for president.
Justification: The Philadelphia Eagles said ads saying they endorsed Kamala Harris for president are fake. Intersection, the company that owns the bus stop shelters, said the Eagles didn’t create the ads and the ads were unauthorized to be there.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: CDC warns a third of adults may die from dangerous bacteria in ramen noodles.
Justification: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is not investigating any food-borne illnesses involving ramen noodles and has not issued any warnings about the products. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has not announced any recalls about ramen noodles because of deadly bacteria.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
U.S. Food and Drug Administration Sun Noodle Issues Allergy Alert on Undeclared Egg in S&S Frozen Cup Saimin

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “BREAKING: Police found ‘explosives’ in car near former President Donald Trump’s rally site on Long Island.”
Justification: Nassau County Police Commissioner Patrick Ryder said in a statement that reports about explosives at Donald Trump’s Uniondale, New York, rally were "unfounded." Ryder also said a person training a bomb detection dog falsely reported finding explosives.
Sources: Nassau County Police Department Facebook post

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Hollywood actor Kurt Russell just said: ‘It is now proven, beyond a shadow of a doubt that Kamala Harris and Joe Biden CHEATED in the 2020 election with mail-in ballots.’”
Justification: There is no record that actor Kurt Russell has said anything about there being 2020 election fraud. The only sources for this claim are anonymous social media accounts.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: CNN reported that the Apalachee High School shooting suspect was motivated by a “lack of trans acceptance.”
Justification: CNN did not report that the Apalachee High School shooting suspect was motivated by a "lack of trans acceptance." In an article published Sept. 5, CNN reported that a Discord account linked to suspect Colt Gray "expressed frustration with the acceptance of transgender people." CNN updated the article the next day to clarify this sentence. It now reads, the Discord account "expressed frustration that transgender people were being accepted in society."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: World Economic Forum “document confirms 6 billion humans will die in 2025.”
Justification: The claim originated as a headline on a site known for publishing misinformation, and the article’s byline is linked to other stories that spread conspiracy theories and false claims. The article that accompanies the headline cites as a source a website that says it relies on "Internet gurus" and "unsigned reports." We found no evidence that the World Economic Forum published such a document.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “A staffer reveals that Kamala Harris doesn’t actually own a gun.”
Justification: This video was manipulated. A spokesperson for Vice President Kamala Harris’ 2024 presidential campaign said the Democratic nominee does own a gun — not that she doesn’t.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In Pompano Beach, Florida, Somali immigrants illegally in the U.S. were in line to get driver’s licenses and “all you need to vote is a driver's license.”
Justification: Florida does not allow immigrants in the U.S. illegally to obtain driver’s licenses. Only U.S. citizens can vote in federal elections. The Florida Department of Motor Vehicles office pictured in this video was the subject of a news report about long wait times.
Sources: Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris “is not eligible to hold the office of president” because her parents were non-citizens.
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris was born in 1964 in Oakland, California. The 14th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution says that people born in the United States are citizens. Only natural-born citizens are eligible to be president, Article II of the Constitution says. Harris, born in the U.S., meets that standard, legal experts said.
Sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A Secret Service agent named Jonathan Willis said he “had the assassin in his sights for 3 minutes, but he was told not to engage by the head of the (Secret Service) unit.”
Justification: On July 14, an anonymous 4chan user claimed he was a Secret Service agent named Jonathan Willis who had been ordered not to shoot the gunman who opened fire at former President Donald Trump’s July 13 rally. A U.S. Secret Service spokesperson said the claim was "categorically false" and that the Secret Service does not employ anyone named "Jonathan Willis." The anonymous 4chan user ID was only linked to four posts, all dated July 14.
Sources: U.S. Secret Service spokesperson Anthony Guglielmi’s post on X

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Maxine Waters told her followers on X not to follow Omar Navarro because he is a “Hispanic Republican.”
Justification: The post is not on U.S. Rep. Maxine Waters’ official X or Instagram accounts. J. Ellis McGinnis, chief of staff for the California Democrat, told PolitiFact via email that the post was fake.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris has adopted the Nazi-rooted phrase “Strength Through Joy” as her campaign slogan.
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris has spoken about joy on the campaign trail and at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. At an Aug. 6 campaign rally in Philadelphia, vice presidential candidate and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz thanked Harris for "bringing back the joy." But we found no instances of Harris saying the "strength through joy" phrase in her presidential campaign speeches. We also found no credible news articles about this phrase being her campaign slogan.
Sources: Nexis searches of campaign speech transcripts and news articles for "‘Kamala Harris’ and ‘strength through joy

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Financial advisory company Austin Private Wealth shorted 12 million shares of Trump Media July 12, the day before former President Donald Trump’s attempted assassination.
Justification: Austin Private Wealth, an investment adviser, said the amount of shorted Trump Media shares reported in its July 12 filing was incorrect. The accurate holding amount was 1,200 shares, not 12 million.
Sources: Austin Private Wealth quarterly report filed by institutional managers

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden had a “medical emergency on Air Force One” on July 5.
Justification: Evidence does not support the claim that President Joe Biden suffered a medical emergency aboard Air Force One July 5. The press had full access to the plane during the flight and did not report a medical emergency. A video shows Biden exiting the plane unassisted after it landed and greeting a military officer.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There are nine states “where Biden’s name can’t be removed and no one can be added. That’s over 130 electoral votes in the toilet.”
Justification: President Joe Biden was the presumptive — not official — Democratic presidential nominee until he announced July 21 that he would be dropping out of the race. The official nominee will be chosen either in the run-up to the Democratic National Convention that starts Aug. 19 or at the convention itself. States set deadlines for receiving the names of presidential nominees so that ballots can be printed. Those deadlines are generally after the convention.
Sources: Indiana Secretary of State Diego Morales
Minnesota Secretary of State Steve Simon

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The shooter who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump was “Maxwell Yearick.”
Justification: The FBI identified the shooter at the July 13 Donald Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, as Thomas Matthew Crooks, a 20-year-old from Bethel Park, Pennsylvania. The gun used in the assassination attempt was traced to Crooks’ father. The FBI believes Crooks acted alone.
Sources: FBI Statement on Incident in Butler

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "President Zelenskyy’s wife orders 4 million dollar Bugatti” in Paris with U.S. tax money.
Justification: A claim that Ukrainian first lady Olena Zelenska preordered a $4 million luxury sports car while visiting France originated on a French website that was created June 22. A Bugatti Automobiles S.A.S. spokesperson said Zelenska did not buy one of its vehicles. Ukraine’s Center for Countering Disinformation called the claim Russian propaganda. Verite Cachee, where the claim first appeared, contains other articles that left instructions on how to write with a pro-Russia slant.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The NFL will now use facial recognition at every stadium to verify the identity of everyone at the game.”
Justification: NFL Communications Director Tim Schlittner said the league is implementing a new process for people "with working credentials" who need access to certain parts of the stadium. The new process will not apply to all fans. Under the new system, credential holders will be required to submit photos in advance and then "facial authentication" technology will be used to grant those people access to parts of stadiums, Schlittner said. Credential holders include team and game-day personnel, vendors and media, Schlittner said.
Sources: Chief NFL spokesperson Brian McCarthy’s X post

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden walked “onto an empty airplane for no reason.”
Justification: President Joe Biden boarded a plane that brought three former American prisoners to Maryland to talk to the flight crew, according to the White House and multiple journalists. Video footage shows the plane wasn’t empty.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Switzerland banned mammograms.
Justification: Mammography is not banned in Switzerland, according to the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health. It’s covered by health insurance and recommended for women ages 40 to 75. Breast cancer screening programs are available in 14 out of the 26 Swiss cantons, or states.
Sources: The New England Journal of Medicine

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden “killed his first wife.”
Justification: President Joe Biden’s first wife, Nealia, died in a car crash in 1972 in Hockessin, Delaware. Biden was in Washington, D.C., at the time.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: CNN producer “caught on hot mic” commenting on Maxine Waters’ “wig problem.”
Justification: The post included a voice-over, not a CNN producer, commenting on the situation. Don Lemon did not laugh at Maxine Waters. The video used a clip from 2018, and Lemon was fired from CNN in 2023.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden is stepping down from the 2024 presidential race because he’s dead.
Justification: President Joe Biden didn’t die, but social media users are claiming he’s been dead since 2018 and that’s why he recently withdrew from the 2024 presidential race.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Videos of media talking about Tim Walz as a "happy warrior" are proof of government propaganda legalized by Barack Obama.
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris and her presidential running mate, Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, have sought to portray themselves as "joyful warriors." News reports and cable news pundits have reported on this approach, and many referred to Walz as a "happy warrior," a common political nickname that dates back at least 100 years. Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who was first elected president in 1932, used it in a speech about New York Gov. Al Smith at the 1924 Democratic National Convention. The Smith-Mundt Modernization Act of 2012, signed into law by President Barack Obama, did not legalize propaganda in the U.S. The law, which has no effect on privately owned news outlets, eased U.S. broadcast restrictions on government-funded media, such as Voice of America.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris voted in favor of passing a law in 2022 to tax tips.
Justification: Tips were federally taxed before Vice President Kamala Harris voted in favor of the Inflation Reduction Act in 2022. The IRS’ tip reporting program is unrelated to the Inflation Reduction Act. It was introduced in 2023 as a way for employers in the service industry to voluntarily report tips. Similar tip compliance programs have existed since 1993.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Craigslist ad shows “every single person” at Kamala Harris’ Arizona rally was paid.
Justification: A Craigslist ad offering anti-Trump protesters $15 per hour to attend a Phoenix event is from 2020. Vice President Kamala Harris’ Arizona presidential campaign rally was held at an arena in Gilbert, Arizona, and not at the Phoenix Convention Center, the location listed in the ad.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kamala Harris posted about banning Barron Trump’s friend from X because he wore a “Biden Loves Minors” shirt.
Justification: The post is on neither of Harris’ official X accounts. Social media analytics show that Harris has not deleted any X posts in the last 30 days. A Harris spokesperson told USA Today that Harris did not repost the image of Donald Trump’s son’s friend, Bo Loudon, wearing a derogatory T-shirt.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Olympic air pistol shooting medalist took up the sport during his divorce and told his ex-wife from the podium, “I want my dog back.”
Justification: Turkish air pistol shooter Yusuf Dikec is an Olympic silver medalist who went viral on social media for his casual demeanor and attire. Claims that he took up shooting during a messy divorce and asked his ex-wife for his dog back while standing on the Olympic podium originated as satire.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “thousands of Christians in France gathered to pray after Olympics opening mocked Jesus Christ.”
Justification: This video was taken in 2022, so it predates the Paris Olympics. It shows thousands of people gathered at the Sanctuary of Our Lady Lourdes in Lourdes, France, for the Feast of the Assumption, which commemorates the belief that Mary, the mother of Jesus, ascended to heaven after she died. Some social media users shared another video claiming it showed a "worship service" following the Paris Olympics opening ceremony. But this video was taken in May.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Rose Garden video shows that President Joe Biden was taller when he emerged from July 24 Oval Office speech.
Justification: The video of President Joe Biden walking out to the White House’s Rose Garden was shot at a lower angle. Because the camera was pointing up at Biden, it made him look taller. In the video, Biden was standing a few steps in front of first lady Jill Biden, making him appear bigger because he was closer to the camera. In another photo from that day, the Bidens were standing beside each other, and their height difference was less exaggerated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The state of Washington has already sent out their ballots” for the 2024 presidential election.
Justification: Washington sent out ballots for its Aug. 6 statewide primary election, which does not include a presidential primary. It held its presidential primary earlier this year, on March 12. President Joe Biden won Washington’s Democratic presidential primary in March, according to the certified election results. Biden has since dropped out of the race and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris. Under Washington law, presidential candidates must be certified for the November ballot by Aug. 20, which falls before the Democratic nominee could be formally elected at the Democratic National Convention. Washington’s secretary of state will accept a letter from the Democratic National Committee attesting to the party’s alternate nominee, a spokesperson said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The World Health Organization ordered governments to prepare for “mega lockdown” because of an mpox strain.
Justification: The World Health Organization has not ordered any lockdowns related to mpox, formerly called monkeypox, and the organization cannot impose lockdowns, a WHO spokesperson said. The WHO’s current recommendations for mpox discourage member states from imposing mpox-related travel restrictions. A social media post sharing this claim showed a screengrab of a headline from a website that regularly shares false or misleading content.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Trump shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks was transgender.
Justification: There is no evidence this is an image of Thomas Matthew Crooks, the shooter in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump. The picture shows a transgender woman identified as Rose, according to reporting by a transgender activist and independent journalist, and confirmed by PolitiFact.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “El que disparo Donald Trump, Mark Violets ha sido asesinado.”
Justification: El 14 de julio, el FBI identificó a Thomas Matthew Crooks, un hombre de 20 años de Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, como el sospechoso del tiroteo en el evento del expresidente Donald Trump en Butler, Pensilvania. Un blogger de fútbol italiano, Marco Violi, negó en Instagram haber participado en el tiroteo. Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto?Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The House of Representatives in the U.S. just passed … the Antisemitism Act that proposes to eliminate part of the Bible.”
Justification: PolitiFact didn’t find any text in the Antisemitism Awareness Act that mentions eliminating parts of the Bible. Experts also confirmed that the bill doesn’t propose to eliminate parts of the book. They also said that prohibiting the Bible would be going against the freedom of expression and religion under the First Amendment.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Biden's sister is married to Stephen Owens, who owns Dominion Voting Systems.”
Justification: Valerie Biden Owens is married to Jack Owens, not Stephen Owens. Jack Owens, a law school classmate of President Joe Biden’s, and Stephen Owens, whose company has invested in Dominion Voting Systems, are not related.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “George Soros is a roaring, cold-blooded Nazi sociopath.”
Justification: Billionaire and philanthropist George Soros is a Hungarian Jew and Holocaust survivor.
Sources: The New York Review of Books

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video compilation shows a tornado and storms in Dubai on April 17.
Justification: The clips in the video all date back to at least January, before recent record rainfall in Dubai. One of the clips is from northern China.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Sunflowers are turning away from the sun because that’s not the sun.”
Justification: Only young sunflowers follow daytime sunlight. As their flower heads mature and the plants’ overall growth slows, their movement decreases and they stay facing east toward the morning sun, according to researchers.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video proves all sizes of Starbucks’ paper drink cups hold the same amount of liquid.
Justification: PolitiFact tested the claim by pouring water from a full Starbucks tall-sized cup, which is the brand’s version of small, into empty grande and venti cups, which are Starbucks’ medium and large sizes, respectively. The water from the tall cup did not completely fill up the grande and venti cups, as the video claimed would happen. Starbucks’ menu says a tall cup is 12 ounces, a grande is 16 ounces and a venti is 20 ounces.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California Assembly Bill 1955 “would allow schools to secretly, socially and perhaps medically transition your child without your knowledge and consent."
Justification: California’s Senate passed Assembly Bill 1955, which blocks school districts from enacting policies that require staff to notify parents about students’ sexual orientation or gender identity. To become law, the bill would have to pass the state’s Assembly and be signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom. The bill says schools should be supportive and affirming of students; it doesn’t require school staff to encourage or assist in a child’s gender transition, legal experts said.
Sources: Assembly member Christopher Ward press release
California Attorney General Rob Bonta press release
California Department of Justice Office of the Attorney General

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a banner with Iran’s supreme leader displayed at the Brooklyn Museum.
Justification: During a May 31 protest, pro-Palestinian demonstrators displayed a black banner reading "Free Palestine Divest From Genocide," from the top of the Brooklyn Museum’s facade. Videos and photos from the protest do not show the red banner with Iran’s supreme leader displayed on the museum.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The Biden campaign has demanded that Joe Biden not have to stand during the presidential debate.”
Justification: A CNN spokesperson said this didn’t happen. Both candidates agreed to stand during the June 27 debate.
Sources: Email exchange with CNN’s Dylan Rose Geerlings

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: When Secretary of State Antony Blinken was in Ukraine recently "he announced that they were going to suspend elections in Ukraine."
Justification: Ukraine’s presidential election would have been held in March, but Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said in November that elections would not take place. Since Russia’s 2022 invasion, Ukraine has operated under martial law. Ukraine’s law prohibits elections during martial law. U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken made no announcement about suspending Ukraine’s elections. He referred to Ukrainian elections in a May 14 speech, saying the U.S. is working with Ukraine to strengthen its election infrastructure for when Ukrainians agree conditions allow for elections.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "There were 42,000 people diagnosed with (an) STD in Houston” in one week.
Justification: A social media post that claimed Houston had reported 42,000 sexually transmitted disease cases in one week shared a chart that city and state health officials said reflect the number of statewide tests, not confirmed Houston cases. A Houston Health Department spokesperson said the numbers in the post were "grossly overstated" and "incorrect," and the result of a "misuse" of a data system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Texas Department of State Health Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Hospitals murdered patients” with remdesivir, a drug banned from Ebola trials because of “53% kill rate.”
Justification: There’s no evidence showing that remdesivir, the first treatment approved for COVID-19, killed patients taking the drug. The antiviral drug is still approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to treat the coronavirus that causes the disease. The FDA said it based its approval of the drug   on three randomized controlled clinical trials. Remdesivir was one of four drugs used in a 2018 clinical trial against Ebola virus in Africa. It was found to be far less effective than two experimental drugs, but the trial did not show remdesivir killed patients.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bird flu in the U.S. is a "scamdemic" timed to coincide with the 2024 presidential elections “by design.”
Justification: The current H5N1 bird flu outbreak has spread to cows at dozens of dairy herds in nine U.S. states. The U.S. outbreak was first reported among wild birds in 2022, and has infected more than 92 million birds. The first description of bird flu in history dates to 1878 in northern Italy and the H5N1 strain was first found in 1996 in southern China. Three human cases have been reported in this outbreak. Human cases of bird flu are rare, and no human-to-human transmission has been reported in the current outbreak.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
United States Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Noncitizens in Washington, D.C., “can vote in federal elections.”
Justification: District of Columbia residents who are not U.S. citizens can vote only in local elections such as those for mayor and Board of Education members, based on a 2022 law passed by the Council of the District of Columbia.​ Noncitizens are ineligible to vote in federal elections in the District of Columbia or elsewhere in the U.S.
Sources: City and County of San Francisco
Council of the District of Columbia
District of Columbia Board of Elections
Email exchange with Sarah Winn Graham
U.S. National Archives and Records Administration

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ronald Reagan’s Federal Communications Commission abolished the Fairness Doctrine and gave rise to Fox News.
Justification: The Fairness Doctrine applied to broadcast licensees only, not cable networks. It required broadcast stations to "afford reasonable opportunity for the discussion of conflicting views on issues of public importance." The Federal Communications Commission eliminated the rule in 1987 amid a changing and more diverse media landscape. Democrats in the House and Senate tried to pass a law to keep it intact, but President Ronald Reagan vetoed it, saying he felt the policy was "antagonistic" to First Amendment protections. Although some people argue that the Fairness Doctrine’s elimination shifted the media landscape, it never applied to cable networks and, according to a Congressional Research Services analysis, would not be applied constitutionally to cable or satellite service providers.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Congresswoman (Anna Paulina) Luna confirms that Biden will be replaced on 2024 ballot.”
Justification: U.S. Rep. Anna PaulinaLuna, R-Fla., did not "confirm" that President Joe Biden will be replaced on the Democratic ticket before November’s presidential election. Luna used language such as "likely" and "we’re hearing."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden told West Point graduates that “he is not planning to accept the results of the 2024 election” and he wants them to “stand back and stand by” to ensure Donald J. Trump doesn’t win.
Justification: President Joe Biden did not mention the 2024 election or former President Donald Trump in his speech to graduates at the U.S. Military Academy at West Point. He referred to the West Point Class of 20204 motto, "Like None Before," saying that West Point  graduates "have kept us free through every challenge and danger, you must keep us free at this time, ‘like none before.’" He said "every generation has an obligation" to defend American democracy and noted that graduates took an oath to the U.S. Constitution, not to a political party or president.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ancestry.com proves President Joe Biden “is not real.”
Justification: President Joe Biden did not die in Guantánamo, Cuba, in 2018, as information posted on Ancestry.com claimed.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The city of San Francisco posted street signs warning that “stolen goods must remain under $950.”
Justification: City officials did not post street signs in San Francisco that appeared to warn thieves that "stolen goods must remain under $950," the city’s Board of Supervisors president said. The city has removed the signs. Proposition 47, a California ballot measure voters passed in 2014, lowered some nonviolent felony crimes to misdemeanors, including shoplifting, as long as items taken totaled less than $950. People convicted of that crime face six months in prison and/or fines of up to $1,000.
Sources: Office of the California Attorney General

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “R. Kelly has been released from United States of America Federal Prison, Chicago.”
Justification: R. Kelly is still incarcerated, serving a 30-year prison sentence.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A 2019 clip from the show “Project Runway,” with a face mask and a designer named Kovid, is proof that the COVID-19 pandemic was a hoax.
Justification: Kovid Kapoor, a contestant on "Project Runway," a fashion design competition television show, said in an interview that he used a face mask as part of his 2019 design in reference to air pollution. Kapoor’s first name, Kovid, is a Hindi name meaning "scholar or learned person." Claims that government leaders and those in power planned the COVID-19 pandemic have persisted since 2020; there is no credible evidence to back the claims.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "No live audience” at CNN debate means “We are watching a scripted movie.”
Justification: President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump agreed not to have a live studio audience during their June 27 debate in Atlanta. Both candidates spoke about their debate performances in campaign rallies the day after.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Israel War Room posted a helicopter emoji “minutes before the news of the Iranian President’s helicopter crash landing broke.”
Justification: On May 19, The Tehran Times and The Associated Press reported at 8:44 a.m. ET and 8:53 a.m. ET, respectively, that a helicopter carrying Iran President Ebrahim Raisi had crashed. The Israel War Room X account posted a helicopter emoji a few minutes later at 8:58 a.m. ET.
Sources: X post by Israel War Room
X post by The Tasnim News Agency
X post by The Tehran Times
X post by the Associated Press

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Gates Foundation “awarded $9.5 million to UW-Madison to make H5N1 bird flu transmissible to humans.”
Justification: In 2009, the Gates Foundation awarded a five-year $9.5 million research grant to the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The university said the grant was set to fund efforts to identify virus mutations that could help identify influenza threats to humans. Bill Gates and the Gates Foundation have been the target of false online claims for years, and this claim was first shared by websites and social media accounts that have spread misinformation.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Fuddruckers is “closing ALL locations.”
Justification: Fuddruckers isn’t shuttering, the hamburger chain’s CEO said. Other restaurants on a social media list have shut down or will close, however.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A study that found sunbathing can increase the risk of heart disease is a cover-up for the “side-effects of the vax.”
Justification: A study out of Kentucky’s University of Louisville found that short-term heat exposure can increase inflammation and impair a person’s immune system. The study involved participants who were recruited in 2018 and 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic. It had nothing to do with COVID-19 vaccines. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Tennessee bill that would ban the release of chemicals into the atmosphere is evidence chemtrails are real.
Justification: Chemtrails are a conspiracy theory that claims the condensation trails behind aircraft are part of a secret, large-scale program to poison the atmosphere with toxic chemicals. Multiple government agencies and scientists say chemtrails are not real. The Tennessee Senate passed a bill that would prohibit the release of chemicals into the atmosphere within the state’s borders "with the express purpose of affecting temperature, weather, or the intensity of the sunlight." The bill does not mention chemtrails. The state House has not yet voted on the bill. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Email interview with National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration spokesperson
White House Office of Science and Technology Policy

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Footage shows explosion on Baltimore bridge.
Justification: The explosion shown in this footage is from 2022 and happened on Kerch Bridge, which connects Crimea and Russia. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Travis County, Texas, officials preparing for April 8 eclipse “know something catastrophic will happen.”
Justification: Travis County is in the path of totality of the April 8 total solar eclipse. In preparation for large crowds of out-of-town visitors, a judge issued a disaster declaration to help officials and first responders plan for emergencies. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Dali ship’s “black box” stopped recording “right before (the) crash” into the Baltimore bridge then started recording “right after.”
Justification: The National Transportation Safety Board used the Dali’s voyage data recorder, which collected audio and sensor data from the ship, to build a rough timeline of events preceding the March 26 bridge collapse. At about 1:25 a.m., the recorder briefly stopped logging the ship’s sensor data, which includes the ship’s speed, engine rotations per minute, rudder angle and heading. However, audio recordings continued. Sensor data recording resumed about a minute later. A few minutes afterward, the ship crashed into Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Footage shows “Israelis panicking after Iranian attacks reach Israel.”
Justification: This video was miscaptioned. It showed music fans running in Buenos Aires, Argentina, not civilians running following Israel attacks. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Videos show “how they celebrated the CERN opening.”
Justification: These videos show the opening ceremony of the Gotthard Base Tunnel in Switzerland, not CERN. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: YouTube video by Railway Gazette International

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Mitch McConnell’s sister-in-law who drowned in a Tesla “is listed as the CEO of the company that owns the ship that hit” Baltimore bridge.
Justification: Angela Chao, the sister-in-law of Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., drowned in February when she drove her Tesla into a Texas pond. She was the CEO of her family’s shipping company, Foremost Group. The ship that crashed into the Baltimore bridge is owned by Grace Ocean Private Ltd. and managed by Synergy Marine Group. Chao has no connection to either company. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Image shows elephants running for higher ground in the “past few weeks.”
Justification: This photo has been online since at least 2018.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The National Guard in the HISTORY of its life, gets called in AFTER a disaster, not BEFORE something happens.”
Justification: National Guard support is not exclusively requested in the aftermath of a disaster. Sometimes, troops help prepare or stand ready to provide a response. National Guard troops often support local and state authorities with responses to things such as large gatherings or bad weather. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The FBI admitted that Venezuela emptied its prisons and sent the inmates to the U.S.
Justification: News reports and the FBI’s press release archives did not show the FBI "admitted" that Venezuela transferred all its prisoners to the U.S. The image in the post is from a 2011 Chino, California, prison. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ben Shapiro posted on X about his sister and Sydney Sweeney.
Justification: This X post was fabricated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Three rockets NASA is launching during the April 8 solar eclipse is “a ritual causing mass psychosis.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The movie “Leave the World Behind” predicted the Baltimore bridge crash.
Justification: The movie "Leave the World Behind" does not depict a cargo ship crashing into a bridge, or a bridge collapse. There is no evidence that the real-world March 26 cargo ship crash in Baltimore involved a cyberattack. Federal and Maryland officials have said that evidence suggests the crash was an accident and not related to terrorism.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says 326,000 migrants were flown to Florida with taxpayer dollars under President Joe Biden’s secret migrant flight program.
Justification: A parole program for people from Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela requires that they pay for their own flights to the U.S. Information about the program has been publicly available since the program began in October 2022. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows legislators “dancing in Congress” while the border is “overrun.”
Justification: A video showing legislators dancing isn’t from Congress. It was taken in the Florida Legislature in May 2023, as legislators there celebrated "Boots Day" and line-danced in the House chamber. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: ProduceMaxx sprayed on organic produce at grocery stores contains pesticides, herbicides, fungicides, insecticides and antibiotics.
Justification: Grocery stores routinely use antimicrobial washes that are mixed with water to wash fresh produce before it’s put on display and to spray it via misters as it sits on store shelves. The antimicrobial washes reduce or eliminate bacteria and foodborne pathogens. ProduceMaxx, one such product, is registered as an antimicrobial pesticide with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. All products that claim to kill pests — in this case germs — are registered as pesticides. ProduceMaxx contains no herbicides, fungicides, insecticides or antibiotics, its maker said. The product is certified for use on organic food by an independent organic food standards group, and federal law allows its active ingredient, hypochlorous acid, to be used on food labeled organic. Hypochlorous acid is also used to disinfect swimming pools, treat wounds and to disinfect against COVID-19, and is produced naturally by the human body to fight infection. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Clips show French President Emmanuel Macron and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy dancing.
Justification: These videos were altered. The clips of French President Emmanuel Macron dancing were altered from footage of a California dance club in the 1980s. The video of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy belly dancing was altered from a dancer’s video originally uploaded in 2020. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A March 26 bridge fire in Ohio is related to the collapse of Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge.
Justification: A fire broke out at a production site of an Ohio landscape supply company in Valley View, close to the Interstate 480 bridge. The company, Kurtz Bros. Inc., said in a statement that the fire was a spontaneous combustion that began in raw wood products at its site. Valley View’s fire chief said such fires are common, it was not suspicious,and it had no connection to what happened in Baltimore. The bridge, which is adjacent to the Kurt Bros. site, was not affected by the fire. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video is from Iranian media and shows rockets fired at Israel on April 13.
Justification: This video does not show Iran’s April 13 attack on Israel. It has been online since at least 2016. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “ULEZ protesters covering cameras with bat boxes. Authorities not allowed to remove under their own law.”
Justification: A spokesperson for the Bat Conservation Trust said bat boxes can be removed with the correct authority. Transport for London said it is working with environmental specialists for the safe and legal removal of the bat boxes. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: Emailed statement from Transport for London spokesperson

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Texas found that 95,000 noncitizens were registered to vote.
Justification: Former Texas Secretary of State David Whitley issued an advisory in 2019 that said 95,000 noncitizens were registered to vote. Whitley’s office later found 25,000 voters on the list were incorrectly identified as noncitizens. In a letter to lawmakers the same year, Whitley apologized for inaccuracies in the list. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A U.S. law says that “if a house is not inhabited, we can expropriate it.”
Justification: There’s no federal law that lets people inhabit an abandoned house. States have varying adverse possession laws. In many states, to claim possession, a person must live in the property for a set amount of years, submit documentation and pay property taxes. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: Email interview with Teri A. Walter
Email interview with U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development spokesperson
