Email interview with an ICE spokesperson
Phone interview with Josh C Price

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “UN Agenda 2030 Mission Goals” include “one world government,” “one world army,” microchipping, “AI courts and end of individual rights.”
Justification: This post distorts the U.N.’s 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: More than 2 million people registered to vote so far this year without photo ID in Arizona, Pennsylvania and Texas.
Justification: Data collected by the Social Security Administration does not show the number of noncitizens who registered to vote without photo identification this year. The data shows how many times state officials verified partial Social Security numbers for voter registration applications, mail ballots and absentee ballots, Ellen Lyon, a Pennsylvania's Department of State spokesperson said. The same voter’s Social Security number could be verified multiple times in one year. State officials in Arizona, Pennsylvania and Texas said the numbers of voters from Social Security Administration data are far larger than the number of new voters who registered to vote in their states this year. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: American Association of Motor Vehicles Administrators
Supreme Court of the United States

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge was “targeted with energy weapons.”
Justification: Video footage shows a cargo ship colliding with one of the Francis Scott Key Bridge’s support columns, causing the bridge’s collapse. The investigation continues. Federal and Maryland officials have called the incident an accident. Similar claims have been made linking directed energy weapons to wildfires in the United States, Canada and Russia. But these claims are also unfounded. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Sydney mall attacker is a “Zionist” who targeted Jewish people so that people would think the attacker was Muslim.
Justification: The New South Wales Police in Australia reported there isn’t evidence that the attack was driven by a particular motivation or ideology. Police identified the attacker as Joel Cauchi, 40, from Queensland. Authorities said he suffered from mental illness. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Canada is passing a bill to essentially ban the idea of Christianity.”
Justification: A Canadian bill, C-367, calls for removing religious exemptions from a section of the nation’s criminal code regarding hate speech. The proposal, which hasn’t advanced from its first reading in Canada’s House of Commons and is not close to becoming law, does not mention Christianity. Experts said the law would not ban Christianity or make quoting from the Bible a hate speech crime, unless it were accompanied by extreme rhetoric vilifying a group or inciting violence. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Fifty percent of the votes to Joe Biden in Michigan’s presidential primary election were mail-in, unverified, no signature, no ID.
Justification: Michigan voters must be registered with proof of identification to apply for absentee ballots. Clerks verify that every signature on an absentee ballot matches with a signature on record. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Texas wildfires were started by directed energy weapons.
Justification: There is no evidence that directed energy weapons started the Texas wildfires. Social media users are pointing to a video of a green laser beam as evidence, but it was shared online months before the fires began. Authorities are still investigating how the Texas wildfires started. Hot weather, dry land and high winds have fueled the Smokehouse Creek fire’s spread. Similar claims have been made linking directed energy weapons to fires in Hawaii, Canada and Russia. But these are also unfounded. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Kamala Harris saying Democrats would use taxpayer dollars to bribe voters.
Justification: Federal work study funds can be used to pay students who register voters, but not for a specific political party, according to federal regulations. Harris did not say that federal work study funds could be used to pay people to register Democrats or bribe voters. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: U.S. Department of Education Federal Student Aid

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The CDC officially agrees with ‘conspiracy theorists’ from 2020” who wanted to treat COVID-19 like the flu.
Justification: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on March 1 updated its guidance on COVID-19, putting it in line with other respiratory illnesses, including influenza. People who have COVID-19 no longer are asked to isolate themselves for five days before returning to work or school. Instead, once their symptoms have improved, they can take other preventive measures, such as wearing masks. Public health experts at the CDC and elsewhere said the change in guidance is a response to lower rates of COVID-19-related deaths and hospitalizations because of vaccines, immunity from infection and effective treatments. Similarly, public health guidance about influenza has evolved over time. Learn more about PolitiFact’s fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A new Missouri bill “would put teachers on the sex offense registry if they ‘contribute to social transition’” of transgender students, including by using gender-affirming pronouns.
Justification: A bill introduced in the Missouri Legislature would make it a felony for teachers to "support" a transgender student’s "social transition." If convicted, teachers would be required to register with the state as a sex offender. A "social transition" is the process by which transgender people adopt new names, new pronouns, or change their clothes or hair style. The bill’s meaning of the term "support" is not clear. Some legal experts disagree on whether it would include the use of gender-affirming pronouns.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Mel Gibson just released a video that shows the satanic rituals which took place on Jeffrey Epstein’s island.”
Justification: We found no evidence that Mel Gibson released a video that shows satanic rituals that happened on the island of the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video of Joe Biden and Hillary Clinton speeches proves that their words are “all scripts and copied, all fake.”
Justification: President Joe Biden and then-presidential candidate Hillary Clinton each quoted from a famous gospel song, at events held 17 years apart. Biden has quoted from the song at least four times since 2020. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Texas wildfires are a “deliberate” attack on U.S. food supply.
Justification: The Texas Panhandle wildfires’ cause is still under investigation, but authorities have not said foul play is suspected. One Texas homeowner sued a utility company, blaming a downed power line for sparking the blaze. Although thousands of animals on ranches were killed, much of the Texas cattle in the region are in feedlots and dairies, which were not affected by the fires, experts said. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Chicken and cows have high levels of estrogen, which leads men who eat them to bald, develop man boobs and be unable to grow muscle mass.
Justification: Hormones occur naturally in all organisms. Estrogen in large quantities can adversely affect health, but there is not nearly enough estrogen in chicken and beef to cause harm, an endocrinologist said. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email interview with Dr. Bradley Anawalt

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Chuck Schumer caught on hot mic” plotting to “blame REPUBLICANS AND MAGA” for reform delays.
Justification: A video of a discussion between Sen. Chuck Schumer, D-N.Y., and President Joe Biden caught on a hot mic was altered in social media posts to show a different discussion. Biden and Schumer were heard discussing the state of the 2022 midterm elections at an airport. They did not discuss delaying any reforms or blaming Republicans, as social media posts claimed. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Biden administration seeks to end voter ID requirements to allow immigrants in the country illegally to vote.
Justification: U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland specified in his March 3 speech that all "eligible citizens" have the right to vote. Cases of noncitizens voting are statistically rare. Some noncitizens accidentally end up on voter rolls when applying for driver’s licenses. States and counties have safeguards to check for voter eligibility. It can take a decade or longer for an immigrant to become a U.S. citizen, a requirement to vote in federal elections. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: City and County of San Francisco

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Study reveals Bill Gates’ Fake Meat causes ‘turbo cancers’ in humans.”
Justification: PolitiFact found no reliable studies or news reports supporting the claim that lab-grown meat causes fast-growing cancer some are calling "turbo cancer." We traced this viral headline to a website known for publishing misinformation. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows flooding in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates on March 9, 2024.
Justification: This footage shows flooding in Oman. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “300,000 illegal immigrants were able to use a simple app to get a free flight to our country.”
Justification: In 2023, the Biden administration let in about 327,000 people from Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua and Venezuela through a parole program. People granted parole do not receive free flights to the U.S. They buy their own plane tickets. An app available to people in the parole program lets them check on their cases and get travel authorization. The app is not used to apply for or be granted parole. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Erewhon grocery store in Brooklyn.
Justification: A video claiming to show that the upscale California grocer Erewhon had opened a store in Brooklyn, New York, was digitally altered, the video creators said. The video shows footage of a City Fresh Market store, and that brand name appears at times. Erowhen has talked about opening in New York, but currently has 10 locations only in California. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden’s comments about Texas homes are evidence that homes of a certain color are spared from wildfires.
Justification: The clip takes President Joe Biden’s remarks about the Texas wildfires out of context. Biden was talking about homes being up to code. After the wildfires in Maui, Hawaii, conspiracy theories claimed that fire spared structures colored blue. But this is unfounded. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The ‘Judge’ who took Trump off the ballot in Illinois is a traffic court judge.”
Justification: Cook County Circuit Judge Tracie R. Porter previously served in the traffic division. But her current role in the county division encompasses a broad scope of cases. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Constitution of the State of Illinois

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Michael Moore is supporting Trump in the 2024 election.
Justification: In a longer video of the 2016 documentary "Michael Moore In TrumpLand," Moore tells members of an Ohio audience that they will regret voting Donald Trump for president. Moore said he voted for Joe Biden in 2020. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: CNN posted on X that Kenyan President William Ruto called President Joe Biden to organize a “naval invasion of the Haitian coast.”
Justification: The X post is not on CNN’s official X page or web archived versions of CNN’s X page. A CNN spokesperson said the post was fabricated and CNN did not report on the claim in the post. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden had a gaffe “in a rally in Michigan on Saturday.”
Justification: The clip is from an October 2020 rally. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Only immigrants in the country illegally are eligible for an interest-free California housing loan program.
Justification: Proposed California legislation would codify into law that immigrants in the country illegally who have Social Security numbers or Individual Taxpayer Identification Numbers — a group that typically includes Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, recipients —  are eligible for a program that gives first-time homebuyers interest-free loans for down payments or closing costs. Immigrants with DACA status are eligible to apply for the program. But federal law says a state must enact a law so that the immigrants can receive state public benefits. The proposed legislation would not give the loans exclusively to immigrants in the country illegally. Californians who meet certain income limits are already eligible for the program. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute
Phone and email interview with Jacob Moss

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: It was not former President Donald Trump who promoted the COVID-19 vaccine, but a “lookalike.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump promoted the COVID-19 vaccine on several occasions. He did so in interviews, rallies, public events and press statements. Trump said multiple times that he had taken the COVID-19 vaccine. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. Code states that a person convicted of treason would be “taken by the posse to the nearest busy intersection and at high noon hung by the neck until dead.”
Justification: U.S. Code states that the maximum punishment for a person convicted of treason is death. But as of 1938, all U.S. states have outlawed public executions. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: Email exchange with the New York State Legislative Library
Email interview with Carlton F.W. Larson
Email interview with Frank O. Bowman III
Excerpt of Society’s Final Solution: A History and Discussion of the Death Penalty

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Monica Petersen was assassinated in Haiti while she was investigating the Clintons’ child trafficking.
Justification: Monica Petersen was no longer working for what was then the University of Denver’s Human Trafficking Center when she was in Haiti in 2016 to teach and start a nongovernmental organization. The director of the former Human Trafficking Center said Petersen was not in Haiti to investigate allegations of sex trafficking involving the Clinton Foundation. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Josef Korbel School of International Studies Facebook post
Web archived Facebook post by Monica Petersen

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Your legal name is in fact a corporation. This is why you always see your name written in ALL CAPS.”
Justification: To help standardize documents, people’s names are often listed in capital letters on official documents such as birth certificates and passports. We found no evidence supporting the baseless claim that a person’s name is printed in all capital letters because it is a corporation. That false claim is linked to a persistent and unfounded conspiracy theory. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email statement from a State Department spokesperson

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Solar flares caused AT&T’s cellphone outage.
Justification: Two solar flares occurred hours before a temporary outage disrupted AT&T cellphone customers’ service Feb. 22. But AT&T and experts said the two events are not connected. Intense solar flares can disrupt radio communications, but the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said it was "highly unlikely" the flares affected cellphone service. AT&T said the outage was caused by technical issues. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The 2020 election was the only time in American history that an election took more than 24 hours to count.
Justification: There has never been a presidential election in which every vote has been counted within 24 hours. Official results take days to weeks to certify, experts said. Media organizations can call races before every vote is counted. There are several examples of presidential and state elections that took longer than the 2020 presidential election to call. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The government did more to stop the distribution of ivermectin and hydroxychloroquine than to stop the distribution of fentanyl.
Justification: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration in March 2020 gave hydroxychloroquine emergency use authorization as a COVID-19 treatment, but rescinded it three months later as data showed it was ineffective and could cause harm. Ivermectin is approved for some uses, but COVID-19 treatment is not among them. The FDA issued a warning in 2021 after it received reports that patients were self-medicating with the livestock version of the drug. The Biden administration has made stopping the flow of fentanyl into the U.S. a priority, with several initiatives, including a $1.2 billion supplemental funding request to Congress to help stop the flow of fentanyl into the country. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “White House announces there will be 2 ‘intermissions’ during tonight’s State of the Union.”
Justification: There were no intermissions during President Joe Biden’s March 7 State of the Union address, and the White House never announced there would be. The claim originated with an X post written by Sean Spicer, former press secretary for former President Donald Trump. Spicer said the post was a joke. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Trump’s hair wig falls off during rally speech!”
Justification: The video is altered. In the original clip, Donald Trump’s hair stays firmly in place. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Google proves that no one ever went to the moon.”
Justification: Google did not conclude footage from the 1969 U.S. moon landing was fake, a company spokesperson confirmed. A video circulating on social media is from an artificial intelligence conference held in Russia in November; Google said it didn’t participate. A Russian report quoted a researcher at the conference who claimed he used Google’s network to analyze a photo from the moon landing, and said the network found that the image could have been manipulated. We could not confirm what tool he used, or which photo was evaluated. About 15 years ago, NASA released restored copies of the Apollo 11 moonwalk after announcing years earlier that the original recordings were mistakenly erased and reused. It’s not known whether the restored footage related to any inconsistencies the Russian report said were supposedly found.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Because “17 million immigrants” were “let in” the U.S, “ foot and mouth disease is back. We got rid of that fifty years ago.”
Justification: There are no cases of foot-and-mouth disease — a highly contagious virus that affects livestock — in the U.S., officials said. The disease was eradicated in the U.S. in 1929. Humans could carry the virus on clothes, shoes or other items, but there’s no evidence the disease has reemerged in the U.S. A similarly named, but unrelated disease called hand, foot and mouth disease, is common among young children in the U.S. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
European Center for Disease Prevention and Control

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Protestors yelled “F--- Joe Biden” as the president arrived in Allentown, Pennsylvania.
Justification: The video contains edited audio. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Johnnie Cochran “mysteriously passed away” and his death is linked to his work on slavery reparations.
Justification: Johnnie Cochran, who gained fame for successfully defending O.J. Simpson against murder charges, died in 2005 from a brain tumor. Although Cochran had been part of a group advocating for reparations for Black Americans, his death was not linked to that fight. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: Oklahoma Supreme Court grants oral argument in Tulsa Race Massacre case

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “At least one of Kansas City shooters identified as Sahil Omar, a 44 year old illegal immigrant.”
Justification: Kansas City, Missouri, juvenile prosecutors have charged two children for the Feb. 14 shooting that marred the city’s Super Bowl victory parade. "Sahil Omar" is a fictitious name that has been falsely linked to recent fatal incidents. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson was booed in Las Vegas because he’s a Joe Biden supporter.
Justification: Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson was booed by fans at a World Wrestling Entertainment event for playing the role of villain in an upcoming match. Johnson endorsed Joe Biden in 2020 but has not endorsed anyone in the 2024 presidential election. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Karine Jean-Pierre ended a White House press conference to avoid answering a question.
Justification: An edited 2022 video cuts out White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre’s response to a question. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy used U.S. aid funds to buy two yachts for $75 million.
Justification: The documents claiming to show the yacht purchases were fabricated. They include an outdated name and logo of a yacht association that supposedly approved the purchases. The two yachts named in the documents, "Lucky Me" and "My Legacy," are still for sale. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.
Sources: MYBA The Worldwide Yachting Association website
Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden’s tweet is proof that a helicopter crash that killed six Nigerian billionaires was planned by Biden.
Justification: Poor weather conditions, including rain and snow, could have caused the Feb. 11 helicopter crash that killed six Nigerians who were headed to the Super Bowl, aviation experts told The Associated Press. Orbic Air, which chartered the helicopter, had previous safety issues, a lawsuit says. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Harvard University Risk Management & Audit Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden announced tax incentives for families willing to take in migrants in a new “Housing for Labor” initiative.
Justification: This claim originated from a satirical post. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: U.S. Ministry of Truth X account
X post by U.S. Ministry of Truth

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Taylor Swift said she “will leave the United States if Donald Trump becomes President in 2024.”
Justification: There is no proof she made such a statement. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Removing gun-related homicides in Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and St. Louis would drop the U.S. to 189th out of 193 countries in gun violence.
Justification: Recent data is incomplete, but in a 2019 study of 204 countries and territories, the U.S. ranked 32nd for gun homicides based on population, with a rate of 3.96 deaths per 100,000 people. Subtracting the number of gun homicides in Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles, Philadelphia and St. Louis from 2022 FBI gun homicide data would decrease the U.S. gun homicide rate from 5.0 deaths per 100,000 people to 4.5 per 100,000 people. That wouldn’t reduce the rate enough for the U.S. to be on the lowest end of a global gun violence ranking. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.
Sources: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation
United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Migrants in New York City are receiving prepaid debit cards with up to $10,000 and no restrictions.
Justification: A New York City-funded pilot program will give prepaid debit cards for food and baby supplies to 500 families with children sheltering in the city’s hotels. The amount of money on the cards will vary by family size, but each family member will receive approximately $12 to $13 per day for 28 days, William Fowler, a spokesperson for New York City’s Housing Preservation and Development said. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Disney World is adding urinals to the women’s restrooms.”
Justification: This claim originated on a satirical site. A Walt Disney Co. spokesperson confirmed to PolitiFact that this claim is not accurate. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There was an “attempt on Dr. Oz’s life” on TV over his diabetes cure.
Justification: Dr. Oz was not attacked onstage for promoting a diabetes cure. A fight scene in an Instagram video is from the set of a Ukrainian talk show in 2022. Oz has not pushed a diabetes cure and has been urging social media platforms to crack down on fake celebrity ads since 2019. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The pictures we see of Mars are actually Devon Island in Canada.
Justification: No, NASA is not editing images from Canada and passing them off as photos of Mars. Similar claims have been debunked numerous times. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The American Red Cross asking blood donors about their vaccination status proves COVID-19 vaccines are dangerous.
Justification: All blood collectors are required to ask donors about their vaccine history because the U.S. Food and Drug Administration requires various wait times to donate blood for live-attenuated vaccines — vaccines that use a weakened form of the virus that causes infection. The FDA has not approved any live-attenuated COVID-19 vaccines for use in the U.S., FDA spokesperson Carly Pflaum said, although one is being developed and is in clinical trials. If a potential donor who was vaccinated doesn’t know the manufacturer of the COVID-19 vaccine they received, the American Red Cross asks them to wait two weeks before donating blood to prevent the risk of spreading the virus from a live-attenuated vaccine. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Association for the Advancement of Blood & Biotherapies

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A photograph shows Klaus Schwab nude at the beach.
Justification: The person in the photograph is a Florida resident with a similar name, not Klaus Schwab. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s U.S. naturalization certificate.
Justification: The naturalization certificate for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is not authentic. It has multiple discrepancies based on what the official document is supposed to include. A reverse-image search showed the photo of the certificate originated on a website known to spread misinformation related to the Russia-Ukraine war. We found no credible news reports or government announcements about Zelenskyy leaving Ukraine to become a U.S. citizen. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.
Sources: Google and Nexis searches for reports of Zelenskyy becoming a U.S. citizen
Reverse-image searches using Google and TinEye

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The ATF updated its background check policy to allow “illegal immigrants” to purchase firearms.
Justification: Federal law prohibits migrants who are in the U.S. illegally from buying firearms. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) lacks the power to change or alter federal law. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Office of the Law Revision Counsel United States Code

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Cloud seeding program connected to recent California storms.
Justification: A four-year cloud seeding pilot program in California began in November. It targeted four mountain regions to increase precipitation during storms. Its ultimate goal is increasing the region’s water supply. No cloud seeding took place during a recent storm that left about 37 million people under flood alerts, a program spokesperson said. The cloud seeding pilot has safety mechanisms to avoid seeding during dangerous conditions and does not seed large storms such as this. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 is caused by radiation poisoning.
Justification: COVID-19 is caused by exposure to a coronavirus called SARS-CoV-2. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: King Charles’ cancer diagnosis is linked to mRNA cancer therapy trial in U.K.
Justification: The first patient in the U.K. to receive the new mRNA cancer therapy did so in October 2023. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Arson, not climate change, caused Canada’s record 2023 wildfire season.
Justification: A Quebec man pleaded guilty to setting 14 forest fires in 2023, a record year for wildfires in Canada. The fires the man set, and the land that burned as a result, represent a fraction of the wildfires and damage throughout Canada that year. Experts said climate change factored significantly in Canada’s wildfires, causing weather conditions that increase the fires’ severity. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Society for the Protection of Forests Against Fire

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The states that have 97% of guns are the states with the least amount of gun violence.
Justification: Lead Stories found the map was created by a Medium blogger in 2017 to show the results of the 2016 presidential election by congressional district, not gun violence statistics. States with more gun ownership and laxer gun laws report higher levels of firearm deaths. The leading cause of gun deaths in the U.S. are suicides, not homicides. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
John Hopkins Center for Gun Violence Solutions

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: If a woman in Texas takes “abortion pills voluntarily,” she would be “charged with murder.”
Justification: A Texas law that criminalizes abortion went into effect in August 2022, after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade. Under the law, physicians who provide abortions can be charged with a first-degree felony, punishable by up to 99 years in prison. Doctors also can face civil fines of $100,000. The new law explicitly says the criminal and civil penalties do not apply to women who get abortions.
Sources: Austin American-Statesman Texas Supreme Court to hear case Tuesday challenging state's near-total abortion ban

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Chicken farm fire that killed 12 million birds intentionally set.
Justification: What caused a January fire at a Texas chicken farm is still under investigation, but authorities determined it was a noncriminal accident. The number of chickens killed isn’t clear, but the CEO of MPS Egg Farms, which owns the Feather Crest Farms, which caught fire, said it is "far less" than the 12 million cited in an Instagram post. Fires at farms and food production facilities are not uncommon. Electrical or heating device malfunctions often cause these fires, experts said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Benjamin Netanyahu refused to take a microphone from an Arab official, suggesting his belief that Arabs “are unclean.”
Justification: A video that showed Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu asking for hand sanitizer before touching a microphone a United Arab Emirates official handed him took place during the COVID-19 pandemic’s apex. Netanyahu had for months urged Israelis to take preventive measures, such as hand-washing. Netanhayu has on several occasions shaken hands with Arab leaders without requesting hand sanitizer. In 2019, he accepted a microphone from Yemen’s foreign minister when his own did not work. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In an interview with Tucker Carlson, Russian President Vladimir Putin said he finds the U.S.-Mexico border issue “ironically amusing.”
Justification: This exchange between former Fox News host Tucker Carlson and Russian President Vladimir Putin was fabricated. The original post was shared before the interview took place. Carlson and Putin did not discuss the U.S.-Mexico border in the two-hour interview. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Judge in E. Jean Carroll-Donald Trump trial “involved in sex trafficking.”
Justification: Federal Judge Lewis Kaplan, who presided over E. Jean Carroll’s defamation lawsuits against former President Donald Trump, has not been accused of or faced charges for sex trafficking. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows explosives disguised as food cans.
Justification: Social media posts claim footage from Gaza shows explosives disguised as food cans, but there are no visible labels or pictures on the metal cylinders to suggest they contain food. Experts on military strategy and the Middle East said the metal cylinders seen in photos and videos online are likely containers for M603 fuzes, which are designed to detonate landmines. Footage shows one of the cans is labeled "fuze mine." The fuzes are not designed to explode if a person opens the container. It requires 140 to 750 pounds of force to ignite the fuze and trigger an explosion. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email interview with retired U.S. Army Lt. General Mark Schwartz
Operator Manual for Fuze M603 metal container
United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Taylor Swift was photographed holding a “Trump won, Democrats cheated!” flag.
Justification: The photo was altered. The original Getty Images photo shows Swift standing with her hands clasped at a Sept. 24 National Football League game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Chicago Bears in Kansas City, Missouri. There is no flag. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: United Nations troops can “round up” and forcibly “vaccinate the population” if WHO pandemic treaty is passed.
Justification: The World Health Organization’s member states are negotiating an agreement to strengthen pandemic prevention, preparedness and response. The pact would not authorize the WHO to mandate vaccines or any other health policy, drafts of the agreement showed and WHO officials said. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Twelve babies died from taking RSV drug in clinical trials.
Justification: Twelve children died in pediatric clinical trials after receiving shots of nirsevimab, which is sold under the brand name Beyfortus. The monoclonal antibody treatment, a type of passive immunization that’s different from vaccines’ active immunization, was approved and recommended by U.S. health agencies in 2023 to protect young children against respiratory syncytial virus. None of the deaths in the clinical trials were tied to the drug, the FDA said. The children died of other causes including COVID-19 and a fractured skull, or had underlying conditions such as lower respiratory tract infections. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “US hospitals caught injecting experimental Ebola vaccine that sheds!”
Justification: Ervebo, an Ebola vaccine, is neither experimental, nor contains the Ebola virus. A different virus used in the vaccine, vesicular stomatitis, can shed. Denver health care workers who received the vaccine are part of a high-risk team that could potentially have contact with Ebola patients. A planned Colorado State University bat research site will not work with Ebola or other dangerous pathogens. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 2014-2016 Ebola Outbreak in West Africa
Department of Health and Human Services
National Emerging Special Pathogens Training and Education Center

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Paper shows “mRNA COVID-19 vaccines caused more deaths” than lives saved.
Justification: The research paper was based on COVID-19 vaccine claims that are false and misleading, experts told us. The mRNA COVID-19 vaccines have been rigorously tested and monitored for years, and public health experts worldwide have found them to be safe and effective. Adverse effects are rare. The World Health Organization estimated that in 2021 alone the COVID-19 vaccines saved more than 14.4 million lives globally. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.
Sources: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration
U.K. Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency
Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System website

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden admitted to using the Justice Department to pursue his political foes.
Justification: The Instagram post splices unrelated videos to create a narrative of President Biden saying he used the legal system to attack Donald Trump. Biden doesn’t control the prosecutions against Trump. Even if Trump is indicted or convicted, he can still rung for and perhaps win back the presidency No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “George Soros worked for Hitler. Klaus Schwab’s father also worked for Hitler.”
Justification: George Soros was a Holocaust survivor. His father obtained a false identity for him for his safety. There is some gray area on whether World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab’s father was involved in Nazi activities, but there is no evidence he had a high-ranking position in the regime. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: Email interview with David Bete of the Sigmaringen department of the Baden-Württemberg State Archives
Emailed statement from the World Economic Forum

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The presence of soft tissue and carbon-14 in dinosaur bones proves they lived “only a few thousand years” ago, not millions of years ago.
Justification: Scientists know that dinosaur fossils are millions of years old by dating radioactive elements in rocks that the fossils were found near or in. Soft tissue can exist in fossils for longer than 4 million years, though scientists are divided on what leads to its preservation. This video comes from a group that spreads the theory of young Earth creationism, a belief that the Earth was formed in the last 10,000 years, as told in the Bible’s creation story. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Illegal immigrants now have the right to vote in New York."
Justification: Only U.S. citizens may vote in statewide and national elections in New York. A 2021 New York City law involving local elections gave voting privileges to noncitizens who are in the U.S. legally, but a judge struck down that law  in 2022 and it’s not in effect. Before it was ruled unconstitutional in New York, the law did not grant voting rights to anyone in the country illegally. The ruling is on appeal. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute
Email exchange with Jerry H. Goldfeder
Email exchange with Kathleen R. McGrath

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Ukraine puts Tucker Carlson on a ‘hit list’ after an interview with Vladimir Putin.”
Justification: A website called Myrotvorets, which translates to "Peacemaker" in English, lists thousands of people, including celebrities and journalists, deemed to be enemies of Ukraine. Tucker Carlson was added to the list in 2023, not after his interview with Russian President Vladimir Putin. He was accused of being an anti-Ukrainian propagandist, among other allegations. The website uses inflammatory language in places, but did not call for Carlson to be killed or harmed. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here’s how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kentucky Republican lawmaker “wants to legalize sexual relations with first cousins.”
Justification: On Jan. 17, Kentucky state Rep. Nick Wilson, R-Williamsburg, withdrew a Jan. 16 bill that he said contained an "inadvertent" error that removed the phrase "first cousins" from the state’s list of prohibited sexual relationships considered incest. Also on Jan. 17, Wilson filed corrected draft legislation that seeks to strengthen the state’s incest law. It retained the ban on sex between first cousins. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine “shuts off” recipients’ hearts.
Justification: Hundreds of millions of COVID-19 vaccines have been administered around the world, and public health authorities have found them to be safe and effective. Adverse effects from the vaccine are rare. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Marburg virus has been implanted into people who were vaccinated and has nanotechnology that can be activated through 5G technology.
Justification: COVID-19 vaccine ingredients do not contain the Marburg virus disease. The Marburg virus is spread through bodily fluids. Nanoparticles in COVID-19 vaccines are not connected to 5G technology.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Jaw-dropping footage from Epstein’s first jail cell provides concrete evidence that Bill Clinton, Prince Andrew, Bill Gates and Oprah Winfrey played a significant role in Epstein’s death.
Justification: Federal prosecutors said in 2020 that video footage from outside of Jeffrey Epstein’s first jail cell does not exist because they failed to save it. An autopsy found that Epstein’s death was a suicide by hanging. The medical examiner ruled out a homicide because his injuries were not consistent with one. Links in the Instagram post do not take users to footage of Epstein’s jail cell, as it claims to.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Social media post claims judge in Trump’s defamation trial engaged in “election interference” by delaying the trial to New Hampshire’s primary day.
Justification: A New York jury is being asked to decide what additional defamation damages, if any, former President Donald Trump should pay writer E. Jean Carroll for comments he made about her in 2019 while he was president. On Jan. 22, a juror’s illness and COVID-19 exposures caused a trial delay. The judge did not immediately grant the Trump legal team’s request that the trial not resume Jan. 23, the day of the New Hampshire primary, but the court docket later said the trial would not resume on primary day. It resumed Jan. 25. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Sports journalist Mike Dickson died because of COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: British sports journalist Mike Dickson died Jan. 17 in Melbourne, Australia, where he had been covering the Australian Open tennis tournament. His wife announced the news on X. The Daily Mail newspaper, for which Dickson was a correspondent, published a story about Dickson’s death. Neither announcement contained information about the cause of death. Dickson had written about a tennis star’s decision not to get vaccinated against COVID-19, but that does not link Dickson’s death to the vaccines. The vaccines, which have been administered to millions of people in the U.S. alone, are safe and effective at preventing severe illness. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Chinese scientists “created (a) new COVID-19 strain (with) 100% fatality.”
Justification: Researchers in China recently released a study, which has not been peer-reviewed, that tested the GX_P2V coronavirus on genetically engineered mice. Although GX_P2V belongs to the coronavirus family, it did not originate from SARS-CoV-2, which causes COVID-19. The mice were genetically engineered to express a protein that SARS-CoV-2 uses to enter human cells. All four mice infected with GX_P2V died in the experiment, but the researchers said this result doesn’t apply to humans. The researchers did not create the GX_P2V coronavirus. Since its discovery in 2017, GX_P2V, like all coronaviruses, has adapted and produced variants. The researchers cloned a cell-adapted variant of GX_P2V to use in their study. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The government is spraying chemicals into the sky to block the sun.
Justification: No, the skies are not being sprayed with aerosols to block the sun during the winter to mitigate climate change. Similar claims with different contexts have surfaced over the years and have beendebunked. There is small-scale research into solar geoengineering, which sprays aerosols into the atmosphere to reflect some sunlight back into space. That is being done by researchers at Harvard University, but it is not widespread and very preliminary. Learn more about PolitiFact'sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Epstein List” shows 166 people connected to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
Justification: Searching through Jeffrey Epstein’s flight logs and address book as well as news reports and newly unsealed documents from a case against Epstein’s former girlfriend and associate, Ghislaine Maxwell, we found no proof that more than half of the names on a popular 166-name "Epstein list" were linked to the sex offender. Some names on the list, however, featured prominently in court documents as attorneys questioned witnesses about their relationships with Epstein, the disgraced financier and convicted sex offender. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Copy uploaded by The Wall Street Journal
See sources linked in PolitiFact spreadsheet
X post from Clinton’s spokesperson Angel Ureña

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Putin refused to acknowledge Netanyahu.”
Justification: The video is from the World Holocaust Forum in 2020. Multiple photographs from the event show the two leaders interacting. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Klaus Schwab admits ‘political revolution’ against the ‘great reset’ is destroying his agenda.”
Justification: We found no credible reports that show World Economic Forum founder and Chair Klaus Schwab said a "political revolution" is destroying his "Great Reset" agenda. The claim invokes the "Great Reset" conspiracy theory. Adherents claim that elites aiming to establish a totalitarian global regime used the coronavirus to depopulate the earth and reorganize society, but the theory has been widely debunked. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Taylor Swift was photographed holding a “Trump won, Democrats cheated!” flag at the Grammy Awards.
Justification: The photo was altered. Taylor Swift endorsed President Joe Biden in October 2020 ahead of the general election but has not yet made an endorsement in 2024. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Last time Democrats removed a Republican from the ballot” was Abraham Lincoln in 1860.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump’s inclusion on Republican primary ballots has been formally challenged in 35 states. Challengers have cited the U.S. Constitution’s 14th Amendment, Section 3, which prohibits anyone who engaged in insurrection from holding the office of president. President Abraham Lincoln was not removed from general election ballots in 1860. At that time, political parties distributed their own ballots, which were single-party tickets, and some slaveholding states in the South did not print and hand out Republican ballots because there was little support for Lincoln in those places. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Department of the Maine Secretary of State
Maine Secretary of State Shenna Bellows

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows people “heading to Texas to stop the Biden Border Invasion.”
Justification: The video is from a 2019 protest in Portland, Oregon. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden changed the State of the Union Address from summer to March.
Justification: House Speaker Mike Johnson, R-La., invited President Joe Biden to deliver the State of the Union address to Congress on March 7. A spokesperson for Biden said the president never wanted to deliver the 2024 address in the summer, nor did he ever ask Congress if he could. For decades, the State of the Union has been delivered in the winter, often in January or February. Biden’s 2022 State of the Union address was on March 1. Our mission: Help you be an informed participant in democracy.Learn more.
Sources: Email interview with White House spokesperson Olivia Dalton

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Oat milk “raises your blood sugar as much as drinking a Coke.”
Justification: Maltose, the type of sugar in oat milk, has a higher glycemic index than other sugars, which means its consumption can affect blood sugar levels more quickly. But the rate at which blood sugar rises is affected by factors other than glycemic load, including protein, fat and fiber content. One 8-ounce serving of oat milk has about 3 grams of fiber, 3 grams of protein and 5.5 grams of fat. A 12-ounce can of Coca-Cola has no protein, fat or fiber.
Sources: Phone interview with Dr. Jen Cadenhead

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: An activist spoke about LGBTQ+ issues at a Plano, Texas, city council meeting.
Justification: The man in the video is a YouTube prankster with a history of "trolling" city council meetings around Texas. Here’s how PolitiFact chooseswhich statements to fact-check.
Sources: YouTube video by the city of Plano
YouTube video by the cty of Plano

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “In Germany, you must be fully vaxxed before your death by assisted suicide.”
Justification: Germany has no policy requiring vaccination before assisted suicide. The post linked to a November 2021 story that referred to a German euthanasia assistance advocacy group’s directive that its members be vaccinated or have recovered from a COVID-19 infection. That rule was made to protect doctors, staff and other members from infection, the group’s website said. The organization, Verein Sterbehlife, no longer lists that directive on its website.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: With Apple’s NameDrop, anyone placing an iPhone near your child’s “will automatically receive their contact information.”
Justification: Apple’s new NameDrop feature, available in iPhones using iOS17.1 and Apple Watches using watchOS 10.1, allows two users to quickly share contact information by tapping and holding their phones close together. The contact sharing doesn’t happen automatically, however, if a stranger simply puts his or her phone too close to yours. Both phones must be unlocked, and each user must choose whether to send or receive information, or both. They must also choose what information to share.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Texas Children’s Hospital pediatric clinics announce they will no longer treat unvaccinated children.”
Justification: A Texas Children’s Hospital spokesperson told PolitiFact that all Texas Children’s Pediatrics clinics accept patients regardless of vaccination status. Texas recently enacted a new law that prohibits physicians who care for patients enrolled in Medicaid or the Children’s Health Insurance Program from refusing care based on the patient’s vaccination status.
Sources: Texas Medical Board’s formal complaint against Mary Talley Bowden

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bloodied Palestinian baby doll was “made in Israel.”
Justification: A bloodied Palestinian baby doll seen on a toy shelf in social media videos was not made in Israel. It was created in Mexico by a person bringing attention to the deaths of children in Gaza. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video showing an orb exploding Jan. 1 at a Miami mall is proof that the Blue Beam project started.
Justification: The video of an orb was shared May 2023 on TikTok. Police said that a Jan. 1 disturbance at Miami’s Bayside Marketplace was caused by teenagers exploding fireworks, not aliens.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video of avalanche shows the “power of nature.”
Justification: A video showing an avalanche barrelling toward diners at a ski resort is being portrayed as real on social media, but it’s a scene from the fictional 2014 Swedish movie, "Force Majeure."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video is evidence that Hillary Clinton is a reptile.
Justification: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is a human, not a reptile.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Women "store DNA" from all their male sexual partners.
Justification: The claim that women store DNA from all their sexual partners has been spreading since 2017 and has been shared by news sites known for producing misinformation. The claim misrepresents the findings of a study that examined how small amounts of male DNA can appear in women’s brains. The study found that the mother likely absorbed this DNA when she was pregnant with a male child. There is no scientific evidence to suggest that women regularly retain and "store" the DNA of sexual partners through intercourse.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video of a man collapsing while confronting service members is “Palestinian Theater.”
Justification: The video shows a 2015 incident in which an older Palestinian man collapsed while confronting Israeli service members in the West Bank.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a woman named Araceli Hernandez who “was kidnapped by George Floyd and brutally beaten during a home invasion.”
Justification: George Floyd had an aggravated robbery charge in 2007 for his involvement in breaking into the apartment of a woman named Aracely Henriquez, but this photo shows a different woman. This photo shows Andrea Sicignano, who shared her account of being assaulted and raped in Madrid in 2018. Floyd had no kidnapping or assault charges.
Sources: Copy of complaint in aggravated robbery from Harris County District Clerk

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Police responded to alien creatures at a Miami mall on Jan. 1, 2024.
Justification: Miami police said there were no aliens at Bayside Marketplace, an outdoor mall, when dozens of officers were called to the area Jan. 1. Police were responding to a riot caused by a group of about 50 teenagers, who were shooting fireworks at people and looting stores.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: World Economic Forum event is evidence that global leaders are planning a new pandemic called Disease X.
Justification: Disease X, a term used for several years by the World Health Organization, refers to a hypothetical deadly pathogen that could lead to a global pandemic. World leaders and scientists have been discussing ways to better prepare for and respond to such an unknown disease before it emerges. They are not planning a new pandemic. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Then-Vice President Joe Biden’s remarks in 2015 video prove he “intentionally” opened U.S. borders to immigrants.
Justification: Then-Vice President Joe Biden, in 2015 remarks about battling violent extremism in the U.S., praised the country’s ability to integrate a steady stream of immigrants. A social media video used a short clip from his lengthy remarks to falsely imply it proves that Biden as president intentionally opened U.S. borders.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Massive f— Joe Biden chant breaks out at Army/Navy game.”
Justification: A video of the crowd at the Dec. 9 Army-Navy college football game was altered to show the crowd yelling a vulgar chant about President Joe Biden. Original video shows it didn’t happen.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Trump promising to pause student loan payments and cancel payroll tax if reelected in 2024.
Justification: This video shows a speech Donald Trump gave in August 2020, while he was president and announcing COVID-19 pandemic relief.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Vaccines that are routinely given to children contain unsafe amounts of aluminum.
Justification: Aluminum is a component in vaccines that increases the immune response. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates it, ensuring it is present in small quantities. On average, people consume more aluminum from their daily diets than they do from vaccines. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Zombie deer virus is sweeping across 32 states after more than 100 million American wildlife animals were vaccinated by Mark Zuckerberg’s foundation.
Justification: • The Chan Zuckerberg Initiative, a charity founded by Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg and Priscilla Chan, Zuckerberg’s wife, does not fund a program to vaccinate wildlife.•  Zombie deer disease is caused by prions, or transmissible proteins that cause normal proteins in the brain to fold irregularly, causing brain damage.• Zoetis, a Pfizer subsidiary, donated 11,000 doses of its animal COVID-19 vaccines to zoos, conservatories, sanctuaries and other organizations in 2021.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email exchange with spokesperson from Zoetis
Email exchange with spokesperson from the Chan Zuckerberg Initiative
Email exchange with spokesperson from the U.S. Department of Agriculture’s Animal and Plant Health Inspection Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Palestinian flag before 1948 included the Star of David.
Justification: Middle East history experts told PolitiFact that the blue-and-white flag with a Star of David represents the Zionist movement, not Palestine. From 1922 to 1948, the Palestinian territory was under British mandate, so the Union Jack was flown in official capacities. Palestinians had their own flag, but it did not feature the Star of David.
Sources: Email interview with Éditions Larousse spokesperson
Reverse image searches through Google Images

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Suggests there have been 17 million deaths from the COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: The 17 million figure comes from research that experts have said is flawed because it counts excess deaths during the COVID-19 vaccine’s rollout without accounting for deaths from the virus. Multiple studies show the COVID-19 vaccines saved lives. No spin, just facts you can trust.Here's how we do it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a “US-owned cargo ship was just hit by a missile off the coast of Yemen!”
Justification: Houthi fighters struck a U.S. container ship off Yemen’s coast Jan. 15, but several Instagram videos show footage captured in May 2021 after a fire broke out on a container ship off the coast of Sri Lanka. The Instagram videos include a faint letter "A." That’s part of a watermark that reads, "AIR FORCE Media" and is visible in the full video shared by news organizations such as The Sun and the BBC. Sri Lanka’s Air Force and Disaster Management Agency captured the footage. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Abraham Lincoln’s coin is copper because he ended slavery. Figures on other U.S. coins “face left because they turned their backs to him in protest.”
Justification: Former President Abraham Lincoln has always faced to the right on the U.S. penny. Lincoln scholars say that’s because the sculptor modeled the design after a 1864 photo of Lincoln. Former U.S. Presidents Thomas Jefferson on the nickel, Franklin D. Roosevelt on the dime and George Washington on the quarter all faced left when they first were put on those coins. But coins in circulation now have Jefferson facing forward and Washington facing right. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Gaza’s education ministry “officially announced the end of the 2023/2024 academic year as all students have been killed.”
Justification: Not all of Gaza’s schoolchildren have been killed. There are about 625,000 registered students in Gaza schools. The number of children that have been killed in the war — including those who are not yet school age —  is about 7,000, according to the Gaza-based Health Ministry that’s controlled by Hamas. The total death toll in Gaza, including adults and children, was about 19,000 as of Dec. 18, the Health Ministry said.
Sources: State of Palestine Ministry of Education
United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
United Nations Relief and Works Agency

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In Palm Springs, California, “transgender residents to receive a monthly payment of $900.”
Justification: In 2023, the city government of Palm Springs, California, and two nonprofit organizations launched a small pilot, described as a "universal basic income" program, that provides eligible residents with $800 per month for 18 months. To qualify, Palm Springs residents had to make less than $16,600 a year and be a past or present client of DAP Health or Queer Works, two groups that provide services to LGBTQ+ people, but do not exclusively serve LGBTQ+ or transgender populations. A pilot program spokesperson told PolitiFact the claim is not accurate. He said there were no requirements about age, race, sexual orientation, gender identity or other demographic qualifications for the 30 chosen universal basic income recipients. How does PolitiFact decide our ratings?Learn more here.
Sources: Email interview with spokesperson for the Universal Basic Income Pilot project

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Amazon got hacked. … Hackers added Hub lockers as your default delivery addresses.”
Justification: Amazon said the addresses of Hub locker locations were added in error to some customers’ address books. It was not the result of a data breach.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Macaulay Culkin’s “Home Alone” shopping trip that cost $19.83 in 1990 would cost $72.28 today, up from $44.40 in 2022.
Justification: In the 1990 movie "Home Alone," 8-year-old Kevin McCallister bought 10 items during a solo grocery store trip for a total of $19.83. When shopping at the same store — the Grand Food Center in Winnetka, Illinois — and accounting for inflation and differences in product sizes, the 2023 total for the same 10 products is $56.84.
Sources: Phone call with Grand Food Center employee
The Grand Food Center’s online store

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Lil Nas X was accepted to Liberty University in Christian Leadership and Biblical Studies.
Justification: A Liberty University spokesperson said Lil Nas X did not apply to the school. Learn more about PolitiFact’sfact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Email exchange with Liberty University spokesperson Ryan Helfenbein

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The International Space Station is in a pool, not in space.
Justification: The International Space Station is 250 miles from Earth. Images in this post show astronauts training underwater in a large swimming pool to simulate space conditions before a mission.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video showing “Israeli occupation forces arrest a 2-year-old child” is from the Israel-Hamas war.
Justification: A video showing Israeli border police briefly detaining a young Palestinian boy was filmed in 2018 and is not related to the current Israel-Hamas war.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hillary Clinton blamed various events, including her 2016 election loss and Jeffrey Epstein’s death, on climate change.
Justification: This video’s audio was edited. Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton did not blame her 2016 election loss or Jeffrey Epstein’s death on climate change. In the original footage, Clinton was speaking on a panel about women and climate change at the United Nations’ 28th Conference of the Parties, aka COP28.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: As of Dec. 12, 2023, Geert Wilders was the “new prime minister of the Netherlands.”
Justification: Although Geert Wilders and his party won the largest number of seats in the Netherlands’ lower house of parliament — 37 of 150 — it does not constitute a majority to form a government. Coalition talks have not been successful and as of Dec. 13, Wilders had not been sworn in as prime minister.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a Doctors Without Borders medic in Jenin taking a weapon from a wounded person and giving it to someone else.
Justification: A Doctors Without Borders spokesperson told PolitiFact that the man wearing an orange vest in the video is not affiliated with the organization. Doctors Without Borders staff members wear white vests with the organization’s red logo. The orange vest matches ones worn by Palestinian Medical Relief Society members, The Associated Press and Lead Stories reported. Photos from The Associated Press, Getty Images and the Palestinian Medical Relief Society’s Facebook page also show vests in use that resemble the one worn by the man in the video. The Instagram post claims the video shows a medic in a West Bank combat zone, but Doctors Without Borders said its Jenin-based staff do not treat people outside on the streets.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows crisis actors in Palestine “working overtime to fool the world” during the current Israel-Hamas war.
Justification: This footage was originally uploaded to YouTube in 2017 and shows behind-the-scenes moments from a film project.
Sources: Press release issued by the Palestinian Ministry of Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The airport in Salzburg, Austria, has a counter for people who flew to Austria instead of Australia.”
Justification: This rumor stems from an ad. No such counter exists, according to the airport.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Israeli soldiers “raising their flag” over al-Shifa hospital in Gaza.
Justification: The video was not taken in al-Shifa hospital, but at a nearby building. A journalist using satellite imagery to find where the video was shot found that it showed the Gaza Preliminary School for Boys. We verified the location by using Google Earth imagery and identifying matching features from the video. ​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "You’re in danger” because the American Red Cross doesn’t label blood donations from donors vaccinated against COVID-19.
Justification: There is no danger from blood transfusions that include blood from COVID-19 vaccinated donors, health experts said. Vaccine components are not found in the bloodstream, an American Red Cross spokesperson said.
Sources: Association for the Advancement of blood and biotherapies
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Videos of Nancy Pelosi from Jan. 6, 2021, show the Capitol attack was staged.
Justification: This footage from Jan. 6, 2021, shows then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi speaking with then-Vice President Mike Pence about when Congress would be able to reconvene to finish certifying the 2020 election results. There are copious news reports and video and audio recordings showing that the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol was not staged. It was a real event with real consequences. More than 1,100 people have been charged with federal crimes related to the attack.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Haaretz investigation reveals discrepancies in Israel’s reporting on October 7th death toll.”
Justification: Haaretz, an Israeli newspaper, said on X that these claims about its reporting are "blatant lies." Haaretz and other news organizations have reported that during an Oct. 7 attack in Israel, Hamas killed about 1,300 people.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows protesters attacking Israel’s embassy in Bahrain with molotov cocktails.
Justification: This footage has been online for more than a decade and shows protesters outside a police station in Bahrain.
Sources: Embassy of Israel to the Kingdom of Bahrain

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Dr. Fauci doesn’t exist!”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.
Sources: National Institute of Allergy Infectious Diseases

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows North Korean President Kim Jong Un blaming President Joe Biden for the Israel-Hamas war and Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and saying, “I support Donald Trump for President in 2024.”
Justification: On Oct. 10, 2020, at a military parade, North Korea leader Kim Jong Un delivered a speech warning that his nation would use nuclear power if provoked and thanking his people for overcoming hardships such as the coronavirus pandemic. A translated version of Kim’s speech did not include the words, "Biden," "Trump," "Israel," "Palestine," "Russia," "Ukraine," or "Taliban." Russia’s February 2022 invasion of Ukraine and Hamas’ Oct. 7 attack on Israel had not yet happened. Kim mentioned that international sanctions had created challenges for North Koreans, but he did not call out the U.S. specifically in his Oct. 10, 2020, speech, according to news reports.
Sources: The National Committee on North Korea

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “New court documents reveal that George Floyd died of a fentanyl overdose.”
Justification: In an August deposition in a workplace discrimination lawsuit, Hennepin County prosecutor Amy Sweasy Tamburino claimed that Hennepin County’s medical examiner told her in 2020, prior to releasing his findings, that he found no evidence of asphyxia or strangulation during George Floyd’s autopsy. The medical examiner’s final autopsy report concluded that Floyd’s death was a homicide caused by "cardiopulmonary arrest complicating law enforcement subdual, restraint, and neck compression," not a fentanyl overdose. Sweasy’s deposition transcript revealed no new information that would prove Floyd died of a fentanyl overdose.
Sources: Email exchange with Sonia Miller-Van Oort

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Quotes House Speaker Mike Johnson as saying, “Every woman has a duty to birth at least one able-bodied worker.”
Justification: There is no evidence Speaker Mike Johnson said the quote that is attributed to him in this post. The quote is an inaccurate paraphrase of comments he made about the effect abortion access has had on the economy and the estimated federal benefits from reducing the size of the current population.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a military chaplain praying, “Please get rid of Joe Biden and bring back the real president, Donald J. Trump.”
Justification: The video’s audio was edited. The military chaplain did not pray to "get rid of" President Joe Biden and "bring back" Donald Trump. The video clip comes from footage of a Thanksgiving event the Bidens held Nov. 19 for military service members and their families. The military chaplain mentioned neither Biden nor Trump during his prayer.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: On Nov. 7, 2023, Pennsylvania voting machines were “flipping votes,” which is evidence of “election fraud.”
Justification: A clerical error by a voting machine company caused votes in two judicial races to appear switched on printed ballot summaries that were produced after some Northampton County, Pennsylvania, voters cast ballots. Local officials said the machines recorded voters’ choices accurately and all votes were tabulated properly. A spokesperson for Election Systems & Software, the company that made the voting machines, said an employee made the programming error. The Pennsylvania State Department said this error was isolated to the two judicial retention questions in Northampton County. Voters were informed of the issue before casting ballots.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Gaza on Oct. 27.
Justification: None of these photos were taken on Oct. 27. One was taken in 2019.
Sources: X post by Quds News Network

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Iceland has banned COVID-19 vaccines “amid soaring sudden deaths.”
Justification: Iceland’s health authority said the country has not banned COVID-19 vaccines and there hasn’t been a rise in deaths caused by the inoculation. The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna COVID-19 vaccines are available in Iceland, the country’s health authority said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A debit card issued by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees is being used to pay for a U.S. invasion.
Justification: The United Nations refugee agency uses the card shown in the video to give humanitarian cash assistance to certain asylum seekers in Mexico, including children at risk of abuse and exploitation, single mothers, gender-violence survivors and people with medical needs. To get this cash assistance, people must express their will to remain in Mexico and register for it. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, less than 10% of people who seek asylum in Mexico receive this assistance. Based on the refugee agency’s monitoring, most people use this help to pay rent or buy food.
Sources: Center for Immigration Studies YouTube video

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Jews did 9/11.”
Justification: Al-Qaida terrorists were responsible for the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, not ‘Jews’ or Israel.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Acapulco destroyed by yet another directed weather attack!”
Justification: Hurricane Otis stunned weather forecasters with winds that rapidly intensified in the 24 hours before it struck Acapulco, a Mexican resort city. Such rapid intensification is becoming more common because of warming oceans, a recent study showed. There are weather modification programs in use, but none that could intensify a hurricane or direct it on a path, experts said.
Sources: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Egyptians delivering food and water to Gaza” in October 2023.
Justification: This video predates the Israel-Hamas war that started in October.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Joe Rogan spoke about a child being abducted into a secret Disneyland tunnel.
Justification: There’s no evidence that Joe Rogan spoke on his podcast about an Oct. 13 child abduction at California’s Disneyland, as an Instagram video claimed. Anaheim, California, police said they are not investigating a child abduction at the park and called the video’s claim unfounded. Rogan has not worn the T-shirt he is seen wearing in the video in any podcast in October or November. Our review found he last wore the shirt for a show that aired in March.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Rise in U.S. infant mortality rate connected to COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: The U.S. infant mortality rate rose 3% in 2022, the first year-to-year increase in 20 years, a Nov. 1 report from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s National Center for Health Statistics shows. The report cited no cause for the increase. Studies have shown no increased risk of pregnancy complications among vaccinated people.
Sources: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Lego donates model MRI kits to hospitals to help children understand the procedure and reduce their anxiety.”
Justification: A Lego employee and physicians at a Danish hospital first developed a Lego model of a magnetic resonance imaging, or MRI, machine, in 2015 to help children understand the procedure and feel comfortable before their exams.
