After a successful pilot program, Lego said in 2022 that it would donate 600 model MRI scanners to hospitals worldwide.
Sources: The Lego Foundation’s Learning Through Play

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Matthew Perry died because of a COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Actor Matthew Perry died Oct. 28, but his cause of death is still under investigation. Social media claims suggesting he died because he received a COVID-19 vaccine lack evidence.
Sources: County of Los Angeles Medical Examiner

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Black Friday shoppers “in Biden’s thriving economy.”
Justification: Footage of a lone shopper entering a store on Black Friday was filmed in London in 2017. The National Retail Federation said a record 200.4 million people shopped in person or online in the U.S. over the five-day Thanksgiving weekend.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy “has surrendered.”
Justification: There are no credible reports that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has surrendered to Russia.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos are evidence actor Courteney Cox uses adrenochrome from kidnapped children.
Justification: Claims that celebrities use adrenochrome harvested from children to stay young are unfounded and stem from the QAnon movement. The supposed photo of actor Courteney Cox appearing old after she went without adrenochrome shows Cox using a photo filter designed to make her look older.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video shows “a car carrying men waving the Palestinian flag abruptly and dangerously stopping traffic to run ‘donuts.’”
Justification: The car was waving a Puerto Rican flag, not a Palestinian flag.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Billboard in New York City shows “Stand with Israel” ad replacing “Stand with Ukraine” ad.
Justification: A video claiming to show a pro-Israel ad replaced a pro-Ukraine ad on a New York City digital billboard is fabricated and didn’t appear there, the company that owns the billboard said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “In UCLA hundreds of students chanting: ‘Israel Israel you can’t hide, we want Jewish genocide.’”
Justification: Protesters chanted, "We charge you with genocide," not "We want Jewish genocide."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump exposes why 9/11 was an inside job.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump speculated in 2001 that the World Trade Center’s twin towers were felled by bombs and planes. Investigation showed the buildings collapsed following fires caused by the collisions, not bombs.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “There isn't a single video or photo suggesting that 250 people were killed (by Hamas) at a concert or that a mass shooting took place” on Oct. 7 in Israel.
Justification: The Oct. 7 Hamas attack at the Tribe of Nova music festival that killed 260 people was well documented by the media and confirmed by world leaders. Reports were substantiated by images and videos of shootings at the festival grounds.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Bill Gates: People who resist ‘mRNA tsunami’ will be excluded from society.”
Justification: Philanthropist and Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates didn’t warn of an "mRNA tsunami" that will exclude people from society. This conflates and mischaracterizes a vaccine company employee’s comments.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hamas militants “dressing up as Jewish soldiers” to create propaganda.
Justification: This is 2022 behind-the-scenes footage of a Palestinian short film.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden and his son snorted cocaine in the White House.
Justification: Authorities said they were unable to identify who left the cocaine discovered July 2 at The White House. The cocaine was found in a storage area where visitors touring the White House must leave their cellphones. White House officials have said Biden and his family were at Camp David in Maryland the weekend the cocaine was discovered.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video of howling people in Germany shows “trans species rights” protest.
Justification: The video featuring people in dog costumes was taken during a "pup walk," which was part of a September fetish festival in Berlin. It was not a protest for people who identify as animals. Puppy play is a role-playing fetish in which people dress up like dogs. There is not a widespread "trans-species" movement for the rights of people to identify and live as animals.
Sources: Email interview with spokesperson at Puppy Germany

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump is commander in chief.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump isn’t the commander in chief.
Sources: The Republican Party of Orange County

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: An emergency broadcast system test will “send a specific high-frequency signal … with the intention of activating graphene oxide” in people.
Justification: As required by law, the Federal Emergency Management Agency will conduct a nationwide test of the Emergency Alert System and Wireless Emergency Alerts at 2:20 p.m. Eastern Standard Time on Oct. 4. Conspiracy theories have claimed that COVID-19 vaccines contain graphene oxide, but the two most widely used vaccines in the U.S., Pfizer and Moderna, do not have graphene oxide as an ingredient. There’s no mechanism by which a high-frequency signal could activate the COVID-19 vaccines’ ingredients, which are short-lived in people, an expert said. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Bill Gates mRNA 'air vaccine' approved for use against non-consenting humans"
Justification: An mRNA COVID-19 "air vaccine" has not been approved for use. Yale University researchers developed a COVID-19 vaccine that could be administered in the nose, without a needle, but it was only tested on mice. The lead researcher said no humans were involved in the study. Neither philanthropist Bill Gates nor the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation provided funding to the Yale research team.
Sources: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Yale University’s School of Engineering & Applied Science

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: U.S. aid to Ukraine will continue during a government shutdown, but programs for food stamps, transportation, education, justice, environmental protection and homelessness will not.
Justification: The Defense Department said its operations supporting Ukraine in the war with Russia are exempt from a potential federal government shutdown, meaning training of troops and shipments of military equipment will continue. Hundreds of thousands of federal workers in the U.S. may be furloughed, leading to slowdowns of some federal services for Americans. But many essential services, such as law enforcement, air traffic control and food stamps will continue.
Sources: Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh
Spokesperson for the U.S. Department of Agriculture
U.S. Department of Agriculture SNAP data tables
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
White House Office of Management and Budget

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: World Economic Forum “elites” are pushing the Great Reset, which aims to control people by taking all their possessions.
Justification: The World Economic Forum and ‘the Great Reset’ have long been at the center of conspiracy theories. But there’s no evidence the forum is planning to seize people’s possessions globally.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “FDA wants to replace salt with Bill Gates’ new mRNA fake salt.”
Justification: The Food and Drug Administration has proposed a rule that would allow salt substitutes in products that use salt, but it’s not requiring such a change, and it’s not connected to philanthropist and Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates or mRNA.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is “not human.”
Justification: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is a human.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Klaus Schwab announces the end of car ownership.”
Justification: World Economic Forum Chair Klaus Schwab can’t and didn’t end car ownership.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Trump just bought a handgun!”
Justification: Video footage shows former President Donald Trump saying he wanted to buy a Glock pistol during a recent visit to a South Carolina gun shop. But his campaign told PolitiFact that Trump did not purchase a firearm. Trump faces 91 criminal charges in four separate indictments. Federal law prohibits merchants from selling guns to people under felony indictment.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden telling a child, “You’re one sexy kid.”
Justification: This video was altered

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows New York City police “arrest two young people for sleeping on concrete blocks.”
Justification: The people under arrest in a viral social media were charged with theft, according to New York police. They weren’t detained for sleeping in public, and the video provides no evidence that they were. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Statement from the New York Police Department

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Iranian lawmakers chanting “death to America” in 2023.
Justification: This video is from January 2020.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A CNN reporter “faked” being near the Israel-Gaza border.
Justification: Clarissa Ward, CNN’s chief international correspondent, was near the Israel-Gaza border in a recent broadcast and was still in Israel several days later, according to CNN.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The 2023 Israel-Hamas war is a “false flag.”
Justification: False flag operations have happened for generations, but in recent history, actual false flags are outnumbered by dubious conspiracy theories. Experts have warned that social media rumors alleging "false flags" should be viewed skeptically. We found no credible evidence that the current Israel-Hamas war is one.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Flu shot ingredients include aborted human cell cultures, monkey kidney cells and antifreeze.
Justification: Flu vaccines in the U.S. do not contain aborted human cells, monkey kidney cells or antifreeze. Flu vaccine ingredients are public and available on a U.S. Food and Drug Administration website.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email exchange with spokesperson for GSK
Email exchange with spokesperson for Sanofi
European Collection of Authenticated Cell Cultures
The College of Physicians of Philadelphia

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Israel just bombed and destroyed” St. Porphyrius Church in Gaza on Oct. 9, 2023.
Justification: As of Oct. 9, rumors of the St. Porphyrius Church in Gaza building’s destruction were "lies and fake news," the church said.
Sources: St. Porphyrios Orthodox Church Facebook post

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Republican Missouri state senators using flamethrowers to burn books.
Justification: A viral video does not show Missouri state Sens. Bill Eigel and Nick Schroer using flamethrowers to burn books. The two Republican lawmakers used the devices to burn empty cardboard boxes before the flamethrowers were auctioned off as part of a local conservative group’s fundraiser. The event organizer confirmed that no books were burned. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: St. Charles County Republican Central Committee website

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “They brought in 25,000 (National Guard members) because Biden couldn't get enough people to his inauguration.”
Justification: The audience size at President Joe Biden’s Jan. 20, 2021, inauguration was limited because of concerns related to the spread of COVID-19 and security following the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol.
Sources: Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Biden is “funding every angle” of the Israel-Hamas war.
Justification: The Biden administration has provided billions of dollars in military aid to Israel, continuing a decadeslong tradition of such U.S. aid. Joe Biden provided $360 million in humanitarian and economic assistance in 2021 to the Palestinian people in Gaza and the West Bank. That money did not fund Hamas, the militant group that controls Gaza and that attacked Israel. As part of a deal to release U.S. prisoners in Iran, the Biden administration agreed to give Iran access to its $6 billion in oil revenue that was frozen in South Korean banks. Officials say none of that money has been disbursed to Iran and is intended for humanitarian purposes.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: New York City is spraying unsafe pesticides to combat West Nile virus.
Justification: Experts and public health officials say pesticides sprayed in New York City and other cities to combat mosquitoes pose no danger to humans because of the small amount of the chemicals used. The main ingredients in pesticides used by New York City are "not likely" to cause cancer in humans, according to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. An ingredient in two of the pesticides was tied to benign tumors in animals, but there’s no evidence it causes cancer in humans. New York City’s health department said there have been no reported diseases in people or pets as a result of its mosquito spraying, which has been happening since 2001.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Less than 48 hours after Israel was attacked “we have hundreds of hours worth of footage but zero footage from the Ukraine war.”
Justification: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has been well documented by news outlets and Ukrainian civilians.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the Secret Service failing to protect Kamala Harris after she became vice president.
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris was a U.S. senator from California when a protester confronted her at a 2019 event.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A Sept. 20 video shows President Joe Biden’s body double.
Justification: Claims that President Joe Biden has been replaced by a body double are unfounded. This video was taken more than two years ago.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Burisma Energy accountant, who blew the whistle on Biden bribery scheme, found dead.”
Justification: PolitiFact found nothing to substantiate claims that a Burisma accountant was "found dead" before she could provide incriminating evidence on the Biden family. We traced this viral headline to a site known for publishing misinformation. The narrative appears to have stemmed from an unclear comment made by Rudy Giuliani, President Donald Trump’s former attorney.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Oprah Winfrey “managed to hire a private firefighting team” to protect her Maui properties before the August wildfires occurred.
Justification: A spokesperson for Oprah denied that she hired a private firefighting team before the Maui wildfires in August. Oprah’s properties in Maui were at a distance from the wildfires. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.
Sources: Council of the County of Maui Land Use Committee
Maui County Planning Department’s Report and Recommendation to the Maui Planning Commission
Maui wildfire disaster government and community response
NASA Fire Information for Resource Management System
Statement from Oprah Winfrey’s press team

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hawaiians being evicted after Maui wildfires.
Justification: This video is from a 1985 documentary about native Hawaiians being arrested and evicted on a beach in Honolulu, which is more than 100 miles from Maui, where the wildfires ignited in August. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A new photo shows Queen Elizabeth II on the day she died.
Justification: We found no evidence this image is authentic. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “People who took the jab are technically ‘non human species.’”
Justification: People don’t lose their "human" status if they get a COVID-19 vaccine. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Burning Man was a national emergency because it was flooded.”
Justification: Heavy rain began falling Sept. 1 in Nevada’s Black Rock Desert. The rain caused flooding at Burning Man, a counterculture festival that draws thousands of people to a makeshift city. The flooding temporarily stranded thousands of Burning Man attendees, who were told to shelter in place and conserve their supplies. We consulted federal websites and found no evidence the flooding at Burning Man was declared a national emergency. By early afternoon Sept. 4, the road to exit the event had been reopened.
Sources: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Marines neutralize fleeing FEMA convoy in Maui.”
Justification: This story was fabricated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows President Joe Biden confirmed “the Lahaina fires were planned.”
Justification: President Joe Biden said Aug. 31 that the Federal Emergency Management Agency response coordinator was already in Hawaii when the fires started. The FEMA official was there for a pre-scheduled meeting. Authorities are still investigating the Hawaii wildfires’ causes, but significant attention has been focused on the role the island’s aging power infrastructure played, along with drought, high winds and invasive grass.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The World Health Organization said there is "a possible causal relationship" between COVID-19 vaccines and multiple sclerosis.
Justification: The World Health Organization did not say COVID-19 vaccines might cause multiple sclerosis.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “World leaders & elite businessmen are ingesting the blood of young children in order to achieve ‘eternal youth,’ a CBS report warns.”
Justification: In 2018, CBS News reported on a clinical trial focused on transfusing blood from young donors to adults older than 35. It didn’t warn that world leaders and elite businessmen were ingesting the blood of young children. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Norway, Finland, Sweden, Holland, and the UK have now banned gender transition surgery for minors.”
Justification: Europe doesn’t ban gender-affirming care in the way some American states have by enacting laws to restrict access. Rather, care in these European countries is often dictated by health policy and guidelines. Finland and the United Kingdom’s health policies limit gender-affirming surgeries to people older than 18. Sweden and the Netherlands allow chest surgery at age 16 and genital surgeries at 18. Norway generally does not offer surgical care to minors, but has not banned it. Experts say that most transgender adolescents aren’t considering surgical care before they turn 18, and that such care is rare even in places where the procedures are legal.
Sources: Council for Choices in Health Care in Finland
Email interview with Ana Muñoz Padrós
Email interview with Anette Bakkevig Frøyland
Email interview with a spokesperson from Amsterdam UMC
European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights
The Swedish National Board of Health and Welfare

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Images of blue things that weren’t burned in Hawaii are evidence directed energy weapons started the wildfires there.
Justification: Fires can hop; directed energy weapons were not used to start wildfires in Hawaii and did not spare only blue things. Claims about directed energy weapons starting the fires in Hawaii are unfounded.
Sources: Email interview with Michael J. Gollner

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden’s comments confirm that the government is going to “increase the number and intensity of extreme weather events.”
Justification: President Joe Biden implicated climate change when recently discussing extreme weather in the United States. His full comments show he misspoke in saying the government’s response to disasters across the country in 2023 would be to "increase the number and intensity of extreme weather events." Although scientists are exploring weather modification technology could be useful in combating climate change’s future effects, these efforts so far show limited success and there is no sign that this technology has been employed in any recent wide-scale natural disasters. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bill Gates-funded research into genetically engineered cattle ticks is responsible for red-meat allergies from alpha-gal syndrome in the U.S.
Justification: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation awarded two grants to Oxitec, a biotechnology firm, to research genetically modifying the Asian blue tick, a common pest affecting cattle in some parts of the world. Oxitec said its modified ticks have not been introduced in the wild. Research has taken place only in United Kingdom labs so far. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said there’s been a rise since 2010 in alpha-gal syndrome, an allergy that’s connected to tick bites. But the CDC said that, in the U.S., the Lone Star tick is largely responsible for spreading the allergy — not the Asian blue tick.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
The Center for Food Security and Public Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “someone who tried to escape Burning Man.”
Justification: Video of "someone who tried to escape Burning Man" amid heavy rainfall was first posted online before the festival started.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Images of burned cars in Lahaina, Hawaii, are evidence wildfires there were started by directed energy weapons.
Justification: Claims that directed energy weapons were used to start recent fires in Hawaii are unfounded. Fires can spread quickly and overwhelm vegetation, structures and cars.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: U.S. Navy SEALs rescued 807 children who were being kept as sex slaves on a barge in San Francisco Bay.
Justification: The U.S. Navy says this story isn’t true.
Sources: Email interview with Lt.j.g. Erin McCullagh

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Videos show confrontation over LGBTQ+ representation.
Justification: Videos presented as real disputes in social media posts that show a parent tearing down a teacher’s pride flag in a classroom and a flight attendant arguing with a passenger over pronouns are taken from skits intended to stir discussion, their creator said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Fox News chyron called University of North Carolina shooting suspect “mostly white Asian.”
Justification: Images showing a Fox News chyron calling the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill shooting suspect a "mostly white Asian male," are fabricated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In Westport, Connecticut, drones are “scanning (people) for COVID-19 symptoms.”
Justification: A plan to use drones to detect COVID-19 in residents of Westport, Connecticut, was scrapped in 2020 over privacy concerns shortly after it was announced. A Westport Police Department spokesperson told PolitiFact the department is not using drones for this purpose.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows a missile hitting the Pentagon on 9/11.
Justification: There is overwhelming evidence that an American Airlines plane crashed into the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, not a missile.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Hawaii is being attacked by direct energy weapons."
Justification: Investigators have not yet determined a single cause for the fires, although attention is increasingly focused on the role downed power lines may have played. Drought conditions and high winds likely contributed to the wildfires’ quick spread, officials say. The U.S. and other governments are exploring using direct energy weapons for military purposes, but experts say there is no evidence they played a role in the Hawaii wildfires.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The World Economic Forum is calling “for COVID concentration camps.”
Justification: This claim originated from The People’s Voice, a site that frequently publishes false information. The article offered no evidence and we found no proof to support the claim. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Oprah started the fire.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Women vaccinated against COVID-19 face "unknown side effects that could perpetually go down through the lineage" to their children.
Justification: COVID-19 vaccines don’t alter DNA, and their side effects are not transmissible, experts said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Modified mosquitoes have officially made it to Ohio.”
Justification: Planes flying over Riverfest, a daylong event on the Ohio River between Cincinnati and Newport, Kentucky, were part of the event. A trail of smoke seen in videos from one of the planes was from smoke oil, a tool commonly used by aerobatic planes to increase visibility. There are no mosquito-release programs in Ohio. Oxitec, which releases genetically modified mosquitoes in order to reduce the pest’s population, is the only such program approved in the U.S. It has released mosquitoes only in the Florida Keys over three seasons since 2021 — none by aircraft.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Fauci declares that all unvaccinated citizens must be locked down this winter.”
Justification: Dr. Anthony Fauci stepped down as director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and has no power to declare a lockdown. He did not make any statement urging the Biden administration to implement a lockdown for unvaccinated Americans in 2023.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “183 bodies have washed up on Lanai.”
Justification: As of Aug. 28, no remains from the wildfires had washed ashore on Lanai.
Sources: Emailed statement from the Maui Police Department

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “California Democrats have proposed Bill 553, which makes it ILLEGAL to confront or fight back against looters, burglars and shoplifters.”
Justification: S.B. 553, which passed the California Legislature on Sept. 12, neither legalizes crimes, nor mentions criminal charges or fines for workers who confront shoplifters. A previous version of the bill said employers were prohibited "from maintaining policies that require employees who are not dedicated safety personnel to confront active shooters or suspected shoplifters." This provision was removed in August. Learn more aboutPolitiFact's fact-checking process and rating system.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "America’s C40 cities will ban meat, dairy, new clothes, private cars by 2030.”
Justification: A 2019 report by the C40 Cities Climate Leadership Group examined consumption-based carbon emissions in its network of cities in six categories, including food, travel and clothing. The report highlighted progressive and ambitious targets to reduce emissions, but said it was not advocating that cities meet the ambitious targets. We could find no evidence that any U.S. cities have agreed to ban meat, dairy, new clothes or private cars.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that the government is passing the “Digital Existence Act” in response to the new COVID-19 variant.
Justification: The X post was not made by Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, but by a self-described parody account named "Justin Trudeau’s Ego." There is no bill titled the "Digital Existence Act."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos are proof that Hawaii fires were caused by a “direct energy weapon assault on the people.”
Justification: Photos that claim to show the origins of Hawaii wildfires are not of recent events in that state. One photo showing a ground fire and a beam of light in the sky above has been circulating online in other baseless claims since 2018. A second photo that claims to show events in Hawaii instead shows a 2018 SpaceX rocket launch.
Sources: Office of the U.S. Air Force’s Chief Scientist for Directed Energy

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: No human remains or aircraft debris were found at the Pentagon or in Pennsylvania after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.
Justification: Human remains and aircraft debris were recovered from both 9/11 sites.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California passed a law “reducing penalties for oral, anal sex with willing children.”
Justification: A 2020 California law changed how sex offenders are added to the state’s sex offender registry. It did not reduce penalties for having sex with minors.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A wind turbine must “spin continually for over four years just to replace the energy it took to manufacture it.”
Justification: A wind turbine can produce in months, not years, more energy than was needed to manufacture it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "WEF chairman Klaus Schwab openly calls for AI technology to replace Democratic elections!”
Justification: In a 2017 interview, World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab interviewed Google co-founder Sergey Brin. Schwab posed several hypothetical questions about the future of digital technology, including artificial intelligence. One question was whether Brin could imagine the technology becoming so prescriptive that elections wouldn’t be needed. Schwab did not call for that scenario to happen.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Klaus Schwab “publicly admitted he is planning to implement China-style forced COVID lockdowns all over the world during the ‘next pandemic.’”
Justification: We found no evidence that World Economic Forum chairman Klaus Schwab said he planned to implement forced global lockdowns, an action he has no authority to take.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: While nearly naked, a member of Mexico’s congress said, “You are ashamed to see me naked, but you are not ashamed to see your people in the streets naked.”
Justification: A Mexican lawmaker stripped during a congressional debate, but he didn’t make the statement attributed to him on social media about "people in the streets naked."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bud Light billboard says “lol CRYBABIES”
Justification: The original creator of the Bud Light billboard explained in a follow-up video that he fabricated the image appearing on the sign based on a Disney+ billboard. An executive with Branded Cities, the actual Disney+ billboard’s owner, told The Associated Press the Bud Light billboard was fabricated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The World Economic Forum “launches ‘mark of the beast’ CBDC microchip that will ‘end gun ownership in America.’”
Justification: This claim is false, according to the World Economic Forum. We found no evidence to contradict that.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The tornado that destroyed a Pfizer building in North Carolina was orchestrated using weather manipulation to provide “an insurance claim for big pharma.”
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “A lot of your chain-food restaurants have been using (lab-grown meat) for years.”
Justification: Lab-grown meat, or cell-cultivated meat, creates real meat from animal cells. Two companies, Good Meat and Upside Foods, in June received U.S. government approval to sell lab-grown chicken to consumers. Each company has made the chicken available only at one restaurant, neither of which is part of a major fast-food chain.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Helicopter released deadly mosquitoes” at Baltimore’s AFRAM Festival.
Justification: A swarm of flying insects annoyed a crowd of music lovers at the AFRAM music festival in Baltimore in June. Many in the crowd described the insects as gnats, not mosquitoes. Mosquitoes do not swarm in the way seen in the video, one insect expert said.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Nicole Schwab said, “Permanent climate lockdowns coming — whether you like it or not.”
Justification: We found no evidence that World Economic Forum founder Klaus Schwab’s daughter Nicole Schwab warned of imminent "permanent climate lockdowns." The viral headline originated on a site known for publishing misinformation, and the article was written by a person known for spreading conspiracy theories and false claims.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Military arrests Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla.”
Justification: There is no evidence Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla was "captured" by the U.S. Marine Corps. The article was published by Real Raw News, a website that publishes "humor, parody and satire" and has a history of posting false information.
Sources: Statement from Pfizer media relations team
Wayback Machine copy of " Military Arrests Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Senator Mitt Romney threatens to leave the Republican party and join Democrats.”
Justification: Republican Sen. Mitt Romney of Utah has not publicly threatened to switch to the Democratic Party. A spokesperson for the senator called online claims to the contrary "misinformation spread by online bots." Romney in April filed a statement of candidacy with the Federal Election Commission as a Republican.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “13 nations agree to abolish farming in order to save the planet.”
Justification: A European Union Times headline shared on Instagram misrepresented a commitment made by 13 countries, including the United States, to reduce methane emissions from the agricultural sector. These countries did not agree to "abolish farming." Methane is a major driver of climate change, and 40% of the world’s human-derived methane emissions come from the agricultural sector. Global organizations have proposed reducing methane emissions, but these do not include getting rid of farming.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Beyonce paid $100K for Maryland Metro to run later following weather delays for her concert.”
Justification: Beyoncé’s Renaissance World Tour paid $100,000 to cover the costs for the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority to run its trains an hour later than planned after her concert. Under a Metro policy, event organizers requesting early or late train service around an event must prepay for the service. The current fee is $100,000 per hour and is paid by event organizers or sponsors. The Aug. 6 show at FedEx Field was delayed about two hours because of inclement weather.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Videos show Planned Parenthood “aiding sex traffickers in their crimes.”
Justification: The anti-abortion group Live Action recently reshared hidden-camera videos from 2011 that show hired actors posing at multiple Planned Parenthood locations as underage sex workers with their adult sex traffickers. Planned Parenthood said the videos are edited to show only parts of the conversations between Planned Parenthood employees and the undercover actors. Planned Parenthood fired the employee shown in one video for acting inappropriately; the employee in the other video followed the law and company protocol. This new post omits that soon after the incidents shown in the videos, Planned Parenthood workers reported the alleged sex trafficking to authorities and fired the non-compliant employee.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos of Barack Obama golfing with bandaged fingers are proof of his involvement in Tafari Campbell’s death.
Justification: Tafari Campbell, a personal chef for the Obamas, died recently in a paddleboard accident in a pond near the Obamas’ Martha’s Vineyard home. Massachusetts State Police said a witness saw Campbell fall into the water and struggle to surface. Police said they do not consider his death suspicious, and that the Obamas were not home at the time. Golfers, including former President Barack Obama, often wear bandages or tape on their fingers to protect from blisters or split calluses. Obama has previously been photographed with the tape on his hands while golfing.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hawaii Gov. Josh Green “wants to turn Lahaina Maui into state lands. All planned for smart city."
Justification: Maui residents have said outside developers are offering to buy homes destroyed by wildfires, raising concerns about a land grab. Hawaii Gov. Josh Green said in an Aug. 12 interview that he was looking for ways for the state to buy land in Lahaina to preserve it for local residents. He did not mention the term "smart city," which is a concept proposing governments use technology to improve services for residents. It would not require a government taking land to implement.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “A Pfizer warehouse full of Covid vaccines was just DESTROYED BY A TORNADO in North Carolina.”
Justification: On July 19, a tornado damaged a Pfizer facility in Rocky Mount, North Carolina. The pharmaceutical company said this facility did not manufacture or store COVID-19 vaccines.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "FBI director Wray confirms Joe Biden is under criminal investigation for Ukrainian bribes by the U.S. attorney in Delaware then tries to backpedal.”
Justification: FBI Director Christopher Wray referred a legislator to the U.S attorney’s office in Delaware when asked in a House Judiciary Committee hearing whether President Joe Biden had received payments from Ukraine. There is a continuing investigation in Delaware into Hunter Biden, the president’s son. Wray did not say that Joe Biden is also being investigated. He said he would not say who is or isn’t being investigated, or for what, as part of the FBI’s long-standing policy. There was an unsubstantiated allegation made by an informant in a 2020 FBI form that a Burisma executive paid Joe and Hunter Biden $5 million each to fire a Ukrainian prosecutor. Multiple news outlets reported in early June that law enforcement couldn’t substantiate the allegations, and the FBI hasn’t commented publicly.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: People who received COVID-19 vaccines can “detoxify” their bodies from the spike protein.
Justification: There is no scientific data showing that spike proteins produced from COVID-19 vaccination are toxic, a Food and Drug Administration spokesperson said. Rigorous testing and safety monitoring have found that the vaccines are safe and effective.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows a highway in Houston.
Justification: This photo was taken in Beijing.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Skin cancer is a relatively new phenomenon in the last 60 years or so.”
Justification: Skin cancer didn’t emerge in the last 60 years. It has been recognized by scientists since at least 1804.
Sources: Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Maui fires are part of an intentional effort to rebuild the island into a “smart island.”
Justification: Officials have not determined the cause of wildfires that have killed dozens of people in Hawaii, but there’s been no public evidence they were set intentionally. The urban planning concept of smart cities was among many topics discussed at a January technology conference in Maui. None of the research papers presented at the conference discussed turning Maui into a "smart island."
Sources: Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences
New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former President Barack Obama “removed 500,000 pedophiles from background check database.”
Justification: This claim misrepresented a 2017 Washington Post report about hundreds of thousands of "fugitives from justice" being purged from the background check database for gun purchases. The report did not specify that the people removed were pedophiles.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: When Bill Nye said “the Earth is a closed system,” he suggested space exploration is impossible.
Justification: Bill Nye said "the Earth is a closed system" while talking about the concept of throwing trash into space. ​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Tafari Campbell, the Obamas’ personal chef who drowned, tweeted that he had “information that will lead to the arrest of Barack Obama.”
Justification: Tafari Campbell, a personal chef to the Obama family, was found dead July 24 after he drowned in a paddleboarding accident in Martha’s Vineyard. He was 45. Social media posts claimed Campbell tweeted that he had information that would lead to former President Barack Obama’s arrest. But that tweet was fabricated.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump and Joe Biden both died years ago.”
Justification: Both former President Donald Trump and President Joe Biden are alive.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “French President Macron has declared a total ban on social media reporting of events in France.”
Justification: France erupted in violent protests following the police shot and killed a 17-year-old driver  during a traffic stop. A fake government press release announced there were temporary restrictions on internet access in some regions. No limitations on internet or social media access have been instituted, though French President Emmanuel Macron has criticized the role these platforms have played in the violence.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former FBI agent Ted Gunderson was murdered.
Justification: Former FBI agent Ted Gunderson died of cancer in 2011, according to his son.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Gold fringe on an American flag means “the Constitution is suspended.”
Justification: Gold fringe added to the American flag is merely decorative. It does not signify that the U.S. Constitution has been suspended.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Titan “submarine never happened. They faked their own deaths.”
Justification: This claim is unfounded.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The U.S. Department of Agriculture requires anyone with a garden to “register that with the government.”
Justification: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has a voluntary registration program for qualifying people who want to designate their gardens as People’s Gardens. But the agency doesn’t require Americans to register their gardens.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Protestors in France have released animals from the zoo.
Justification: Many of the video clips in these claims are old or from other countries. The Paris Zoological Park responded on Twitter to the claims, writing that the animals are all safe.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Donald Trump arrested” July 5.
Justification: Former President Donald Trump wasn’t arrested July 5.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video is evidence the moon landing was faked because someone would have had to stay behind to film
Justification: A remotely controlled camera captured Apollo 17 leaving the moon in 1972. This video is not evidence the moon landing was a hoax.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Recent wildfires put more carbon in the atmosphere than "the human race has put out in the last 100 years."
Justification: Canada’s wildfires have set records for carbon dioxide emissions over a short period of time, but they represent only a tiny fraction of total CO2 emissions from human activity.
Sources: Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California San Diego

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Joe Biden leaning in and sniffing a child.
Justification: This is an altered video. It was zoomed in and cut short, with sniffing sounds added in.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Biden administration quietly DROPS all charges against Sam Bankman-Fried.”
Justification: Prosecutors are continuing to trial in October with eight charges against Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder and former CEO of the bankrupt cryptocurrency exchange FTX, who was extradited to the U.S. from the Bahamas, where FTX was based. After Bankman-Fried’s attorneys objected to five charges pressed against him following his extradition, prosecutors temporarily withdrew them but asked a judge to schedule a second trial date to address those charges. That date is set for March 2024, giving Bahamian authorities time to review the charges and determine whether they consent to them.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The day before 9/11 the Pentagon reported $2.3 trillion missing.”
Justification: The Pentagon did not report $2.3 trillion missing Sept. 10, 2001. Accounting entries totaling that amount that lacked adequate audit trails were detailed in government records, news reports and an official’s testimonies long before 9/11.
Sources: Department of Defense Office of the Inspector General

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden announced that the U.S. dollar will now become cryptocurrency.”
Justification: Executive Order 14067, which President Joe Biden signed in March 2022, directed the Federal Reserve to weigh the risks of using digital currency and research the possibility of using a central bank digital currency. It didn’t turn the U.S. dollar into cryptocurrency.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Florida to ban mRNA vaccines as credible evidence of biological weapons."
Justification: Florida state officials have not moved to ban COVID-19 vaccines and brand them as biological weapons. Some county Republican parties in Florida have called for such a ban.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Titan submersible passenger Shahzada Dawood is the World Economic Forum’s vice chairman.
Justification: The Instagram post misrepresented the World Economic Forum page on Shahzada Dawood. He was the vice chairman of Engro Corp. Engro Corp. is a partner of the World Economic Forum.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ohio replaced lethal injection “with a system that quickly and humanely rips off the heads of death-row inmates using powerful robotic arms.”
Justification: An Instagram video about Ohio’s new plan for prisoners on death row was produced by The Onion, an outlet known for its satirical headlines and stories.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Health professionals are being “urged” to call vaginas “bonus holes” to avoid offending transgender or nonbinary patients.
Justification: There is no widespread push for health care professionals to use the term "bonus hole" instead of "vagina." Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust, a United Kingdom-based charity, listed the term "bonus hole" on its website as an alternative word to vagina that some transgender and nonbinary patients may prefer. The glossary encourages health care professionals to talk with patients about the language and terminology they are comfortable using.
Sources: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
World Professional Association for Transgender Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “No human is allowed to travel to Antarctica.”
Justification: Humans may travel to Antarctica, and scientists among others live there on a rotating basis.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: NASA faked footage of astronauts on the International Space Station.
Justification: This is one in a series of false claims about the existence in space of the International Space Station, which has been crewed since its launch in 2000.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows the city of San Diego displaying a flag supportive of pedophilia.
Justification: A progress pride flag was displayed at Balboa Park in San Diego for Pride Month, but its colors don’t represent pedophiles.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Greta Thunberg said the world would end on June 21, 2023.
Justification: This post distorts a tweet Greta Thunberg posted in 2018.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Wall Street Journal reporting proves that “Pizzagate” is real.
Justification: The Wall Street Journal didn’t confirm that the debunked Pizzagate conspiracy theory is real. The newspaper recently reported that Instagram allowed a network of accounts that commission and purchase underage-sex content to connect with one another and promote their content. Some of these accounts use emojis as code language, including an image for "cheese pizza." One of The Wall Street Journal’s reporters dismissed the claims. The Pizzagate conspiracy theory — which claims that former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, and those around her, ran a child sex-trafficking ring in a Washington, D.C., pizzeria’s basement — remains baseless.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says a video showing water inside a glass on a spaceflight proves space isn’t real
Justification: This video shows Chinese taikonauts giving a lecture aboard the 2021-22 spaceflight Shenzhou-13. Water has high surface tension, so it makes sense that a glass seen in the video would retain water. Liquid molecules bind together rather than moving to other surfaces. The glass itself was affixed to the table with Velcro, Chinese fact-checkers wrote.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Biden points and waves to nobody again.”
Justification: President Joe Biden was waving and pointing at people to the left of him onstage, not "nobody," as a recent social media video claims.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video of Hunter Biden at the White House was taken on the “same day they found cocaine.”
Justification: This video was taken two days after cocaine was discovered at the White House.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video suggests COVID-19 vaccines are responsible for breast cancer deaths in women under age 45 rising from 26,000 in 2021 to 297,000 in 2023.
Justification: An Instagram video misstates what an American Cancer Society report shows, mistaking projected cases for deaths and confusing age group categories. The statistics the video cites are not listed in the American Cancer Society report as numbers of deaths; they are projected cases of cancer. And the largest figure the video mentions was projected cases from all age groups, not just 45 and younger.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: NASA space rockets can’t reach space.
Justification: NASA rockets have reached space numerous times.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Neil deGrasse Tyson describing how NASA faked the moon landing.
Justification: NASA did not fake the moon landing. The Instagram clip took a joke about the moon landing conspiracy out of context. In the full interview, Neil deGrasse Tyson was rejecting claims that the moon landing was fake.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Smoke that covered New York, New Jersey and Connecticut after the Canadian wildfires “was a planned operation in geoengineering.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that geoengineering — using technology to manipulate the environment — produced smoke that covered the U.S. Northeast in early June. The evidence is that the smoke came from Canadian wildfires.
Sources: Cooperative Institute for Research in the Atmosphere at Colorado State University and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration
Harvard University Solar Engineering Research Program

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos show “Elon Musk and his company are in the final stages of making a Robot Wife.”
Justification: The images of Twitter owner Elon Musk kissing robots were generated by artificial intelligence. There is no evidence that he is making a "robot wife."
Sources: Instagram direct message exchange with Pablo Xavier

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says a report shows that “Ventilators Killed Nearly ALL COVID Patients”
Justification: The claim cites a Northwestern University study as evidence that ventilators killed nearly all COVID-19 patients. One of the study’s authors told PolitiFact the claim is inaccurate. The study focused on the effects of ventilator-associated pneumonia and found it was a contributing factor, not a direct cause, of death.
Sources: Phone interviews with Dr. Benjamin Singer

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows officials in Maricopa County, Arizona, "illegally breaking into" voting machines.
Justification: The video, which was recorded and livestreamed by cameras owned by Maricopa County, showed routine preparation for the Nov. 8, 2022, election, the county said in a court filing.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Hundreds of thousands of innocent people died” from taking the drug azidothymidine, or AZT.
Justification: We found no evidence that azidothymidine, or AZT, has killed "hundreds of thousands" of people. An expert said this claim is a conspiracy theory. ​
Sources: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "NYC mayor plans to track and limit meat and dairy."
Justification: New York Mayor Eric Adams has long advocated a plant-based diet for personal and environmental health. A city report relied on a national, voluntary survey to model New York carbon emissions from food. Adams has introduced policies that limit the amount of red meat served each week at city institutions, such as hospitals, schools and jails. There are no limits on what citizens can consume.
Sources: New York City Mayor’s Office of Climate and Environmental Justice

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Italy announced they are changing LGBT Pride month to Family Pride Month,” in order to “celebrate traditional families.”
Justification: Italy’s Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni has not announced that Pride month was changed to a "Family Pride Month" to celebrate heterosexual families instead of the LGBTQ+ community. Pride month celebrations continue in Italy.
Sources: International Gay and Lesbian Travel Association

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "The European Union is now warning pregnant women not to get the COVID-19 vaccine due to the possibility of infertility and miscarriage.”
Justification: The European Union has not warned pregnant women to avoid COVID-19 vaccines because of fertility and miscarriage risks. The European Medicines Agency, which regulates drug safety in the EU, said on its website that studies have shown the vaccines do not increase risks of pregnancy complications, such as miscarriages. An agency task force said in October 2022 that there’s no evidence that heavy menstrual bleeding, a possible side effect of the vaccines, have any effect on reproduction and fertility.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “A Ukrainian tank uses a house as camouflage.”
Justification: The video does not show a Ukrainian military tank. It’s a car a Ukrainian folk craftsman converted into a "house on wheels." A reverse-image search revealed the video was from 2020, which predates Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Miami-Dade County has banned” Amanda Gorman’s poem “from elementary schools.”
Justification: In March, a parent of students at the Bob Graham Education Center, a school in Florida’s Miami-Dade County, filed a complaint about "The Hill We Climb," a poem written by Amanda Gorman and read at President Joe Biden’s inauguration. After a review, the school moved the book to the middle school section of the K-8 school’s library. The school said the book was not banned, and that all students can still access it if they are at the appropriate reading level. That might limit access for some younger students.
Sources: Florida Department of Education 2021-22 Bob Graham Education Center Report Card
Florida Department of Education 2022-23 enrollment map

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Recent wildfires in California were planned to clear land for a high-speed rail system.
Justification: This claim originated in 2018. It was wrong then, too. Recent research has found that a surge in wildfires in California is largely attributable to climate change.
Sources: California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Pop-Tarts and other foods “have antifreeze in them.”
Justification: Some foods and drinks contain a small amount of propylene glycol, a food additive that helps maintain moisture and structure. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has determined propylene glycol is safe to consume in small quantities. Propylene glycol, like many substances, can also be found in nonfood products, such as antifreeze. That does not mean that foods that contain propylene glycol also contain antifreeze.
Sources: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Footage shows Canada’s wildfires were “planned.”
Justification: Video circulating on social media is being framed as evidence the recent wildfires in Canada were planned. That’s wrong. Footage of so-called planned ignitions show a strategy to combat wildfires, not start them.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Mel Gibson has announced he has been secretly working on a 4 part docu series exposing the 34 billion dollar global child sex trafficking trade.”
Justification: Mel Gibson’s publicist said the actor isn’t working on any documentaries.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says Bill Gates visited Jeffrey Epstein’s Island "37 times."
Justification: Subpoenaed flight logs that had previously been obtained by the press show that philanthropist and Microsoft Corp. co-founder Bill Gates traveled on financier Jeffrey Epstein’s plane once, from New Jersey to Florida. They do not show that he traveled to Epstein’s private island in the Virgin Islands. Gates and Esptein did meet multiple times between 2011 to 2013, The New York Times reported. Gates said he met with Epstein for philanthropic donations, and has since said he regrets doing so.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Pfizer funneled $12 million to CNN anchor Anderson Cooper as part of a deal to promote mRNA COVID jabs to the American public.”
Justification: There is no evidence that Pfizer is paying CNN anchor Anderson Cooper’s salary to promote the COVID-19 vaccine.
Sources: Email with Robert F. Kennedy Jr. press team

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In a simulation, an AI-enabled drone operated by the U.S. Air Force killed its operators and “started taking out communication towers.”
Justification: This scenario was described by U.S. Air Force Col. Tucker "Cinco" Hamilton, chief of AI test and operations, in a conference. But he later said he "misspoke" and that this was only a hypothetical thought experiment. Hamilton said the scenario is possible but that the U.S. Air Force has not tested any weaponized AI in this way.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A bill in Connecticut that changes the definition for “sexual orientation” would protect “minor attracted persons” from discrimination.
Justification: Connecticut House Bill 6638 would modernize the definition of "sexual orientation," but it would not protect child sex offenders. Experts on sexual orientation law said that the proposed definition would not protect child sex offenders or people attracted to minors.
Sources: CHRO Testimony Regarding HB 6638 – AA Revising the State’s Antidiscrimination Statutes
Connecticut House of Representatives House Bill 6638

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 vaccines administered during pregnancy drove an increase in cases of myocarditis in babies.
Justification: Between June 2022 and April 2023 in Wales, 10 newborns under 28 days old developed myocarditis associated with infections from enterovirus, some of the most prevalent viruses in the world, according to the World Health Organization and the Welsh minister for health and social services. A WHO spokesperson told PolitiFact that at this stage, there is no reason to believe the increase in myocarditis cases among newborns was linked to COVID-19 vaccines. Health authorities are investigating the situation further, including exploring population immunity and evaluating the pandemic’s impact on how infections circulate.
Sources: Emailed statement from Dr. Shamez Ladhani
Emailed statement from a World Health Organization spokesperson
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A list shows violent crimes in Los Angeles that “people will be set free on as of today.”
Justification: The screenshot shows exceptions to Los Angeles County’s zero-bail policy — charges for which people would be required to post bail — not offenses on which people would be released with zero bail. The Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department said May 24 that the zero-bail policy does not apply to serious or violent offenses.
Sources: Second Los Angeles County Emergency Bail Schedule Modification
Third Los Angeles County Emergency Bail Schedule Modification

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “An 11-year-old boy saved the lives of two people on the same day.”
Justification: On Dec. 9, 2021, then-sixth grader Davyon Johnson performed the Heimlich maneuver on a Oklahoma classmate who was choking on a bottle cap. Later that day, while riding in the car with his mother, Davyon noticed that a house was on fire. They pulled over and Davyon got out to help an elderly woman get away from the burning house.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “They are trying to throw Trump in jail for the rest of his life for having a couple dozen documents that he had authority to declassify.”
Justification: Former President Donald Trump has been indicted on 37 charges in a case centered on federal documents he took to Mar-a-Lago, his Palm Beach, Florida, resort. In 2022, the federal government recovered more than 300 documents with classified markings from Mar-a-Lago. Presidents do have the authority to declassify documents, but the Justice Department said Trump gave no indication he declassified any of the sensitive material found at Mar-a-Lago.
Sources: U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia
U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A movement representing "minor attracted people" has adopted a flag that is being integrated into LGBTQ+ advocacy.
Justification: The so-called pedophile pride flag appears to have been created by a Tumblr user in 2018 as a prank. The flag has spread online and may have been used by some people who describe themselves as being "attracted" to children, but most posts that shared the image online did so to condemn its use. LGBTQ+ advocacy groups have not incorporated pedophilia advocacy into their work, nor have they adopted or shared this flag. The term "minor-attracted persons" is used by organizations that aim to provide access to therapy for people who describe themselves as being sexually attracted to minors.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy called for the immediate “expulsion and prosecution of Rep. Adam Schiff for committing crimes of treason against the United States.”
Justification: House Speaker Kevin McCarthy, R-Calif., has publicly questioned whether Rep. Adam Schiff, D-Calif., should be expelled from the House. But McCarthy has stopped short of calling for Schiff’s removal. Another Republican representative submitted a resolution to expel Schiff, but McCarthy has not voiced his support for the resolution.
Sources: Office of Special Counsel John H. Durham

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Former President Donald Trump rescued deformed children who were born into sex slavery in tunnels under Central Park in New York.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support this claim. The proof the Facebook post offers includes images of a supposed site where children were rescued; it was actually a COVID-19 field hospital.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows boxes of books removed from a middle school library that were “banned by the DeSantis regime in Florida.”
Justification: The books at a Florida middle school were not banned. The school was "weeding" out the books because they were out of date.
Sources: Gov. Ron DeSantis administration press release

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: President Joe Biden showed signs of cognitive decline when he walked away from an Air Force Falcons presentation with a jersey, snubbing a signed football and helmet.
Justification: The full video showed that Biden held the jersey, football and helmet, thanked the Air Force Falcons and posed for pictures.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “AIDS-associated diseases and cancers have increased by 338x since the rollout of the COVID-19 vaccines, according to the CDC and foreign government bodies."
Justification: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it hasn’t detected any unusual or unexpected patterns for HIV or AIDS-associated diseases and cancers following COVID-19 immunization. The figure comes from unverified data in the U.S. government’s Vaccine Adverse Reporting System. Any person can report adverse events in the system. The reports are not verified, and incomplete VAERS data is often used in claims about vaccine safety. There is no association between the COVID-19 vaccines and the risk for HIV infection or associated cancers, according to medical experts and the CDC.
Sources: The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The United Nations replaces all 193 country flags with LGBT flags.”
Justification: The United Nations in New York didn’t replace its member country flags with pride flags, a spokesperson said. A photo used to support this claim was taken at Rockefeller Center in New York City in 2019.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Rep. Nancy Pelosi being arrested.
Justification: The video shows Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., leaving her San Francisco home and getting into her car.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Dropped globe in video shows NASA astronauts filming in TV studio.
Justification: A NASA astronaut on the International Space Station dropped a plastic globe during a 2021 livestream video, pushing it down and out of the camera frame with his arm motion. The full video shows the globe floating back into the frame seconds later, as well as the globe and microphones floating at other times during the event.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Walmart stores are being converted to FEMA camps to imprison Americans.
Justification: These claims are unfounded. A Walmart spokesperson said there’s "no truth" to them.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: An Instagram video shows a man confronting President Joe Biden about an inappropriate relationship with a 13-year-old girl.
Justification: An Instagram video that appears to show a man confronting President Joe Biden about an inappropriate relationship with a 13-year-old girl is fake. It features deceptively edited clips of a 2019 Biden interview spliced together with segments from the show, "To Catch a Predator." Biden has been the target of pedophilia attacks for years, but we’ve found no credible evidence to support such claims.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “mRNA in food is being tested by USDA now.”
Justification: The U.S. Department of Agriculture said it isn’t testing for mRNA in meat or poultry, the food products it oversees, and told us there are no mRNA vaccines approved or under trial for cattle. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration oversees milk products and confirmed there are no tests involving mRNA. The video in the post misrepresents a recent study that used cow’s milk molecules to stabilize mRNA to inject into mice and elicit an immune response. The research didn’t show, as the clip claims, that mRNA can be ingested via milk and cross the gastrointestinal barrier into the bloodstream. Chances are minuscule that mRNA vaccines could transfer to people who consume food products from vaccinated animals, experts said. Messenger RNA breaks down quickly, and federal rules don't allow for meat or milk to be harvested from animals until recent vaccines have been metabolized.
Sources: USDA Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The Antarctic ice cap is not melting.”
Justification: Multiple scientific studies have found that the Antarctic ice sheets have been melting for decades. The two people who claimed that the ice sheets aren’t melting, Judith Curry and Don Easterbrook, are known for questioning or denying proven aspects of climate change.
Sources: Ice Sheet Mass Balance Inter-comparison Exercise website
National Snow and Ice Data Center

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows people collapsing because of COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: None of these incidents in which people on air experienced medical emergencies were linked to the COVID-19 vaccine. Two of the incidents predate the pandemic.
Sources: National Institutes of Health National Library of Medicine

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Chick-fil-A “donates another $1.8 million to anti-LGBTQ groups,” backtracking on its promise not to.
Justification: The donations to the Salvation Army and the Fellowship of Christian Athletes amounting to $1.8 million were made in 2018, a year before the company said it would no longer donate to the organizations.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: NASA's T-minus launch countdown is a mocking reference to Satan.
Justification: The "T" in a "T Minus" countdown simply stands for "time" or "test."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Duke Health, UNC Health and ECU Health “in North Carolina are diagnosing toddlers who play with stereotypically opposite gender toys as having gender dysphoria and are beginning to transition them!!”
Justification: Duke Health, UNC Health and ECU Health rebutted claims that the systems provide transition care to toddlers. In statements, both ECU Health and UNC Health said that it is not an indication of gender dysphoria when children play with toys that are stereotypically associated with the opposite gender. The standards of care for gender diverse youth that are accepted by many major medical organizations recommend social transition only for children who haven’t reached puberty.
Sources: Statement provided by Duke Health media relations director Sarah Avery
World Professional Association for Transgender Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Joe Biden touching a child inappropriately.
Justification: This photo of President Joe Biden is altered.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Chelsea Clinton said, “It’s time to force-jab every unvaccinated child in America.”
Justification: Chelsea Clinton did not say that every unvaccinated child in the U.S. should be forcibly vaccinated without parental consent. Clinton spoke of the Clinton Health Access Initiative’s partnership with the World Health Organization and others in the "Big Catch-up," a global effort to restore childhood immunization progress lost during the COVID-19 pandemic. There are no forced vaccinations associated with the initiative, the WHO said.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows someone impersonating Joe Biden in a mask.
Justification: If this video shows anything, it’s that Biden, 80, has wrinkles. The full video comes from Biden’s widely covered April trip to Ireland, during which he took questions from children.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Face masks may raise risk of stillbirths, testicular dysfunction and cognitive decline, study warns.”
Justification: The "study" was an article that reviewed studies. It presented no evidence that masks caused serious health problems.
Sources: Annals of the American Thoracic Society
Indian Journal of Otolaryngology and Head & Neck Surgery
Journal of Infectious Diseases and Epidemiology

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Healthy pilots are suffering from myocarditis and dropping dead on flights” because of the COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: There is no evidence that causally links adverse side effects from COVID-19 vaccines to incidents of pilots dying or becoming incapacitated on flights. There were several incidents in March of pilots falling ill on flights, but no details support claims they were related to vaccine effects. The Federal Aviation Administration and the International Air Transport Association say they have seen no credible evidence to support claims there has been an increase in pilot deaths or incapacitations due to vaccines.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Pfizer agreed to pay $2.3 billion in a health care fraud settlement involving COVID-19 vaccines.
Justification: In 2009, Pfizer was fined $2.3 billion for fraudulent marketing of an anti-inflammatory drug called Bextra. The settlement came more than a decade before the COVID-19 pandemic. ​

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bill Gates is coating your organic produce with a “dangerous chemical.”
Justification: Apeel Sciences created a thin, edible coating that extends the shelf life of fruits and vegetables. The plant-based coating  is deemed safe by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.
Sources: U.S. Food and Drug Administration database

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “1,900 food production companies have been destroyed” as part of conspiracy.
Justification: Many fires or accidents have made headlines, but such things are not uncommon in manufacturing plants or farms, experts said. Two recent fires at egg farms killed hundreds of thousands of birds, but the farms are still operating. The causes haven’t been determined, but there’s no sign of foul play. We found no groups that track food plant fires. But when we have fact-checked more detailed claims that suggest widespread, coordinated destruction of food processing facilities, we learned that most of the incidents cited were not deemed suspicious by authorities investigating them.
Sources: Email from Pennsylvania State Police spokesperson

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The abortion pill has been linked to the deaths of at least 28 women in the U.S. alone.”
Justification: A U.S. Food and Drug Administration report showed 28 deaths out of 5.6 million women who have taken the drug since it was approved in 2000 through June 30, 2022. But the FDA did not attribute these deaths to mifepristone. Some of the deaths, such as ones caused by sepsis and ectopic rupture, could be plausibly related to mifepristone, experts said. But the cases listed also included patients who died by homicide, suicide and various drug overdoses.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “We are about 1 degree Celsius above the coldest it’s been in the last 10,000 years” and “that’s why we shouldn’t be panicking.”
Justification: The claim was not made by a climate change expert. Research shows that for a decade, the Earth’s temperature has likely been the hottest in the past 125,000 years.
Sources: Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Pregnant women getting the Tdap vaccine “voluntarily are quite literally the experiment.”
Justification: Researchers have studied thousands of pregnant women who got the Tdap vaccine, which aims to prevent tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis, aka whooping cough. The vaccine is recommended for pregnant women by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
Sources: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Journal of the American Medical Association
Journal of the American Medical Association Pediatrics

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The phone President Richard Nixon used to talk to the first astronauts on the moon is evidence the 1969 moon landing was faked.
Justification: The moon landing was real. The photo of the phone President Richard Nixon used to call the astronauts belies the technology used to make that communication happen.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "U.N. calls for decriminalizing sex with minors.”
Justification: The International Commission of Jurists published a set of legal principles in March about applying a human rights-based approach to criminal law on matters involving sex, reproduction and other areas. It did not call for decriminalizing adults having sex with minors, nor does it mention the topic. A U.N. official and human rights experts said the principle being wrongly characterized refers to applying criminal law to similarly aged adolescents in which one may be under the legal age of consent.
Sources: U.N. Committee on the Rights of the Child
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Dr. Anthony Fauci “admits that mask mandates were a broad spectrum failure.”
Justification: A tweet took a quote from Dr. Anthony Fauci out of context. Fauci did not say that mask mandates as part of the COVID-19 response were a failure. Mask mandates were not discussed in the article in which he was quoted. Fauci said masks have life-saving potential.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Brain aneurysms are a “serious and common COVID-19 mRNA vaccine injury in young people.”
Justification: There is no evidence that the COVID-19 mRNA vaccines cause brain aneurysms. Risk factors for brain aneurysms include certain inherited disorders, untreated high blood pressure, cigarette smoking and drug abuse.
Sources: Intracranial aneurysm rupture within three days after receiving mRNA anti-COVID-19 vaccination: Three case reports
National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Kobe Bryant was killed “as a setup to stop him from testifying.”
Justification: The National Transportation Safety Board investigated the helicopter crash that resulted in Kobe Bryant’s death and concluded the pilot became disoriented flying among clouds and crashed.
Sources: U.S. Patent Office and Trademark case 91233646

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Scientists struggle to understand why Antarctica hasn’t warmed for over 70 years despite rise in CO2."
Justification: A scientific study examined how Antarctica’s high elevation and mountains help insulate the continent from climate change’s effects at a much slower rate compared with the rest of the world. The study has been used out of context to deny human-driven climate change’s existence. Recent studies have shown the continent is warming.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “U.S. military is now testing soldiers for AIDS, after DOD database reports 500% increase in HIV since the COVID vaccine rollout.”
Justification: We found no evidence that COVID-19 vaccines caused a 500% increase in HIV infections among U.S. military personnel. COVID-19 vaccines became widely available to adults in 2021. The rate of newly diagnosed HIV infections among service members did not change from 2017 to 2021, according to the Congressional Research Service.
