He initiated the peaceful transition of power to the incoming administration.• Brazil’s election was free and fair, according to independent electoral observers, who also said the nation’s electronic voting machines were "secure, trustworthy, and credible."
Sources: An official statement from the Supreme Court of Brazil

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: McDonald's uses potatoes sprayed with a highly toxic pesticide called Monitor.
Justification: Vegetables and fruits are routinely sprayed with pesticides to kill off harmful insects. The Environmental Protection Agency requires that pesticides won’t harm children and adults who eat food treated with it. Trace amounts of pesticides are occasionally found on vegetables and fruits, but not at unsafe levels. The U.S. ended all uses of the pesticide Monitor in 2009.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “If outer space was a vacuum, astronauts would train in vacuum chambers. Not in swimming pools. Outer Space is a hoax.”
Justification: Vacuum chambers are used in limited training for astronauts. Simulations take place inside vacuum chambers and underwater in swimming pools, according to NASA. Astronauts train in vacuum chambers to understand pressure changes in outer space. They train in swimming pools to experience a microgravity environment.
Sources: NASA Johnson Space Center Official YouTube Account

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Joe Biden announced to the world tonight that they are going to cheat by dumping ballots.”
Justification: Joe Biden urged Americans to be patient as all legitimate ballots are counted in races in the midterm elections. He didn’t say Democrats will dump ballots.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “It’s not that there is no evidence the election was stolen, but that no court had the guts to HEAR the evidence. They dismissed the cases, NOT the evidence.”
Justification: Election security officials have said the 2020 presidential election was secure and post-election audits in various states found no evidence of widespread fraud. Post-election lawsuits were thrown out for jurisdictional or procedural reasons, but several judges also said the Trump campaign’s allegations of election fraud lacked sufficient proof. A group of prominent conservatives examined 64 cases brought by Trump and his allies and found that 30 included a hearing on the case’s merits. Trump and his allies won only one case, and it involved too few votes to impact the results, the group found.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “If you use the US Postal Service certified mail or registered mail, they can do anything they want with those ballots." They “can burn your mail and they won't get in any trouble.”
Justification: The U.S. Postal Service is the country's only mail service and was established in 1970 as an independent government agency. Postal Service employees are prohibited by federal law from tampering with or destroying any election mail, including ballots. Around 99% of mail-in ballots are sent to election officials on time.
Sources: U.S. Postal Service 2021 Post-election analysis: Timely and secure delivery of the nation’s election mail

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California state Sen. Scott Wiener “doesn’t just want to sterilize California kids, but sterilization of kids everywhere!”
Justification: Senate Bill 107, also known as the gender-affirming health care bill, wassigned by California Gov. Gavin Newsomon Sept. 29 and will officially become law Jan. 1, 2023. It does not call for the sterilization of children. The legislation is meant to protect transgender youth and their families who seek refuge in California after fleeing states that have banned gender-affirming health care for youths.
Sources: Emailed statement from Calif. Sen. Scott Wiener via spokesperson
Press release from Office of Calif. Sen. Scott Wiener

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: California’s Proposition 1 includes “a right to abortion up-to-birth.”
Justification: If passed by voters, the constitutional amendment would not change existing state laws, which already outline when abortions can be performed. Under current California law, abortion is legal until viability, which is when a fetus can survive outside the womb. That occurs around 24 to 26 weeks of pregnancy. After that, an abortion is allowed only if the mother’s life or health are in danger. If passed, Proposition 1 could be challenged in court, but experts say it’s unlikely that courts would rule to remove limits on abortion.
Sources: State Guide to Abortion in California

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Brazil’s presidential election was “stolen.”
Justification: Brazil’s presidential election wasn’t stolen. Incumbent President Jair Bolsonaro has told his supporters to stop protesting the contest’s results and his chief of staff said the transition of power will happen.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Julie Powell died from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: There is no evidence to suggest that Julie Powell died after receiving a COVID-19 vaccine. Eric Powell, her husband, has said publicly she died of cardiac arrest.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Proposed Senate bill would give FDA power to approve dietary supplements and “ban herbs.”
Justification: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration regulates the dietary supplement industry, but does not approve products before they hit the market. A U.S. Senate bill would require companies to provide information about their products to the FDA, which would use the information to create an online database for consumers. The bill does not grant the FDA the power to approve new products before they come to market, or any new regulatory powers over dietary supplements.
Sources: Sen. Dick Durbin speech on Senate floor

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The COVID-19 vaccine caused Katy Perry’s eye to close during a recent show.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support claims that Katy Perry’s eye closed in a recent concert because of the COVID-19 vaccine.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “There are no greenhouse gas emissions in this photo” of cows grazing.
Justification: Cattle, and all mammals, produce methane, nitrous oxide and carbon dioxide, which are all greenhouse gases. Cattle and other grass-chewing animals with hooves and multichambered stomachs  — called ruminants — produce significant amounts of methane.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Marjorie Taylor Greene planted pipe bombs at Republican and Democratic party headquarters on Jan. 5, 2021.
Justification: The FBI is investigating an incident from Jan. 5, 2021, when video showed an unidentified suspect placing two pipe bombs in front of the Republican National Convention and Democratic National Convention offices. Investigators have named no suspects, but confirmed the investigation is ongoing. They have released video and a map showing what they believe to have been the suspect’s path. In a separate court case that dealt with Greene’s activities relating to Jan. 6, 2021, a judge wrote that the evidence was insufficient to establish that Greene "engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the same, or (gave) aid or comfort to the enemies thereof under the 14th Amendment to the Constitution."
Sources: Email interview with FBI National Press Office

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Australian officials “are giving cows mRNA vaccines."
Justification: There are currently no mRNA vaccines being used on livestock in Australia. Officials in New South Wales said they are prioritizing development of mRNA vaccines for livestock to prevent foot-and-mouth disease and lumpy skin disease. Those are expected to be introduced in August 2023.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A Phoenix TV station aired the election results more than a week early.
Justification: A Phoenix television station accidentally aired a graphic that appeared to show it calling the election in favor of Democratic gubernatorial candidate Katie Hobbs. The numbers were randomly generated mock election results released by The Associated Press as part of a system test.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo shows Stanford scientists' "3D model of how Joseph, the husband of Mary the Mother of Jesus Christ, might have looked.”
Justification: This 3D rendering was made in 2019 and uploaded to an online 3D image gallery host site. The image shows Andre Rene Roussimof, a French former professional wrestler and actor known as Andre the Giant. We find no evidence the image is linked to Stanford University.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “DISGRUNTLED EX-EMPLOYEE? Twitter CEO Elon Musk's account is presently suspended.”
Justification: Elon Musk’s Twitter account was not suspended by a disgruntled ex-employee. An account that bears similar spelling as Musk’s Twitter handle was suspended.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The documentary “2,000 Mules proves” Democrats “cheated on the 2020 elections.”
Justification: A documentary film by a right-wing commentator alleged massive voter fraud involving ballot drop boxes and cellphone location data. Experts said the movie is based on a flawed analysis. William Barr, who served as attorney general during the Trump administration, has said the cellphone data revealed nothing at all. Convictions related to the use of ballot drop boxes are extremely rare.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: DJ Mighty Mouse died because of a COVID-19 booster vaccine.
Justification: There’s no credible evidence that Matthew Ward, aka DJ Mighty Mouse, died because he received a COVID-19 booster vaccine in April. His record label said he died of an aortic aneurysm.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There were two shooters in the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting.
Justification: Las Vegas police and the FBI investigated the deadly 2017 shooting on the Las Vegas Strip and found that Stephen Paddock acted alone. A video showing a strobing light as gunfire can he heard doesn’t prove there was a second gunman.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "In Germany, millions of solar panels are blanketed in snow and 30,000 wind turbines are sitting idle because there’s no wind.”
Justification: Weather conditions can reduce the output of renewable energy sources, but neither snow nor wind significantly hampered Germany’s energy sources. The claim originated in February 2021 and was previously debunked by Agence France-Presse.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Eagles fans shout F— Joe Biden while Jill Biden attends NFL game!”
Justification: The clip of first lady Jill Biden at an Oct. 16 Philadelphia Eagles football game was altered to add expletive-filled crowd chants. The real footage showed Biden and others singing along to the team’s fight song.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The "Department of Homeland Security and the State Department coordinated with a group called the ‘Election Integrity Partnership’ to censor Joe Biden’s opponents.”
Justification: The Election Integrity Partnership, composed of researchers, worked with government agencies, civilian groups and social media platforms to counter mis- and disinformation during the 2020 election cycle. The partnership focused on claims intended to suppress voting, reduce participation, confuse voters or delegitimize election results. The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, which is part of the Department of Homeland Security, partnered with the project on election misinformation claims. But in practice, no one from CISA sent examples of misinformation to the partnership, and the partnership sent no reports to social media companies on the agency’s behalf. The Global Engagement Center, which is part of the U.S. State Department, also partnered with the project. But the Global Engagement Center is focused on foreign propaganda, and less than 1% of the claims investigated by the partnership involved foreign actors.
Sources: University of Washington Center for an Informed Public

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video shows an actor “getting into character before his press interview less than 24 hours after the supposed killing of his 6-year-old daughter."
Justification: This parent of a Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting victim isn’t an actor.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Millions” of people from International Monetary Fund member countries are at risk of being placed in “COVID camps.”
Justification: There is no evidence of quarantine camps set up around the world that will ultimately "execute" private citizens, as Alex Jones claims. Quarantine camps have been established in some regions of China, but they do not function in the manner Jones implies in the video

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Ukraine has a nuclear bomb primed in Mykolaiv.”
Justification: Ukraine does not have a nuclear bomb or a "dirty bomb," according to experts and watchdogs. The country used to have Soviet-era nuclear weapons but returned them to Russia after the Soviet Union collapsed. Ukraine also dismantled or destroyed its nuclear missiles and silos. Its nuclear materials are now used for peaceful purposes.
Sources: A joint statement by the foreign ministers of France
Email exchange with a BBC Monitoring spokesperson
United States Department of Homeland Security

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Mailing in a ballot “gives the bad guys a chance to know how many ballots they need to make.”
Justification: Washington implemented statewide vote-by-mail in 2011. There is no history of widespread voter fraud in Washington linked to this voting method. Completed ballots can be returned through the mail or dropped off at specific locations. A Washington election official said there are security measures in place to identify if people have voted more than once or if they’re ineligible to vote.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There’s a “coincidental correlation” between COVID-19 vaccines and a spike in cancer in adults younger than 50.
Justification: A recent study showed an increase in early onset cancer — cases diagnosed in adults ages 20 to 49. The data analyzed in the study was collected from 2000 to 2012 from 44 countries, involving 14 types of cancers. COVID-19 vaccines, which rolled out in early 2021, do not cause cancer, health experts say.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “California sets their own forest fires and claims them as climate change effects.”
Justification: This video shows a helitorch — an aerial ignition device attached to a helicopter that firefighters use to combat or prevent forest fires.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "When electric cars get in accidents, they explode, they catch fire very very badly because of the lithium batteries.”
Justification: Tesla, which makes more than half of the electric vehicles sold in the U.S., reports five car fires per billion miles driven, compared with 55 fires per billion miles driven in gasoline-powered cars. Electric vehicles are not more likely than gas-powered cars to catch fire in crashes. Electric vehicles don’t use lithium batteries, but the much safer lithium-ion batteries.
Sources: Email interview with Chief Energy Storage Engineer at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory Ahmad Pesaran

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Boston University CREATES a new COVID strain that has an 80% kill rate.”
Justification: Boston University researchers created a new COVID-19 strain by adding a spike protein from the original omicron variant to the original virus strain. Their goal was studying whether the mutated spike protein from the omicron variant of SARS-CoV-2 was the reason omicron was more able to evade immunity, but less deadly than earlier COVID strains. The new strain, called Omi-S, killed 80% of infected mice. By comparison, the original strain killed 100% of the mice, while omicron killed none.
Sources: Boston University National Emerging Infectious Diseases Laboratories
Boston University’s National Emerging Infectious Diseases Laboratories study
U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Premature babies are at a much higher risk of injury from immunizations than full-term babies.”
Justification: Vaccines are safe for both premature and full-term infants. Premature and underweight infants are at a higher risk of developing complications from vaccine-preventable diseases if their vaccinations are delayed.
Sources: Journal of Paediatrics and Child Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Nancy Pelosi (purchased) 10,000 shares of Amgen, manufacturer of Nplate, a drug used to treat radiation sickness.”
Justification: Required financial disclosures show no record of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., purchasing stock in the U.S. drug manufacturer Amgen. Pelosi’s staff said the claim is false.
Sources: Clerk of the House of Representatives

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video shows that a “Nuremberg 2.0 crimes against humanity trial starts Jan 2023.”
Justification: There’s no evidence that a "crimes against humanity" trial is starting in January 2023. The Nuremberg Code includes the principle that humans should not be involuntarily subjected to medical experiments. COVID-19 vaccinations are not a violation of the code.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Ballots are “mailed unconstitutionally” to every voter in Colorado.
Justification: Colorado’s constitution says elections must be conducted by ballot, but it does not specifically address voting by mail. In Colorado, election officials mail ballots to every registered, active voter in the weeks leading up to an election. State law dictates procedures for voting by mail. Voting by mail is secure and has been used in Colorado for years; it is not unconstitutional, experts said.
Sources: Cornell Law School’s Legal Information Institute
Email interview with Douglas M. Spencer

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hillary Clinton talking about a glass dome over the Earth.
Justification: In her 2016 speech conceding the presidential election to Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton talked about the "glass ceiling" women encounter in society. She wasn’t talking about a dome over our planet. Some people who believe the Earth is flat think a dome over us exists.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Bodybuilder died from the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: Bodybuilder Doug Brignole posted on Facebook in April 2021 about getting vaccinated against COVID-19, urging skeptics to use him as an example of the vaccine’s safety. Brignole died Oct. 13 at age 62. The Los Angeles County Medical Examiner-Coroner’s office confirmed Oct. 24 that Brignole died of a COVID-19 infection. It listed atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease as a "significant condition" that contributed to, but didn’t cause, his death.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Today’s high food prices were planned during a 2015 food shortage simulation.
Justification: In 2015, 65 international researchers, policymakers, business leaders and others participated in a simulation called "Food Chain Reaction: A Global Food Security Game." The game simulated a real-world global food crisis and had participants work together to best respond. Lessons learned were shared in a report in hopes of helping decision-makers prevent and address potential food shortages. Current high food prices and instability are driven by inflation, Russia’s war in Ukraine and other factors, not anything that happened in this simulation.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Haitian singer Mikaben died because of the COVID-19 vaccine
Justification: No evidence Mikaben died because of the COVID-19 vaccine.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A House Republican plan says that if the GOP wins the majority, “Retirees who have a pension, IRAs, 401k, disabled veteran benefits will be ineligible for Social Security benefits.”
Justification: • The screenshot is fake and does not align with language in the actual House Republican plan as published online.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: COVID was "so bad one year, they just forgot to give us a hurricane? What’s really going on here.”
Justification: Hurricanes are formed when humid air flows upward in a low-pressure zone over warm ocean water. That water is then released from the air, and as it rises, the air rotates in a circular motion. The pandemic-era hurricane seasons of 2020 and 2021 marked the first and third most active Atlantic seasons on record, respectively, according to the National Hurricane Center.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The diphtheria vaccine is a “poison dart” with side effects worse than the symptoms of diphtheria.
Justification: Diphtheria was a common cause of death among children in the United States in the 1920s. A vaccine was introduced in the 1940s, and the illness has now been almost completely eradicated in the U.S. Severe adverse reactions to the current version of the DTaP vaccine are rare.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Dr. Anthony Fauci admitting “he failed Americans during the pandemic when unnecessarily forcing masks.”
Justification: In a recent interview, Dr. Anthony Fauci reflected on his recommendation early in the coronavirus pandemic for most people to not wear masks. "If I had to do it over again, of course, I would have analyzed it a little bit better," he said. He wasn’t talking about his regrets in "forcing masks."
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Pfizer executive “admits” vaccine was never tested for preventing transmission.
Justification: Pfizer did not claim that a clinical trial for its COVID-19 vaccine was testing whether the vaccine prevented transmission of the coronavirus to other people. The aim of the drug trial was to study whether the vaccine was safe and if it prevented disease from SARS-CoV-2. Details of Pfizer’s clinical trial for its COVID-19 vaccine have been available online since November 2020. When the U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced in December 2020 its emergency use authorization for the Pfizer vaccine, the agency said there was no data available on whether the shot prevented transmission from person to person.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with Dr. Amesh Adalja
Email interview with Dr. Monica Gandhi
The New England Journal of Medicine

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: In Arizona, early voting would allow Kari Lake’s opponents to see how many votes they “need to fake to catch up and surpass.”
Justification: Many social media users have urged voters in multiple states including Arizona to cast ballots in person on Election Day rather than by mail or early. This strategy is born out of falsehoods that voting by mail or early leads to widespread fraud. The majority of voters in Arizona cast ballots early. Results become available starting at 8 p.m. local time election night. Although data shows how many Democrats, Republicans and other voters have cast ballots, we don’t know how many voted for any candidate.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Seattle authorities are investigating a string of serial killings.
Justification: Both the Seattle Police Department and King County Sheriff’s Office said they are not investigating serial killings.
Sources: Email interview with Det. Patrick Michaud

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows gunfire in Venezuela.
Justification: This video was taken in Brazil, not Venezuela.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A study showed mRNA COVID-19 vaccines are harmful to infants who are breastfeeding.
Justification: A study of 11 breastfeeding women who had recently been vaccinated found traces of mRNA COVID-19 vaccines in breast milk samples from five of the participants up to 45 hours after vaccination. Researchers recommended further study, but concluded that "it is safe to breastfeed after maternal COVID-19 vaccination." They said that until further studies are done "caution is warranted" when breastfeeding children younger than 6 months in the first 48 hours after maternal vaccination.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Email interview with Dr. Nazeeh Hanna
Journal of the American Medical Association (Pediatrics)

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows paratroopers crashing in Uganda.
Justification: This happened in Honduras in September, not Uganda in October.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “No plane debris was found at the Pentagon.”
Justification: There was clear evidence, including plane debris onsite, that an airplane crashed into the Pentagon on 9/11. More than 180 people died at the Pentagon that day.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A CNN report on 9/11 proved that a plane never hit the Pentagon.
Justification: A CNN report from 9/11 was misleadingly edited, with the reporter’s words taken out of context. The former CNN reporter featured in the clip, Jamie McIntyre, responded to the conspiracy theory in 2015 to debunk it.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Footage NASA shared from the DART spacecraft just before it crashed itself into an asteroid isn’t real.
Justification: NASA’s Double Asteroid Redirection Test spacecraft, also known as DART, intentionally struck the asteroid Dimorphos on Sept. 26. DART transmitted images back to earth as it approached the asteroid. The final partial image was sent just one second before impact. NASA compiled the images into a short video clip that has been shared widely on social media and in news reports.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Queen Elizabeth shot dead in Detroit.”
Justification: Queen Elizabeth II "died peacefully" at Balmoral Castle in Scotland, U.K. on Sept. 8, according to officials from the royal family. There’s no evidence that the queen has been anywhere near Detroit in years.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Hurricane Ian was orchestrated as part of a pandemic-related conspiracy to devastate Floridians.
Justification: Similar to all hurricanes that have come before, Hurricane Ian was real, and was not part of a government plan to harm Floridians.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows an "invasion of crocodiles" that has flooded the beaches of Brazil and caused residents to panic.
Justification: The Pantanal is the world’s largest wetland that stretches across Brazil, Bolivia and Paraguay. It’s nowhere near a beach with open seawater. Yacare caiman is a species of reptile related to alligators that are native to the Pantanal. Large groups of caiman commonly bask together in the sun. Crocodiles are native to northern South America and are not found in Brazil.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Russia is becoming the first country to break ties with the Antarctic Treaty."
Justification: Russia is still listed as a member of the Antarctic Treaty, a decades-old agreement that facilitates global cooperation for the purposes of conducting scientific research in and around Antarctica. Russia was reported to have received a cold reception from member nations at a May 2022 conference on the treaty, but there is no indication it has announced any plans to withdraw. There is no evidence there is a secret civilization beneath Antarctica, as a TikTok video suggests.
Sources: British Antarctic Survey and the Natural Environment Research Council

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “America now has a government that forbids border agents from using deadly force, but is training IRS agents to use SWAT-team tactics on law-abiding citizens.”
Justification: Border Patrol agents may use deadly force if they believe there is danger of death or severe injury to themselves or another person, according to the U.S. Customs and Border Protection’s use-of-force policy. IRS special agents in the agency’s Criminal Investigation division train with tactical gear and breaching equipment, but the agency’s policy is to let other specially trained agencies lead if a raid is deemed "high-risk." IRS special agents do not handle routine audits that most Americans face. They investigate a variety of financial crimes, including money laundering and fraud.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "$12 billion more for Ukraine on top of $100+ billion while Jackson, Mississippi has yet to receive any funding to fix their water infrastructure."
Justification: When the Instagram post was shared, Congress was considering legislation that included $20 million in funding for Jackson, Mississippi’s water infrastructure. The legislation passed Sept. 30. Much more funding will be needed to completely address the problems in Jackson.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Florida schools (were) still open during the start of the hurricane."
Justification: The video in the post is of a Texas school in 2019, not a Florida school during Hurricane Ian.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Martha’s Vineyard "used the military to deport every last illegal migrant from their island.”
Justification: A group of about 50 immigrants who arrived in Martha’s Vineyard were relocated to a military base on nearby Cape Cod. Deportations are carried out by U.S. Customs and Immigration Enforcement, not the military. The military was not involved in the transport to the Cape Cod base, the head of a civil rights group representing the immigrants said. They are not being detained.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Supreme Court just voted to ban condoms.”
Justification: The U.S. Supreme Court has not issued any rulings that ban the use of condoms or other contraceptives.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Father danced for his daughter at her grave after she was killed during recent protests in Iran.
Justification: The video of a man dancing has been circulating online since at least 2021. It does not depict a scene in Iran this year.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Defibrillators are being installed all over” the U.K. after a child’s death, which may be “why the UK suddenly stopped” COVID-19 vaccination for children under 11 years old.
Justification: An 18-year-old man died of sudden cardiac arrest Jan. 1, and his family blamed his death on the lack of access to a defibrillator and a long wait for an ambulance. The man’s family raised money to have 20 outdoor defibrillators installed in Rugby, England. There’s no widespread effort to install defibrillators across the United Kingdom, but there are efforts to show people where they are located. The U.K. has not stopped giving COVID-19 vaccines to all children ages 5 to 11. There are eligibility restrictions, however.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “CDC says 60% of Americans have parasites.”
Justification: Evidence does not support the claim that 60% of Americans are infected with a parasite.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Hillary Clinton dressed as a space cult leader in a satanic ritual.
Justification: A video of Hillary Clinton at a costume party has been taken out of context and described as showing "Satan worshippers."

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Astronaut Karen Nyberg filmed what “was supposedly a video from space” in front of a green screen.
Justification: This isn’t a video of retired NASA astronaut Karen Nyberg. It was created by the host of a Flat Earth podcast.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A royal guard member collapsed because of the COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: There’s no evidence to support the claim that a royal guard member standing by Queen Elizabeth II’s casket fainted because of the COVID-19 vaccine. It’s not uncommon for the guards, who must stand still for hours, to faint.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos show Queen Elizabeth II was a “Luciferian.”
Justification: She was a Christian and the supreme governor of the Church of England. Photos show a young Queen Elizabeth II participating in a cultural festival in Wales, not a Luciferian rite.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows “Italians take down an EU flag and replace it with an Italian flag” after the 2022 national election.
Justification: The video is from 2013 and features neo-fascists in Italy tearing down the European Union flag. It is unrelated to the 2022 Italian election.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Walrus seen on Florida streets after Hurricane Ian hits land."
Justification: The video is from 2020 and shows an elephant seal that got stranded in a coastal neighborhood in Puerto Cisnes, Chile.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “All weather is artificially controlled.”
Justification: Hurricane Ian is not a man-made, artificially controlled storm.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Joe Biden appointed a 'satanist' to the White House.
Justification: Dr. Demetre Daskalakis is a Harvard-educated public health advocate and an expert in LGBTQ health issues whose career in medicine spans more than 20 years. Daskalakis shared pictures of himself on Instagram wearing a leather harness in the design of a pentagram. Daskalakis and the CDC said he is not a satanist.
Sources: Email interview with CDC spokesman Paul Fulton

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “There are giant human caucasian skeletons in Ohio that predate any known civilizations.”
Justification: PolitiFact found no corroborated evidence suggesting that ancient, giant human skeletons were found in Ohio. Historical claims that giant skeletons were unearthed in Ohio have been fueled by tall tales that were later contradicted.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Prince was sacrificed for (Queen Elizabeth II’s) 90th birthday.”
Justification: The musician Prince died because of an accidental fentanyl overdose. His death had no connection to Queen Elizabeth II.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A BBC radio station resumed playing dance music after announcing Queen Elizabeth II had died.
Justification: All radio programming in the United Kingdom was suspended following news that Queen Elizabeth II died. A BBC station didn’t resume playing dance music.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The National Institutes of Health “adds ivermectin to list of COVID approved treatments.”
Justification: Ivermectin appears on a list of drugs being evaluated to treat COVID-19, but the National Institutes of Health isn’t recommending people use it.
Sources: Emailed statement from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Only 325,000 American kids out of 19,000,000" were vaccinated against COVID-19.
Justification: In the United States, about 30 million children ages 6 months to 17 years old have received at least one COVID-19 vaccine dose, according to data from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. More than 20 million kids ages 5 to 17 have completed their primary vaccine series. About 325,000children ages 6 months to 4 years old were fully vaccinated as of mid-September. And U.S. Census Bureau data showed that there were about 18.8 million children younger than 5 in the U.S. as of July 1, 2021.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Breaking: Judiciary Democrats just voted to support non-citizens voting in our elections.”
Justification: A Democratic representative proposed a bill to make it easier for elections officials to provide ballots and other election materials to eligible voters who are not proficient in English. A Republican amendment said the bill should not be construed to allow noncitizens to vote in a federal election. All the votes in favor of the amendment came from Republicans; all the votes against came from Democrats. But a vote against the amendment isn’t a vote to let noncitizens vote in federal elections — that’s already banned in federal law. Whether noncitizens can vote in nonfederal elections is up to states and local municipalities.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Martha’s Vineyard “deported 50 illegals after only 24 hours.”
Justification: Deportations occur when people are removed from the United States and sent back to their country of origin or, in some cases, to a third country. The approximately 50 migrants who were flown to the island of Martha’s Vineyard in Massachusetts were not removed from the United States. Local governments and municipalities cannot carry out deportations, according to a legal expert.
Sources: Email interview with Monika Y. Langarica

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: ‘The White House is now trying to protect Joe Biden by changing the definition of the word recession.'
Justification: • The White House blog post cited in the Instagram post is not only accurate about what the official definition of a recession is, but it’s also citing the longstanding definition, not something the White House suddenly cooked up as cover.
Sources: Email interview with Ryan D. Ratcliff
Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Actor Tom Holland is “confirmed to have died.”
Justification: There is no evidence that actor Tom Holland died.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Electric cars in California are not sustainable as only 10% of their batteries are recyclable and the state can’t recycle them.
Justification: There are five facilities in the United States dedicated to recycling electric car batteries as it’s still a relatively new industry. Observers say this is not an obstacle to recycling lithium-ion batteries, however. One electric car battery recycling method can recover up to 95% of its materials.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There’s an unlimited supply of water being generated “deep within the Earth.”
Justification: There is not an unlimited supply of water being produced underneath the Earth’s surface. Groundwater derived from rainfall and melted snow and ice is stored in natural underground aquifers. Aquifers can be found from 10 feet to several thousands of feet under the Earth’s surface. It’s unknown where Earth’s water originated, but a widely accepted theory is that it came from ice brought to the planet by asteroids and comets billions of years ago.
Sources: United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Plankton in the Atlantic Ocean is 90% gone."
Justification: The study cited by the Instagram post has not been peer-reviewed Marine biologists and oceanographers have not observed any dramatic reduction in the plankton population in the Atlantic Ocean or anywhere else. If a large portion of plankton died off, it would have a disastrous effect on ocean life.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: R. Kelly “missing after prison security verify he’s escaped beneath facility.”
Justification: R. Kelly didn’t escape prison. He was recently moved from a federal detention facility in New York to one in Chicago where he awaits another criminal trial.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Biden giving the "same exact speech" months apart.
Justification: Although the speeches highlighted in the Instagram post bear some similarities, they’re not identical and were not delivered months apart. The speeches were delivered two days apart, and the post omitted where they diverged.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Biden is adding more IRS agents to investigate your taxes than we have detectives investigating every crime in the country.”
Justification: The $750 billion Inflation Reduction Act signed into law Aug. 16 earmarks about $80 billion for the IRS to hire as many as 87,000 employees. But how it uses that money is not finalized. The funding comes as an estimated 50,000 IRS workers are expected to retire over the next five or six years. The most recent data from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that there were about 107,890 detectives and investigators in the U.S. in 2021.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Biden admits $5 gas is being done on purpose” and “this has been his plan all along.”
Justification: During a May press conference, President Joe Biden talked about the United States’ high gasoline prices but didn’t say he planned them.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Jane Goodall’s comments about population growth at World Economic Forum show COVID-19 pandemic was planned.
Justification: Goodall has spoken about unchecked human population growth’s effects on the environment for at least two decades. And COVID-19 had already been circulating in China before her 2020 remarks at the World Economic Forum in Davos. There’s no evidence that the COVID-19 pandemic was planned, and two recent studies back the prevailing view that the virus jumped from animals to humans at a live market in China. The pandemic has killed nearly 6.4 million people worldwide, but the population is still growing and is expected to reach 8 billion people this November.
Sources: Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Starbucks just announced that they’re going cashless.”
Justification: A sign from a Starbucks cafe in the United Kingdom announcing it was going cashless started rumors that the entire company was eschewing cash. But that’s not right.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Instagram’s "precise location" feature can be used by criminals to target victims.
Justification: Instagram’s "precise location" setting is used for optional location tags and map features, the company said. A location is not revealed to others unless users voluntarily tag the content with that information. Location services on Instagram are not new or part of an update. They were already installed on iPhones by Apple in 2020 and Androids by Google in 2021.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “China threatens to shoot Nancy Pelosi’s plane down if she visits Taiwan.”
Justification: •China’s government did not say it would shoot down House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s plane. The statement came from a commentator for a Chinese newspaper.•China’s government said Monday that its military would "not sit idly by" if Pelosi visits Taiwan.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Suggests root canals are linked to breast cancer.
Justification: •There is no medical evidence that root canals cause cancer, according to the American Association of Endodontists, American Dental Association and American Association for Dental, Oral, and Craniofacial Research.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Tennessee court rules “taxpayer-funded establishments can place signs that say ‘No Jews allowed.’”
Justification: A 2020 Tennessee law provides legal protections for religious adoption agencies that deny services based on religious or moral beliefs. A Jewish couple denied foster care training by a Christian group challenged the state law in a lawsuit. A three-judge panel dismissed the lawsuit, ruling that the couple lacked standing on several grounds. The panel did not rule on the law’s merits or constitutionality, and did not approve signs that say "No Jews allowed."
Sources: Americans United for the Separation of Church and State
Chancery Court for the state of Tennessee 20th Judicial District
Holston United Methodist Home for Children

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Video shows Joe Biden sleeping at the Arab Conference in Saudi Arabia.
Justification: Biden appears to be listening at the summit, not sleeping.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Anne Heche was murdered by the illuminati because she was working on a movie about Jeffrey Epstein.
Justification: Anne Heche died from injuries sustained when the car she was driving crashed into a Los Angeles home and caught fire. She stars in a Lifetime movie about sex trafficking that’s scheduled to air in September, but it’s not about Jeffrey Epstein.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Congress just voted to exempt themselves from IRS auditing of their personal finances.”
Justification: Members of Congress are not exempt from IRS audits, nor did lawmakers recently pass a bill to grant themselves this immunity. The claim appears to have originated from a satirical Twitter account.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "AirPods are essentially microwaving your brain.”
Justification: Apple’s AirPods and similar wireless devices emit radiofrequency radiation, a kind of low-level electromagnetic field referred to as EMF, that most scientists say is harmless. The government sets limits for how much radiofrequency radiation products can emit, based on how much exposure is safe. Tests show AirPods fall well below that limit. Wireless earpieces emit far less radiation than the cellphones they’re often used with, experts say. And there’s no evidence that cellphone use can cause cancer in humans.
Sources: International Commission on Non-Ionizing Radiation Protection
National Institute of Environmental Health Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Marjorie Taylor Greene was raided by Joe Biden’s DOJ last night.”
Justification: Authorities and Marjorie Taylor Greene have said she was the target of swatting — not a DOJ raid.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Third grade reading scores in the USA help correctional institutions predict how many beds they'll need in the future."
Justification: Experts and previous reporting show that there is no basis for this claim, which has been recycled by politicians and others for years. Private prisons use inmate projections from state governments, not third grade reading scores, to project how much space they’ll need. For example, the Florida Department of Corrections measured their estimates for the future based on the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Sources: Email interview with spokesperson for the U.S. Department of Education
Email interview with the Florida Department of Corrections

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Moderna’s lawsuits against Pfizer-BioNTech shows COVID-19 vaccines were in the works before the pandemic started.
Justification: Moderna is suing Pfizer and BioNTech for patent infringement, alleging the rival companies used key parts of its mRNA technology to develop their COVID-19 vaccine. Moderna’s patents were filed between 2010 and 2016. Vaccines using mRNA technology date back to the 1990s, but the first-time mRNA vaccines were widely disseminated was to combat the spread of COVID-19. Scientists have also used mRNA technology to study other viruses including the flu, Zika and rabies.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Water-fueled car can travel from LA to NY on 22 gallons."
Justification: Late inventor Stanley Meyer claimed to have invented a means to convert water into usable fuel. But the process he detailed has never been supported by science, and physicists say it’s an impossibility.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was “faking being arrested” during an abortion-rights protest outside the Supreme Court.
Justification: Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez was arrested with other Democratic lawmakers during an abortion-rights demonstration outside the Supreme Court July 19. Ocasio-Cortez did not fake her arrest. She said on her Instagram story that those claims were false. She also addressed allegations that she pretended to be handcuffed.
Sources: Email correspondence with the Office of House Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez
Email correspondence with the Office of House Rep. Ayanna Pressley
Email correspondence with the Office of House Rep. Ilhan Omar
Email correspondence with the Office of House Rep. Jackie Speier
Email correspondence with the U.S. Capitol Police

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Nancy Pelosi and Democrats "want to turn 150 million Americans into felons overnight" with HR 1808.
Justification: The proposed assault weapons ban includes a grandfather provision that would allow current lawful owners of semi-automatic weapons to keep their guns and high-capacity magazines. It will prevent them from buying new ones. National surveys estimate that about 81 million U.S. adults own a firearm.
Sources: Giffords Law Center To Prevent Gun Violence

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The U.K. is no longer recommending the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 mRNA vaccine for pregnant women.
Justification: Outdated information from the United Kingdom government has been taken out of context to purport that pregnant women should not receive the COVID-19 vaccine. This information is based on a December 2020 report. At the time, there was limited research available on the vaccine’s effects during and after pregnancy. The U.K. government currently strongly recommends women who are pregnant or breastfeeding get vaccinated against COVID-19.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "If every person on earth just recycled, stopped using plastic straws, and drove an electric car, 100 corporations would still produce 70% of total global emissions."
Justification: 100 corporations are responsible for 71% of emissions related to fossil fuel and cement production, not 71% of total global emissions. Of the total emissions attributed to fossil fuel producers, companies are responsible for around 12% of the direct emissions; the other 88% comes from the emissions released from consumption of products.
Sources: Climate Accountability Institute and Carbon Disclosure Project

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: There is documentation of bull sharks in the Great Lakes.
Justification: •There’s no documentation of bull sharks in the Great Lakes, according to experts.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Antarctica has “an entrance to a different world” — a “mythic land” with green forests, giant animals, and “extraterrestrial technologies.”
Justification: Scientists know the Earth is not hollow, partly because its interior is denser than its surface. Elites are not trying to hide the North and South poles from the public — they’re visible in satellite images and can be visited by tourists. Life is impossible inside the Earth.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Image claims to show a list of "Republican members of Congress whose PPP loans were forgiven."
Justification: The U.S. Small Business Administration and Treasury Department started the Paycheck Protection Program in response to the coronavirus pandemic. The program offered loans to businesses affected by COVID-19 with money to pay up to eight weeks of payroll costs. Some companies used the money to rehire laid-off employees. Lawmakers are not barred from taking advantage of the program and Democratic and Republican politicians both received loans for their businesses.
Sources: Clerk of the House of Representatives

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A Texas GOP lawmaker recently introduced a bill that would allow the death penalty for women who have an abortion.
Justification: State Rep. Bryan Slaton, member of the Texas House of Representatives, introduced the bill in March 2021, not May 2022. That bill stipulated that it would criminalize abortion as homicide, which is punishable by death. The bill did not make it out of the committee process. Following the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade, Slaton has said that he plans to reintroduce the bill in the next legislative session.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Finnish Court rules sex with children is permitted.”
Justification: This isn’t true. Sex with children under 16 years old is illegal in Finland. A controversial 2018 court ruling about what constitutes rape prompted Finland to update and strengthen its child sex abuse laws. But the country has never ruled that sex with children is legal.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: News interview proves that the Buffalo, New York supermarket shooting was staged.
Justification: In a TV interview, a man who heard the shooting in Buffalo describes a feeling he had when he first saw the shooter. Someone off camera can be heard offering a word to capture what the man was describing: "intuition." But that’s not indication that the man was being directed on what to say, or that the shooting was staged.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "The Supreme Court ruled that border agents can enter anyone’s home within a 100-mile radius of the border without a warrant for any reason and federal courts cannot do anything about it."
Justification: While Border Patrol agents do have some unique permissions that allow access to vehicles and private land within a 100-mile radius from the border, Fourth Amendment protections still require agents to have probable cause before entering and searching a home. The Supreme Court case Egbert v. Boule deals with whether people whose constitutional rights have been violated can sue individual agents for monetary damages in federal court. The Supreme Court ruling in no way changes what Border Patrol agents can and cannot do.
Sources: Cornell Law School Legal Information Institute
Email Interview with James E Pfander

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Clintons and Bushes were “involved in orchestrating the assassination of JFK Jr.”
Justification: John F. Kennedy Jr. died in a plane crash in 1999. He wasn’t assassinated by the Clinton and Bush families.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: White supremacists are going to be “shooting up all Walmarts and will kill Blacks and Mexicans” in San Bernardino, California.
Justification: Police officials in San Bernardino and San Bernardino County say there are no credible threats about Walmart shootings there. San Bernardino Police say they were monitoring threats nationwide, not specific to the city or county. Copycat threats are common after mass shootings. There have been several recent threats made to other Walmart stores nationwide, but most have turned out to be false.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A reporter who covered the Buffalo supermarket shooting was a "crisis actor."
Justification: A local TV reporter for a station in Houston had his name misspelled when a report he filed from the scene of the Buffalo, New York, shooting was broadcast by a partner affiliate based in Orlando, Florida. The on-screen error is not proof that the reporter was a "crisis actor." The reporter, Brandon Walker, is a real reporter, and the shooting was not staged.
Sources: Email statement from WMKG assignment desk

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Hepatitis outbreak in kids may be related to Johnson & Johnson COVID-19 vaccine.
Justification: An outbreak of hepatitis in children has sickened dozens of children in at least 11 countries. Officials at the World Health Organization and the UK Health Security Agency said that COVID-19 vaccines are not a factor, as most of the children diagnosed with hepatitis are not vaccinated. The Johnson & Johnson vaccine has not been approved for anyone under 18.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Active shooter drill at high school in Uvalde, Texas, two months before the elementary school shooting shows the event was a false flag.
Justification: About 95% of schools nationwide drill students on active shooter lockdown procedures. It isn’t unusual that an active shooter training happened at Uvalde High School in March. Uvalde is a small town with a population of about 15,000 people. A gunman shot and killed a teacher who was married to a school district police officer, but there’s no evidence those circumstances are suspicious or indicative of a "false flag" attack.
Sources: Uvalde CISD Police Department Facebook post

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: According to International Olympic Committee data, “an average of 29 athletes under the age of 35 suffered sudden death per year from 1966 to 2004. From March 2021 to March 2022, 769 athletes have died or suffered cardiac arrest."
Justification: Scientific reviews, medical experts and sports cardiologists have found no association between sudden death in athletes and COVID-19 vaccines. Figures used to support the claim that there is a link are inconsistent and often include unconfirmed and incomplete reports that don’t confirm vaccination or involve any emergency episodes.
Sources: IOC story about study At the IOC in Lausanne: consensus meeting on "Sudden Death in Athletes"

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "In Iran, if a 12-year-old girl is raped and impregnated by her father, she must carry the baby to term, or be thrown in prison for life. Wait, sorry, no, That's Alabama."
Justification: •An Alabama abortion law that never went into effect specified that women receiving abortions would not be criminally or civilly punished. The law would have punished doctors who provided abortions.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Gavin Newsom reportedly intervened at the request of Nancy Pelosi and directly ordered the California Highway Patrol to drop all charges" against Paul Pelosi for his DUI arrest.
Justification: Paul Pelosi, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s husband, was arrested by the California Highway Patrol in late May on suspicion of driving under the influence after being involved in a two-car collision in Napa County. The highway patrol does not have the ability to file or dismiss charges, and Gov. Gavin Newsom has no involvement in Pelosi’s case. Charges have not been filed in the arrest, and the case remains under review by the Napa County District Attorney’s Office.
Sources: Archive of The Sly Show’s Tweet

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has amassed the “largest collection of human data in history” through COVID-19 PCR tests.
Justification: The Centers for Disease Prevention and Control, or CDC,tweetedthat "there’s a 10% chance" that people’s PCR tests were sent to laboratories across the country for genomic sequencing analysis. Genomic sequencing is a process that analyzes the genetic makeup of a virus to track its spread and understand how it mutates. Though swabs used for PCR tests contain human DNA, one of the first steps in the sequencing is to isolate the coronavirus genetic material from the rest of the sample.
Sources: U.S. Centers for Disease Prevention and Control

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Colloidal silver is “harmless” unless you’re allergic to it.
Justification: Colloidal silver is often promoted online for its medical benefits. But medical experts say there’s no evidence to support this and that colloidal silver could cause serious side effects.
Sources: National Center for Complementary and Integrative Health

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Disney CEO Bob Chapek was arrested for human trafficking.
Justification: The claim that Disney CEO Bob Chapek was arrested for human trafficking comes from a satire site called the Vancouver Times. It is not a real story.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: CNN tweeted about “brave children” in Ukraine signing up to fight Russia.
Justification: •The tweet was fabricated and did not originate with CNN.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said her country doesn’t have to deal with the “rage of older white men” because “we’ve never allowed Rupert Murdoch to set up a media outlet here.”
Justification: The quote is fabricated. A communications expert in New Zealand made a related comment to The Guardian in 2020, but even that quote is distorted in this social media post.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photo of injured Ukrainian woman was from 2018 Russia gas explosion.
Justification: Olena Kurilo, a teacher, was injured on Feb. 24, 2022, when a Russian missile strike hit her apartment complex in Chuhuiv, Ukraine. Her photograph was taken by at least three journalists that day and she was interviewed on video. Photos in news reports that day show the apartment complex is not the building damaged by a 2018 gas explosion in Russia.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: U.S. has biological weapons labs in Ukraine.
Justification: • China was echoing a false claim first made by Russia.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Members of Congress gave themselves a 21% pay raise
Justification: •Salaries did not increase for members of the U.S. Congress after the passage of a recent government spending bill. The salaries have not increased since 2009.•Members of the U.S. House of Representatives received an increase in their office budgets, which pay for staff and other official expenses.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Canada’s new law allows government to take children away if parents don’t accept kids’ ‘gender identity.’”
Justification: In 2017, Ontario lawmakers updated the province’s child welfare laws to include "gender identity" and "gender expression" as factors child protection workers should consider when determining the best interest of a child and whether they should be placed in foster care. Child protection workers cannot remove children from their families solely on the basis of a parent refusing to accept their child’s gender identity or expression. Only when there is proof of abuse or neglect can child protection workers intervene. The Canadian government is not involved in this process.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The Australian Technical Advisory Group on Immunisation advised that the COVID-19 vaccine may be given to patients under sedation for unrelated procedures without consent as a way to force compliance.
Justification: The Australian agency advised that people with anxiety disorders and needle phobias could get the vaccine under sedation under special circumstances, and only if they give informed consent beforehand. The purpose of the recommendation is to help people who have issues getting shots while awake. It’s not a tool to force vaccinations.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A CNN story reported that Rice Krispies added a transgender mascot.
Justification: Spokespeople from both CNN and Kellogg’s told PolitiFact that the image showing what looks like a CNN headline about a Rice Krispies character is fabricated. The company has made no change to its Rice Krispies characters, a spokesperson said.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Special Forces arrest Deep State Dr. Anthony Fauci."
Justification: •Dr. Anthony Fauci was not arrested.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Shinzo Abe was assassinated because he “didn’t mandate vaccines, sent 1.6 million doses back and gave citizens ivermectin.”
Justification: Police are still investigating the assassination of former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The shooter told investigators he wasn’t politically motivated and wanted to kill Abe because he believed Abe was linked to a group he resented, according to reports. Japan recalled some tainted Moderna COVID-19 shots in September 2021, but it continued vaccinating against COVID-19 and did not authorize using ivermectin to treat infections.
Sources: Japan Pharmaceuticals and Medical Devices Agency

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Gas in Canada is $9.00 a gallon.”
Justification: Gas is not $9 per gallon in Canada. The national average price was about $5.89 per gallon in U.S dollars as of June 22, or $7.66 per gallon in Canadian dollars.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A compilation of images shows what Joe Biden has “done to our country.”
Justification: A meme shared by conservative commentator Benny Johnson falsely claimed to show photos of "your stores," "your cities" and "your borders" under Joe Biden’s presidency. Those three photos were all taken either before Biden took office or outside of the U.S.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Images show the Ukrainian flag being replaced by the Soviet Union flag in Mariupol in 2022.
Justification: Iterations of the collage have been online since at least 2015 and appear to be screenshots of a video that shows pro-Russian forces taking control of the eastern Ukrainian city of Debaltseve. It’s unrelated to Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Plan B can cause an abortion. It’s right there on the box.”
Justification: Plan B, also known as the morning-after pill, and other emergency contraceptives do not cause abortions, medical experts say. The medication is known to be effective only before a pregnancy is established.
Sources: American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Vitamin D levels of 50 ng/mL correlates to zero mortality rate from COVID.”
Justification: Vitamin D intake at the 50 nanograms per milliliter level will not eliminate deaths related to COVID-19 entirely. A published meta-analysis and systematic review of eight quantitative studies on COVID-19 and vitamin D found a "theoretical" inverse relation between the hormone and the virus that resulted in zero mortality at the 50 ng/mL level. One of the authors of the study cited in the Instagram post told PolitiFact that he believes there is a clear correlation between vitamin D and successful COVID-19 outcomes, but that zero mortality is unachievable. The presence of high levels of vitamin D does appear to help patients with COVID-19.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Billie Eilish's younger sister has an OnlyFans account.
Justification: •Billie Eilish does not have a sister.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video shows “your packages were rerouted and have arrived in the port of Miami” as a result of Gov. Ron DeSantis.
Justification: Social media users claim that a video of a cargo ship entering the port of Miami came from California. There’s no evidence of the ship’s origins or that it was rerouted. Gov. Ron DeSantis has invited backed-up cargo ships to come to Fla., but there’s no recent data showing that it’s happened yet.
Sources: Phone interview with Edie Ousely spokesperson for Florida Ports Council

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “SHOCKING: In the wake of Austria’s drastic lockdown of unvaccinated people, EU chief calls for throwing out Nuremberg Code.”
Justification: •Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, did not say the Nuremberg Code should be disregarded and did not mention the treaty in a Dec. 1, 2021, press conference.•Von der Leyen called for a discussion about mandatory COVID-19 vaccination within the European Union, as a way to increase vaccination rates.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Tylenol "ruins your ability to kill” COVID-19.
Justification: Health officials have recommended the use of Tylenol and other fever-lowering medications to treat COVID-19 symptoms. Sometimes people can let a fever run its course, medical experts said, but it can be dangerous in certain situations. Tylenol can have serious side effects when taken in excess of the recommended dose.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Image from news broadcast shows a hospital in France trying to pass off a mannequin as a COVID-19 patient.
Justification: •The image has been altered and does not depict a real news story.•The photo of the mannequin was from a simulation that did not depict real events.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Photos show “sheep feces” that are “now in high demand in China because of their richness in protein.”
Justification: Several photos of bubble tea have been mischaracterized as showing "sheep feces" popular in China.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pays mainstream media $600 million to report in favor of him.”
Justification: Joking comments from a speech Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau gave in 2019 have been taken out of context, and some people are wrongly suggesting that he pays the media to report about him favorably.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Deaths from vaccines have totaled 1,621 from Johnson & Johnson, 4,799 from Moderna, 13,039 from Pfizer and 73 from unknown vaccines. And this is an undercount because “only 1% of deaths are reported.”
Justification: This claim cites the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System, which the CDC and FDA warn cannot be used on its own to verify if a vaccine has caused an event. It accepts reports before verifying them, and reports can usually contain information that may have errors or lacks details. When used properly, VAERS can detect true adverse health effects. The CDC confirmed six deaths following the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, which resulted from a rare but serious adverse reaction of thrombocytopenia syndrome, or blood clotting.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Electronic Support for Public Health-Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (ESP:VAERS)
Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System Summary

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says Vice President Kamala Harris called the unvaccinated “dirty Trump people.”
Justification: Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t call unvaccinated Americans "dirty Trump people" in a recent phone call with White House’s COVID-⁠19 Health Equity Task Force. Her spokesperson called the claim a fabrication and said Harris didn’t participate in any such call.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The CEO of Moderna deleted his Twitter and dumped $400 million of Moderna stock. Big Pharma seems to know some bad news is coming.”
Justification: In the first two weeks of February, Moderna CEO Stéphane Bancel sold just over $6 million worth of shares in his company’s stock. Bancel regularly sells stock at predetermined dates, as U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission regulations allow. Bancel deleted his Twitter account around Feb. 11. He rarely used the social media platform; his last tweets were from April 2019.
Sources: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission filing

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Arizona Department of Education gives green light on face mask and vaccine mandates, as well as implementing Critical (Race) Theory.”
Justification: The Arizona Supreme Court upheld a ruling that state laws banning mask mandates and the teaching of critical race theory in schools are unconstitutional. A Maricopa County judge had earlier ruled that state legislators violated the state constitution by adding these unrelated bills to a state budget bill. The Arizona Department of Education said it was passing along information about the ruling, and that it had no authority to give districts a green light to implement those policies.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The New York City Police Department arrested a 9-year-old "because she didn’t have a vaccine card in the museum."
Justification: •The 9-year-old was not arrested. She was escorted to the police station in a separate car from those who were arrested — a group which included her mother — and cared for by police officers until her mother was released.•The adults were arrested and charged with trespassing because they would not leave the museum after it closed.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Elon Musk to donate $250 billion for reparations to African Americans in U.S."
Justification: •The claim originated on a site that publishes satire.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "By declining the vax, I am 100% safe from adverse reactions and 99.8% safe from COVID."
Justification: The overall survival and fatality rate of COVID-19 in a given population should not be confused with an individual's chance of survival from the virus. The unvaccinated account for a majority of cases, hospitalizations and deaths in the United States. The COVID-19 vaccines have proven safe and effective in reducing the risk of infection and hospitalization.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Blue Cross Blue Shield pays your doctor a $40,000 bonus for fully vaccinating at least 100 patients under the age of two."
Justification: An Instagram post falsely claims that Blue Cross Blue Shield is paying pediatricians a bonus to vaccinate a percentage of patients in their practice, Providers are paid for overall performance in a number of services in addition to vaccines.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
U.S. Department of Health & Human Services

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Trudeau's foundation owns 40% of Acuitas Therapeutics which makes mechanic lipids for Pfizer."
Justification: The Pierre Elliott Trudeau Foundation does not own stock in Acuitas Therapeutics. Justin Trudeau was involved in the foundation from the time of its founding until 2014.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Children who receive COVID-19 vaccinations "will be walking factories of spike proteins" that will "undoubtedly cause illnesses to spread like wildfire in schools."
Justification: COVID-19 mRNA vaccines do not cause the body to continuously generate spike proteins in children or adults. Spike proteins produced by the body through vaccination are not infectious.
Sources: Peterson-Kaiser Family Foundation Health System Tracker
U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Vaccine Education Center at Children's Hospital of Philadelphia

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Says the FDA said that Pfizer “falsely misled” the agency about the safety of the COVID-19 vaccines and that the shots are killing more people than they save.
Justification: The FDA did not make the statements, and doesn’t agree with them. The claims were made by a public commenter named Steve Kirsch during a September FDA vaccine advisory committee meeting. Kirsch is a tech entrepreneur who has promoted misinformation about the vaccines. He has no medical background and is not affiliated with the FDA.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: The CDC finally admits its COVID-19 test can’t tell the difference between the virus and the flu
Justification: The CDC in July announced its intent to withdraw an emergency use request for a protocol for PCR testing for COVID-19. The withdrawal would become effective Dec. 31, 2021. But that was because of the need for efficiency. The original protocol only detected COVID-19, while newer tests that were already FDA authorized were able to also detect influenza.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “The convoy in Canada has made the Guinness Book of World Records for the longest convoy.”
Justification: A spokesperson for Guinness has said that the "Freedom Convoy" is not a contender. Guinness has strict requirements for how to achieve a Guinness title. The organization requires a number of pieces of evidence to verify the achievement, such as video and photographic evidence, witness statements, cover letters, and statements from stewards who have been tapped to supervise the record attempt. The Guinness World Record for longest truck parade was achieved in Egypt in 2020.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "Yale study: Vaccinated people more likely to be infected than those without the jab.”
Justification: A Danish study shows a sharp drop in vaccine effectiveness over time against the omicron variant of COVID-19 in people with two doses of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccine. But it also shows protection is quickly restored with a Pfizer booster dose. There was not enough data about a Moderna booster. The study’s authors said that their findings prove a need to ramp up vaccination and booster doses to fight the variant.
Sources: PolitiFact email interview with Astrid Blicher Schelde of the Statens Serum Institut

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: COVID-19 vaccines are gene therapy and a recent Forbes article proves that.
Justification: The original headline on a Forbes opinion column said "The Vaccine Changes your DNA. A little bit," but the author, a Johns Hopkins University gene expert, quickly changed it to "Covid Vaccines Don’t Alter Your DNA," after getting reaction from readers. The column itself attacks anti-vaccine activists and states that the vaccines do not alter DNA. The author told PolitiFact that he was trying to explain that  the mixture of DNA in the body is different after vaccination just as it is different after a viral infection.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “NASA hired 24 theologians to study human reaction to aliens.”
Justification: •NASA awarded a grant in 2015 to a nonprofit theological institute to study astrobiology, which is research into the origins of life on Earth and the search for life beyond Earth.•Those who worked on the project — including visiting scholars in theology, the humanities and social sciences — were not hired or employed by NASA.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: "National Guard to fill in for cops who refuse to get vaccinated."
Justification: Police officers across the United States are refusing to get the COVID-19 vaccine even as the virus has become the leading cause of death for members of law enforcement. Some officers have sued their cities over vaccine mandates and, in some cases, resigned their positions rather than get vaccinated. No state has brought in the National Guard to replace a city’s unvaccinated officers, but Illinois’ governor has offered to do so for Chicago.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Military data from 2021 show military members experienced spikes of 300% in miscarriages, almost 300% in cancer diagnoses and 1,000% in neurological issues.
Justification: An error in the Defense Medical Epidemiology Database gave the false impression that there was a huge spike in miscarriages, cancer and other medical issues among military members in 2021. The 2016-2020 numbers used to determine a five-year average were underreported, officials said. The database has been taken down to identify and correct the problem.

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Estimated annual COVID-19 deaths in the U.S. totals 27,530, after you subtract those who died “with, not from” COVID-19, not in nursing homes and who didn't have four or more comorbidities.
Justification: 385,460 people died from COVID-19 in 2020 and 452,707 in 2021, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Claims that the figures are inflated by counting those who died "with, not from" COVID-19 are premised on false assertions. And the post’s math also depends on a false claim that 75% of COVID-19 deaths occurred in people with four or more comorbidities. There is no scientific basis for excluding from the death count COVID-19 deaths that occurred in nursing homes. Though the residents are an already-vulnerable population, studies showed that their risk of dying increased during the pandemic. Research shows overall deaths associated with COVID-19 have been undercounted, not overcounted, in the U.S. since the start of the pandemic.
Sources: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: A video from British public broadcaster BBC shows the network was part of a 9/11 conspiracy.
Justification: •BBC reported the collapse of World Trade Center Building 7 before it actually occurred. The network relied on an incorrect report from Reuters, for which Reuters later issued a correction.•BBC staff said there was consistent information that Building 7 was in danger of collapse. The building was on fire for seven hours.
Sources: National Institute of Standards and Technology

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: “Million pounds of rat meat being sold as boneless chicken wings in the U.S.”
Justification: • There is no evidence to support the claim, which originated in 2016 and has been debunked multiple times.
Sources: U.S. Department of Agriculture Food Safety and Inspection Service

Speaker: instagram-posts
Main Claim: Map shows states where “all of the children… are back to living mask-free, normal lives.”
Justification: •Though the majority of states do not have statewide school mask mandates, individual school districts still have mandates.•The absence of state mask rules has not meant a full return to pre-pandemic "normal" at school in most places.
